PARA.TAB: Mr SPEAKER (Hon. Stephen Martin) took the chair at 12.30 p.m., and read prayers.
Consideration resumed from 10 May.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: The government has announced that the public share offer for the Commonwealth's remaining 75 per cent equity in Qantas Airways Ltd will take place in the middle of 1995. The Qantas Sale Act 1992, which established the legislative and administrative framework for the sale, received royal assent on 21 December 1992. Consistent with the conditions then prevailing in the aviation industry, the Qantas Sale Act imposed a limit of 35 per cent on the level of foreign ownership of Qantas. This was supported by a limitation on individual foreign holdings of 25 per cent, and a range of national interest provisions ensuring that Qantas's Australian status would be maintained.

PARA.TAB: The statutory national interest provisions require that Qantas be incorporated in Australia, its main operations base and headquarters remain in Australia and the name of `Qantas' be preserved for the company's scheduled international passenger service. In addition, it is a requirement that the chairman of Qantas and at least two-thirds of the board be Australian citizens.

Following the 1993 amendments, the Air Navigation Act 1920 includes the same national interest provisions as the Qantas Sale Act, and requires that foreign airlines can hold no more than 25 per cent individually and 35 per cent in total of an Australian international airline other than Qantas. However, the Air Navigation Act imposes no overall limitation on holdings by foreigners other than foreign airlines, although if foreign holdings moved above 49 per cent, international carrier status may be challenged by Australia's bilateral aviation partners on the grounds that the carrier may no longer be seen as substantially Australian owned and controlled.

The government believes it is desirable that Qantas should be subject to a similar foreign ownership regime as applies to Ansett and other potential Australian international airlines. Therefore, the government proposes in this bill to increase the overall foreign ownership limit for Qantas from 35 to 49 per cent and to restrict foreign airlines to holding no more than 25 per cent individually and 35 per cent in total of Qantas. The national interest provisions of the Qantas Sale Act would remain unchanged, as would the existing 25 per cent limit on individual holdings of foreigners.

The government considers that all of its Australian ownership and control objectives for Qantas, as well as obligations under Australia's bilateral aviation treaties, would still be met under a higher foreign ownership limit. Placing Qantas in a similar position as applies to Ansett—and any other emerging Australian international airlines—will have no effect on Qantas's Australian status. That status is protected statutorily by the national interest provisions and the overall foreign ownership limit.

A consequence of the proposed change in foreign ownership limitations on Qantas is that the sizeable Qantas float would be able to access additional demand from international equity markets. British Airways already owns 25 per cent of the 35 per cent of Qantas's shares available to foreign investors and, consequently, without any change in the overall limit, a maximum of only 10 per cent could be sold to other foreigners. Indications were that under these arrangements there would be substantial unsatisfied offshore demand.

The participation of foreign investors should therefore assist in attracting full value for the Qantas offer, as the bids of those who routinely value and trade in international airline stocks could be accommodated. This could further the government's objective of seeking, on behalf of taxpayers, the most successful outcome for the float. The ability of foreigners to participate more fully could also assist in establishing a healthy after market for Qantas's stock.

The interests of taxpayers should be better served if any additional offshore demand is able to be taken into account in establishing a fair and justifiable price for the sale of Qantas. In saying this it has to be recognised that even if substantial foreign demand for Qantas's shares emerges, Australian investors will be allocated more than two-thirds of the government's remaining 75 per cent shareholding. I commend the bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Mrs B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to the Qantas Sale Amendment Bill 1995, I think it is worthy to point out that Qantas, in fact, has featured in no less than the last five budgets of this government. Indeed, you could say it has made five farewell appearances from public ownership and could well be known as the Dame Nellie Melba of privatisation in Australia.

PARA.TAB: This bill seeks to amend the Qantas Sale Act 1992 to increase the foreign ownership limit in the Qantas privatisation from 35 per cent of issued capital to 49 per cent and to restrict foreign airlines to holding no more than a combined 35 per cent of the issued share capital.

The explanatory memorandum states that none of the amendments in the bill affect the primary financial impact arising from the sale. However, there is only one reason the government is putting forward the bill, and that is to increase the proceeds of the Qantas float. That is the real intention of the bill—to increase that foreign ownership limit would help to ensure an appropriate return to the Commonwealth.

It has been reported in various publications around Australia that the foreign ownership decision may add $200 million to $300 million to the value of the float. That, of course, is the real driving force behind this decision to flog off an additional percentage of Qantas to foreign ownership. It is this potential $300 million decision which is part of the greatest fraud of the government's budget, and I use the word `fraud' advisedly. We are told it is a surplus, but the government's own documentation shows, in fact, it is a deficit.

The use of the privatisation proceeds to pretend that we are seeing a surplus is something which, I think, has now been shown and understood by the Australian people to not be a fair dinkum budget. It is about time the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) understands that the asset sales do not equate with expenditure restraint, and to suggest that it is fiscally responsible to use such revenue for recurrent expenditure is simply a swindle. It is like selling off the family home to pay for the groceries.

Privatisation proceeds should be used largely to retire debt and to relieve the onerous burden imposed by that debt on us all and on our children in the future. Labor's credibility gap on privatisation proceeds is steadily becoming a gulf. You can be sure that the government's asset sales forecasts in the budget are wrong. After all, they have been wrong almost every year for the last decade. Since Labor came to power, actual privatisation proceeds have fallen short of budget estimates by a whopping $5.1 billion. So why should anyone believe that in this 12-month period we are going to see a realisation of the $5.3 billion that is itemised in the budget?

I think the history of the Qantas float itself makes the point very well that this government is a perfidious government. Initially faced with uncommercial debt to equity ratios, the boards of Qantas and the former Australian Airlines repeatedly raised with the government from 1988 the possibility of greater access to equity capital. In September 1990, the government addressed the issue and decided to sell 100 per cent of Australian Airlines and 49 per cent of Qantas.

After a scoping study, the government announced in April 1991 that the sale of both airlines would proceed on the basis of a trade sale. Submissions of expressions of interest from prospective buyers, including indicative non-binding bids, were invited and from these the operational efficiency gains of combining Qantas and Australian Airlines became clear.

We then move to 1992. In June of that year, it was announced that Qantas would be permitted to acquire Australian Airlines for $400 million and that 100 per cent of the expanded Qantas group would be sold rather than 49 per cent as had been originally decided. The community's interest was said to be protected by a number of national interest safeguards. These safeguards required the Qantas articles of association to contain provisions ensuring several points. These are as follows: that total foreign ownership was not to exceed 35 per cent; that no single foreign interest could exceed 25 per cent; that Qantas's operational base and headquarters would remain in Australia; that the name `Qantas' would be preserved for the company's scheduled international passenger services; that the company would be incorporated in Australia; and that at least two-thirds of the Qantas board would be Australian citizens. The chairman of the board was to be Australian and the directors were to be provided with broad powers, including the power to deny registration or to force the disposal of shares held by foreigners to ensure that foreign ownership limits were not breached.

The 1992 act imposed a restriction to prevent votes of substantial foreign shareholdings, defined as being more than 15 per cent of voting shares in Qantas, being counted in any vote to appoint or remove more than one-third of the directors of Qantas at any given time.
Of these requirements—and the 35 per cent foreign ownership limit in particular—the then Minister for Finance, now the Treasurer (Mr Willis), stated in the second reading speech on 4 November 1992:

SPEECH.PARA: These safeguards are important to maintain the basic character of Qantas, as well as to ensure that Qantas's operating rights under Australia's various bilateral air service agreements and arrangements with other countries are not put under threat. Once in legislation, these safeguards will not be subject to the whim of the Government of the day.

This statement, very simply, reveals the outrageous hypocrisy of the government's decision to increase the foreign ownership at its own whim just because it suddenly needs the money to spend. It is just the same as the l-a-w law tax cuts being done away with and suddenly transposed into superannuation payments.

PARA.TAB: The question remains: why was the 35 per cent limit, in the words of the current Treasurer, `important to maintain the basic character of Qantas' in 1992 when today it can be subject to the whim of a government desperate to get its hands on more cash to finance its supposed government surplus?

TALK.START.PARA: —International aviation considerations.
—That was not your consideration. We should expect this sort of hypocrisy from the government when it comes to Qantas and aviation in general.

PARA.TAB: In 1992 the One Nation statement of the Prime Minister announced the open skies agreement with New Zealand, which, by November 1994, would have allowed Air New Zealand to compete in the domestic Australian market and open up the New Zealand market to Australian players. By June 1994 it was made known to the government that the open skies agreement would have a substantial impact on the profitability of Qantas. Less than a week before the single aviation market was to take effect, a fax from the Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton) revealed that the Australian government had reneged on the agreement. At a meeting between our Prime Minister and the New Zealand finance minister on 8 November 1994, it was made clear that plans for a single aviation market would not proceed.

This from the Prime Minister who struts the international stage to declare to the world that he is a defender of free trade. Really? Thus the additional value for Qantas was preserved. The future of the open skies agreement may rest with the planned sale of News Corporation's half stake in Ansett to Air New Zealand and any future dealing with the Qantas interest in Air New Zealand. The disposal of the Qantas stake was referred to as the `best solution' by Dr Peter Forsyth of the University of New England at a recent AIC conference in a paper titled `Aviation 1995'.

We then come to 1993 and the amendment that resulted in that year. The government's original timetable was for the Qantas privatisation to be finalised by November 1993. A provision of the 1992 act provided that relevant sections of the act would lapse on 31 December 1993 if the sale process had not been completed. The trade sale of 25 per cent to British Airways for $665 million was finalised in March 1993, but it was announced in July 1993 that the float of the remaining 75 per cent would be delayed until the 1994-95 financial year. This decision necessitated the passage of the Qantas Sale Amendment Act 1992 which extended the sale process to a deadline of 30 June 1995.

Then we move on to 1994. We had yet another amendment act. In September last year the Australian Stock Exchange's new electronic share transfer system, the Clearing House Electronic Subregister System, known as CHESS, became operational. As a condition of listing on the Stock Exchange, Qantas would be required to be eligible to participate in CHESS. Under the Qantas Sale Act 1992, however, power was conferred on the directors to refuse to register any transfer of shares which would have resulted in the 35 per cent foreign ownership limit being breached.

These powers, very simply, were inconsistent with the CHESS rules, which allowed unrestricted economic transfer and settlement in shares. Accordingly, the parliament enacted the Qantas Sale Amendment Act 1994 which provided that the Qantas articles of association no longer imposed restrictions on the transfer of shares to give effect to the foreign ownership limit. The government maintained that the disenfranchisement and divestiture provisions which remained in the articles would ensure that the legislative requirements of Qantas to monitor and enforce the foreign ownership restrictions would in fact be fulfilled.

The timetable for the float was progressively delayed by the government to accommodate the further delay. The 1994 act extended the legislative sunset clause by two months to 31 August 1995. The 1994 act removed any ambiguity in pre-existing legislation by providing that the foreign shareholding provisions in the Air Navigation Act 1920 no longer applied to Qantas.

So we come to the actual mechanics of the sale and the appointment of consultants. The float was again delayed on 31 January 1995, with the announcement that the proceeds from the float would not be expected until the 1995-96 financial year, the subject of the current budget. To assist the float process, the following parties were appointed: the Rowland Company to implement a communications strategy to encourage widespread public participation; Ernst and Young Registry Services Pty Ltd as share registrar; Reark Research Pty Ltd to conduct qualitative and quantitative research to gauge investor interest; and, lastly, John Singleton Advertising to mount the privatisation advertising campaign.

It was the appointment and the manner of the appointment of John Singleton which particularly angered me. In addition to John Singleton, three other agencies were asked to pitch for the multimillion dollar account at the last minute. Mojo, the Ball Partnership and Clemenger were asked to present a pitch. Mojo was the holder of the domestic Qantas account and responsible for the I Still Call Australia Home campaign. But it seems that its pitch originally was not considered adequate and so the additional pitches were asked for.

The common factor of the other three is that they all act for political parties—Ball for the New South Wales Liberal Party; Clemenger for the National Party; and John Singleton for the Australian Labor Party. The contract was worth $15 million. It is open to question as to whether Ball and Clemenger were simply asked to pitch as mere window-dressing before the award was made to Singleton, the holder of the ALP advertising contract.

It is well known throughout the advertising industry that Clemenger and Ball were asked to pitch in addition to Mojo, but the identity of the other contender—that is, the successful Singleton tender—was not disclosed until the eleventh hour. There is evidence to suggest that the losing agencies were even gagged by the government. Those agencies were told not to speak to the media on this matter, and at least one agency could not obtain an answer to the question whether their pitch would even be researched after considerable effort was put into its preparation.

We have every right to know what steps were taken by the Department of Finance asset sales task force to ensure that a multimillion dollar government contract was not simply handed to a coterie of government mates including John Singleton and his underling, Bob Hogg, who is associated with Mr Singleton. Interestingly enough, a spokesman for the Department of Finance said that the reason those agencies were chosen to pitch was that they were not associated with other airlines. However, just prior to the announcement of the successful tender, the sister of the Prime Minister was added to the board of the Singleton agency. She, of course, has a well-known association with a different airline.

We now come to another obstacle in the float, the joint services agreement with British Airways. One obstacle to the float which was recently overcome was a draft determination of the Trade Practices Commission on the $1 billion joint services agreement between Qantas and British Airways on scheduling, capacity and pricing of the kangaroo route between Britain and Australia. At the time of the British Airways investment into Qantas, the Trade Practices Commission was assured that the two airlines would be competitive on the kangaroo route.

As a consequence, the commission approved the acquisition. The joint services agreement, however, represented a change of heart on the part of the airlines and, after an application had been made to the commission to approve the agreement, a draft determination was issued against the airlines. In what could be seen as the first attempt at government intervention in a decision of the Trade Practices Commission for 15 years, Ministers Willis, Beazley, Brereton and Lee wrote to the commission urging a different final determination on the issue on the grounds of the impact of the value of the float. Obviously, the government believed that cash for the Treasury coffers was of greater public benefit than any prevention of price fixing to the possible detriment of the travelling public.

It has been suggested that approval of the deal could bring in an extra $250 million for the float. I suppose Labor would call that $250 million worthy of public benefit. If it had been used to retire part of our outstanding international debt, maybe you could argue that way; but to use it as recurrent expenditure, to spend it as quickly as it is received, is simply a waste and a travesty of the privatisation process. On 12 May 1995 the commission handed down its final determination to allow the agreement to run for five years upon certain conditions, after which the airlines must reapply for approval.

I turn to look specifically at the foreign ownership decision. The joint lead managers for the float, Potter Warburg and McIntosh Securities, which have now been joined by Salomon Brothers, reportedly made representations to the government several months ago to raise the foreign ownership limit in Qantas. It was thought that there was an apparent lack of investor demand for the 65 per cent of stock earmarked for local investors and a likely oversubscription of the remaining 10 per cent stake reserved for foreign consumption. The government, with opposition prior knowledge, announced in the budget that the foreign ownership limit would be increased from 35 per cent to 49 per cent. It is this decision which is the subject of the bill that is before us.

Clause 3 of the bill provides that the Qantas Sale Act 1992 is amended according to the schedules set out. Item 1 of the schedule increases the foreign ownership limit in Qantas from 35 per cent of issued capital to 49 per cent. Item 2 restricts the total shareholdings of all foreign airlines combined to no more than 35 per cent of the issued capital in Qantas. Item 3 confirms that the shareholding of any one foreign person, including a foreign airline, is limited to 25 per cent of the total share capital. Item 4 transposes certain definitions from the Air Navigation Act 1920 and the International Air Services Commission Act 1992 into the Qantas Sale Act 1992. Item 5 expands the definition of a foreign person to mean either a foreign airline or a person who is not an Australian person.

It is here that the bilateral agreements become of critical importance. At issue is a matter originally highlighted in the second reading speech for the Qantas Sale Act in 1992—that is, the preservation of Qantas's operating rights under Australia's various bilateral air service agreements, without which Qantas cannot operate as a truly international airline. Legal advice received by the coalition in March on this question was in the following terms:

SPEECH.PARA: In short, there appears to be tacit international agreement that such ownership will not exceed 35%.

Each national government grants to the other national governments under bi-lateral Air Services Agreements the right to designate an airline(s) to operate scheduled services between specified points in the contracting countries. Universally these Agreements provide that a contracting government has the right to prevent a designated airline from operating the agreed services if it is not satisfied that the airline is substantially owned or effectively controlled by the other governments or its nationals. Thus the nature of these Air Service Agreements make it mandatory that a designated airline, in this case Qantas, be relevantly owned and effectively controlled by Australian interests. If such ownership and control is not maintained Qantas's operating rights under various Air Services Agreements could be jeopardised.

These Air Services Agreements do not establish an across the board figure for allowable foreign ownership in a designated flag carrier, but there appears to be tacit agreement on 35%. These limits may be negotiable, however, as the US has allowed KLM to own 49% of Northwest's stock accompanied by limitations on its voting entitlement.

The legal advice concluded that there would have to be solid research done and one would have to be satisfied that those agreements were not placed at risk. Since March the best advice is that the due diligence team has considered this question and is satisfied that after the passage of this bill Qantas will still be regarded for the purposes of the bilaterals as substantially owned and effectively controlled by Australian nationals. As a result of the United States apparent acceptance that the 49 per cent stake of KLM in Northwest Airlines has not destroyed that airline's national status, there is a general acceptance in similar terms for other airlines provided that the majority of board members and senior management are nationals.

PARA.TAB: Applying this test to the current bill, it would seem that the requirements for substantial ownership and effective control pursuant to those agreements have been met by Qantas. In addition, the other so-called national interest safeguards of the Qantas Sale Act 1992, which I outlined earlier, including the following two, are maintained: firstly, Qantas's operational base and headquarters are required to remain in Australia; and, secondly, at least two-thirds of the Qantas board are required to be Australian citizens. The chairman of the board is required to be an Australian citizen as well.
However, it is well to note that this issue was discussed at the most recent International Civil Aviation Organisation conference last year. The official report of the conference is as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: the Conference concluded that:

a)In their air services agreements States usually retain the right, the use of which is optional, to withhold or revoke the operating permit of an air carrier if it is not satisfied that the carrier is not substantially owned and effectively controlled by nationals of the designating party or by the party itself.

b)There was broad support for the need to review this traditional ownership and control requirement in order that carriers could broaden potential sources of investment and that States be given greater opportunities to participate meaningfully in international air transport.

c)The option of broadening the ownership and control criteria to one or more States parties to an agreement or their nationals as well as the variant of an air carrier owned and controlled by nationals or by one or more other States which were part of a pre-defined group with a "community of interest" should be considered.

d)The option of using a criterion based on "headquarters, central administration or principal place of business", regardless of ownership and control received some support but was not acceptable to most delegations, mainly because it was regarded as an unacceptable means of gaining market access; differing interpretations of the terms involved could subject it to abuse; and it might lead to "flags of convenience" with lack of regulatory control and social "dumping", although it was recognised in this connection that the Chicago Convention confers responsibility for safety regulation on the State of registry.

Commercial reality may dictate the future of what constitutes substantial ownership and effective control of an airline by its nationals or, indeed, whether or not this will remain the determining definition. However, at present the requirement for substantial ownership and effective control remains the test as to whether bilateral agreements are honoured. These agreements are fundamental to the business and viability of Qantas.

PARA.TAB: It is theoretically open to a party to one of Australia's around 3,000 agreements to repudiate an agreement on the basis of increased foreign ownership breaching the national ownership/control test. On the material set out above, it is considered that this is unlikely to occur. In the view of Qantas, it will not occur.

The coalition will not oppose this bill, but this decision not to oppose is not to be construed that we are political conscripts of the government's decision. My conviction for privatisation is manifest, but the success or failure of the government's Qantas float is solely the responsibility of the government. The aim of privatisation for us is to have a broader spread of ownership and to see that the proceeds are used for the retirement of debt and not for recurrent purposes.

Let us make it quite clear. The only reason the government is increasing the foreign ownership limit in Qantas is to generate extra cash for its pretend budget surplus. Qantas, quite simply, is being used as kindling to cook the books.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is unfortunate to hear some of the opposition's contributions in this debate on the Qantas Sale Amendment Bill. The opposition seems to want to find reasons why the government should not privatise Qantas, to find what it thinks are flaws in the process or to generally talk down the process. It is unfortunate to hear these things now when we go back to what the opposition said some years ago. In 1989, when my colleague the honourable member for Fadden (Mr Jull) was the spokesman on aviation matters, the opposition's answer to micro-economic reform was to sell the government owned airlines—Australian Airlines and Qantas—outright in a $7 billion garage sale during its first term of office.

PARA.TAB: Fortunately, the people were awake to the opposition then and it did not get to do that. But it did not learn much. Again on 4 April 1991 the opposition demanded that the government fully privatise Qantas. The government has said over time that it was looking at selling part of Qantas. It is now selling the lot.

Even after the opposition in 1989 and 1991 said that we had to get rid of Qantas quick smart, in the House yesterday the honourable member for Forrest (Mr Prosser) derided the sale of assets, claiming that they were swindles and one-offs to make the year's bottom line look a little better. We heard the honourable member for Mackellar (Mrs Bishop) say somewhat similar things a few moments ago. What for the opposition was going to be a fire sale after the 1990 election is now, in a process that the government has looked at sensibly, a swindle and an attempt to make the bottom line look a little better.

The opposition is a little miffed that we have decided to sell Qantas before it had a chance to do so. After more than a decade of pork-barrelling promises by the opposition, all of which were to be funded by asset sales, it must be a real smack in the face for the coalition's economic geniuses, who must now, in the upcoming election process, resort to due and proper funding processes in funding any promises they make to the electorate. We will probably still hear them saying that, if they are elected after the next election, Telecom will be sold to pay for everything that they promise.

The difference between the government and the opposition in how things have been done is that we have planned sensibly. The honourable member for Forrest and others have rightly pointed out that this sale has been on the books of the government for a number of years. But the mischief in the opposition is that it fails to state that, firstly, the revenue from this sale has never been included in budget figures until this year, except as projections for out years, and that, secondly, this is not a fire sale. Unlike the opposition's proposal, this was a careful, deliberate policy move by the government.

The government deferred the finalisation of the float to ensure a maximum return to the public purse. We heard the honourable member for Mackellar say earlier in this debate that it was shocking that the government was trying to maximise the sale price of Qantas and not using the proceeds to retire debt or something like that. It was all right for the opposition in earlier years to fund all sorts of shonky election promises with fire sales.

The opposition also conveniently forgets that in 1988 Qantas and Australian Airlines urged the government to float as a means of acquiring the required capital to enable them to remain competitively placed in the market. In response to the government's announcement in 1991 of its intention to float a total of 49 per cent of the shares in Qantas, the opposition went into its usual reactionary mode and said that we were not doing enough. It called for full privatisation immediately. It always has to go one better. It wants things done quicker and done now. It does not think of what can be got for a public asset; it wants to just get rid of it quickly.

Look at the Qantas government guaranteed losses for that financial year. Most analysts would agree that that probably would have been the dumbest thing that anyone could have done in 1991. At that time, honourable members might recall that, following deregulation, the pilots dispute and the downturn in tourism from the Gulf War, Qantas was haemorrhaging at $1 million per day. It foreshadowed a loss of $350 million that year, possibly bowing out to half a billion dollars in the following financial year. The opposition said that we ought to have privatised the lot then. It just shows the business aptitude of these so-called captains of industry opposite. The problem with the opposition in the House of Representatives is that it contains the dregs of the business world who cannot find jobs.

Rather than sell at a time when the share price probably would not have even got off the floor, the government's policy was to manage the float in such a way that we would get a good return on the people's investment. The government managed Qantas over those years to ensure that it turned the $376 million loss of 1992-93 into a $156 million profit last year. Even the economic gurus on the opposition side might realise that one gets a far better share price for a business that is making a $150 million profit than one that has turned in a $376 million loss.

Half yearly results to December, which were announced in March this year, were $128 million—an increase of 79 per cent on the same period last year. So the government is going into this float with the profitability of Qantas being about the best it has ever been, which will attract quite a premium for the sale of the business. The targets the government's plan outlined in 1991 and 1992, when the government announced that Qantas had acquired Australian Airways, were correct. In December 1992 the cabinet approved the sale of a 25 per cent stake in Qantas to British Airways in an attempt to ensure that Qantas became more integrated into the world market and had on-carriage rights and better facilities for passengers in the European market.

If we look at a map of the airline schedulings of the world, we see that a fit with Qantas and BA is a very useful fit for a medium sized airline like Qantas. The distribution of British Airways around the world is Europe, Africa and parts of north Asia, but it is very light in the area of the world where we have a very substantial part of the business. So the synergies between Qantas and British Airways are very good for Qantas.

No doubt my colleagues who follow me will tell us that there would be a better fit with Thai International or an airline like that, but I really think the fit with Qantas and BA is a good one. Some might argue that Lufthansa, as an airline of the same size, might have been a better arrangement, but I think the synergies that Qantas gets with having British Airways as a partner are both good for Australian travellers and good for Qantas.

When we sold that 25 per cent stake in Qantas to British Airways we also said we intended to sell the other 75 per cent at the end of 1993. The government changed that schedule from 1993-94 to the 1994-95 financial year to take advantage of what we expected was an upturn of the economy and in the travelling public. That decision the government made has been shown to be a very smart one. Improvements in the financial performance of Qantas are expected to continue, given the management's focus on increased profitability, notably through exploiting the synergies with British Airways I mentioned before; the application of greater controls over costs; and improved efficiencies in utilisation of aircraft—for example, purchasing of larger capacity aircraft, which both maximises passenger potential and minimises noise emanations around the airports of Australia.

What I believe really annoys the opposition is that the government has managed to float Qantas so well. It ensured Qantas was in a strong market position to maximise the potential returns to the taxpayers in this float. Today's bill changes those arrangements only at the margins, but these are very important changes because they will improve the position of Qantas in the float by allowing foreign investors in total to acquire up to 49 per cent of Qantas, but any particular foreign entity will be restricted to 25 per cent.

This brings the foreign ownership in line with the limitations for other Australian carriers and places Qantas in a competitive position in the market. While that limitation of 25 per cent for any foreign owner is not set out in the Air Navigation Act, the government's aviation policy requires that other airlines seeking to become designated international carriers comply with bilateral agreement requirements, which is that they be substantially owned and effectively controlled by Australian nationals.

Under the Air Navigation Act such carriers are required to meet various national interest criteria. Those criteria include: at least two-thirds of the board members being Australian citizens; the chairperson of the board being an Australian citizen; the airline's operational base being in Australia; and relevant interest by foreign airlines individually not exceeding 25 per cent or in aggregate not exceeding 35 per cent of the total value of the issued share capital.

The Air Navigation Act imposes no overall limitation on holdings by foreigners, other than by foreign airlines. But, if foreign holdings moved above 49 per cent, international carrier status could be challenged by Australia's bilateral partners on the grounds that the carrier may no longer be seen as a substantially Australian owned and controlled entity.

As the Minister for Finance (Mr Beazley) stated earlier, the government believes it is desirable that Qantas be subjected to the same foreign ownership regime that applies to Ansett and other potential Australian and international airlines. With this legislation and this program of privatising Qantas, we want to place on the Australian market a large corporation which will be very viable and will not have regulatory or legislative impositions on it any different from those imposed on other players in the market.

The national interest provisions of the bill remain unchanged and set individual foreign holdings at a maximum of 25 per cent. These changes in foreign ownership limitation mean that Qantas will be able to access additional demand from international equity markets, which will be good for the Qantas share price. With these changes to foreign ownership, Qantas can take full advantage of that offshore demand. The changes to the foreign ownership limits will mean that Qantas will attract a better value, and that is in the interests of the Australian taxpayers who own this business. The government has done all it can to ensure that Qantas is a viable player in the international transport game.

Qantas should go to the market looking to the future as a very viable and successful Australian commercial operation. It should not be looking to the past, to its previous incarnation as a government business enterprise. In some of the statements made by Qantas executives you see this hankering for the good old days of being a GBE. That is a very regrettable situation. Qantas has to understand that when it is freed from public ownership there will not be any more free rides. It will be competing in the market and the government should not be giving it any more of an edge than it gives to any other business enterprise.

There is this harking back, wanting to have the best of both worlds. Recently, Qantas has said that the government should give it some undertaking that it should never have to fly into Sydney West airport. It feels it should be a protected species and that Sydney West should be the airport that other airlines use. It says the government should do that for it because Qantas is the government's airline. But it is not the government's airline. Qantas wants to be set free—it wanted to be set free in 1988—and the government is now setting it free. Once it is set free it will be out there in the market and cannot have that sort of guarantee.

In a recent article in the Australian, the Managing Director of Qantas, James Strong, declared that Qantas would not expand its operation to Badgerys Creek. Mr Strong said that Badgerys Creek was not a viable option for Qantas, although it was fine for others to move out there. If you talk to Qantas executives privately, they are saying we should force the others to move out there. They are saying that Sydney airport should be the airport for Qantas and maybe Ansett while everyone else—the other international operators, commuter airlines and charter operators—should be forced out to Sydney West.

Qantas says that it wants to have a special status—it is an Australian company and the government used to own it. Qantas has made some bad mistakes in the past when it was a government entity. It put all its eggs in the one basket with Sydney airport. It was never willing to accept that Sydney airport had a shelf life and that there needed to be expansion somewhere else. With the expansion of traffic into Sydney, and with the expansion of international traffic into Australia, Sydney airport is not going to become Qantas international airport.

Qantas will have to, as will other operators, move out and take advantage of Sydney West airport. It is no good for Qantas, once it is privatised, to expect the special deals it was able to get when it was a government entity. The market is there. Qantas has to meet it and should be able to succeed in that market. The government has given Qantas as much assistance as it could along the way to support the share price. Qantas will now have to look to the future as a fully privatised Australian business; it will have to share the perils and the profits from doing that.

Qantas cannot keep carping and harping on about special deals and saying that if it does not get special deals it will have to shed staff or it may have to have its work done overseas. Qantas cannot, on the one hand, say that the government ought to help it because it is a good Australian corporation and then, on the other hand, say, `If you do not help us, we will shed staff, we will move some of our maintenance operations offshore, or we will start to source things elsewhere.'

Qantas has found that the biggest selling points it has are its safety record and the fact that it is Australia's international airline. Its own research shows that, if it steps away from that concept of Australianness, its selling position in the market is going to deteriorate. Why would you go on Qantas and pay full fare if Thai International, or one of the other international operators that tend to act more as foreign exchange earners for their governments than as airline businesses, can sell you a cheaper fare?

I commend this bill to the House. In doing so, I say to Qantas executives that what we want to see Qantas become is an active Australian corporation looking to the future and putting behind it its GBE days. We want to see it go out there and make a profit which will be good for it, and provide an airline service which will be good for all Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is much in the speech by the honourable member for Watson (Mr Leo McLeay) with which I agree, and much with which I disagree. I was fascinated to hear of the approaches that have been made to him by Qantas in terms of its moving its operations to Badgerys Creek or the Sydney West airport. I think we have all heard those. My suggestion to the honourable member for Watson would be that next time Qantas goes to him with that line he ought to tell it to do some homework on what the traffic to the western suburbs of Sydney is. It might find out that already there is enough traffic going into Sydney international daily that would justify five services a week from Melbourne and three services a week from Brisbane—and that is before we even start.

PARA.TAB: The fact that the business heart of Sydney is moving west to Parramatta and that there is something like the population of Brisbane living west of Parramatta augurs well for a very bright and rosy future for the Sydney West airport, both in a domestic and an international sense. That is not to say that there is no future for Kingsford Smith airport. The reality is that we will need two airports. The reality is that the population is moving westward. The reality is that anybody who is going to make a dollar out of the airline business ultimately will have to have some sort of operation at Sydney West airport.

The Qantas Sale Amendment Bill—as I think somebody mentioned this morning—has probably had more comebacks than Dame Nellie Melba. For five years we have been looking forward to the day when we finally get the Qantas sale off the books. The honourable member for Watson made reference to what the opposition had proposed in 1989. My suggestion is that, had we been in power in those days, many of the difficulties that Australia and Australian aviation have struck since that time would not have been in existence. I very much doubt that we would have had the disastrous 1989 pilots dispute. I very much doubt that we would have had the downturn in the economy that we experienced in those times.

The privatisation of Qantas and Australian Airlines should have been undertaken many years ago because privatisation is not only about selling off the silver; it is about getting efficiencies into the operations; it is about the major convergence from a government instrumentality into a private operation and the resultant efficiencies that can be brought about. It would have meant a major change in the nature and philosophy of Australian airlines. We needed that change for the reasons mentioned by the honourable member for Watson. We had this old GBE attitude that what is good for Qantas is good for Australia. I am afraid that was not necessarily so.

Five years later, once this legislation is passed, we can see the benefits in an operational sense that the privatisation of Qantas might be able to bring about. The privatisation of Qantas will be a momentous occasion for the Australian money markets. I congratulate the honourable member for Mackellar (Mrs Bishop) for her reading of the government's aims in the privatisation of Qantas. She has mentioned what the government intends to do with the proceeds.

It is perfectly correct that, apart from the operational efficiencies that one can get from a privatised entity, one of the things we should have been looking at was retiring the debt with the proceeds of the sale. That is not to be. We have to ensure that, once Qantas is privatised, the country can benefit. In her contribution, the honourable member for Mackellar went, chapter and verse, through some of the difficulties that could have resulted from the government's decision just prior to the last election to increase the foreign ownership of Qantas to 49 per cent.

It is true that in past years there have been difficulties with foreign shareholdings for some overseas carriers. Interestingly enough, British Airways was one of those companies that suffered in the United States. After privatisation it was found that British Airways had a foreign shareholding of 39 per cent. The American carriers said that British Airways was not a British entity if it had that sort of shareholding.

That brought into focus that particular piece of folklore within the airline industry that 35 per cent foreign ownership is the ultimate maximum. However, we then saw disastrous times. We saw those huge seas of red ink coming out of the American aviation industry. We saw the near collapse of some of America's major carriers, including North West and Continental. We saw European carriers come into the industry in America. We saw KLM go into North West and we saw the Scandinavian Airline System buy into Continental.

In true American tradition, all that went out the window when the 49 per cent situation was reached. It has now virtually become the accepted norm within the international airline industry. Hopefully, that particular position is covered by having the 35 per cent limit in the legislation. If there are advantages in having a greater foreign holding, we are covered by the 49 per cent.

There are a couple of other aspects in the lead-up to this legislation that I would like to raise. My colleague the honourable member for Mackellar made particular reference to the situation of the Trade Practices Commission and its draft determination of the joint services agreement between Qantas and British Airways on the kangaroo route. I will not go into all that again, except to say that I thought Professor Fels had some very pertinent points to make in his initial finding. The reality of this delay in the privatisation of Qantas has meant that Australian aviation has not necessarily been able to develop to its full potential in the last five years; the Australian travelling public has not necessarily had the full benefits of privatisation and the open competition that could have been brought about if privatisation had occurred earlier; and inbound tourism operators did not necessarily have the best result for their operations as a result of the delays. In his determination Professor Fels highlighted one thing: he was concerned that, with the tie-in between British Airways and Qantas on the kangaroo route, we would see a lack of competitive force on that route.

That fact may or may not have been right. The kangaroo route is the most competitive in the world in terms of price. I rang a couple of travel agents before I came in here today and found that the price for a return trip to London at the moment varies between $1,650 and $2,800. So there are some fairly competitive price forces involved there.

Professor Fels was right to point out the possibility of losing some of these competitive forces if this move was allowed to go ahead unchallenged. My concern is that it may not be the kangaroo route which gets the collusion in the future but some of the other routes to and from Australia if we allow a situation to develop where one carrier can virtually control the market.

It all comes about through this process called code sharing. Code sharing has always been fairly well developed in the United States, and we are seeing more and more of it here at the moment. It is fairly obvious that the Qantas-British Airways tie-in is going to allow for a lot of code sharing because you are not just talking about two airlines but a number of airlines. You are talking about the British Airways arrangements with US Air in the United States, with TAT in France, with Deutsche BA in Germany, and with a number of other minor carriers with which they have affiliations. We always have to be vigilant so the Australian travelling public, and those travelling to Australia, will not be disadvantaged if we get those cosy arrangements with a combination of those airlines that go typically under the expression `code sharing'.

The situation in the United States at the moment is quite interesting. If you go into a travel agent there and book on, say, Continental for an overseas trip, you could well find yourself flying on Air Canada, Air France, SAS, Alitalia, or some other carrier. If you book on United, you may find yourself travelling on Lufthansa, Thai Airways International, Transbrasil, British Midland or ALM Dutch Antillean airlines.

If you book on Delta, which is an interesting one because it has a cross-share arrangement with Singapore Airlines and Swiss Air, you might find yourself travelling on any one of those three airlines but you could also be travelling on Malev, Aeroflot, Vietnam Airlines, Varig, Swissair, Sabena, Austrian, TAP—Air Portugal—or Virgin Atlantic. Basically, you are getting a situation where these combinations, under the title of code shares, are being used to allow airlines to go into markets where maybe they have not operated before. It also gives them a chance to bump up the price.

Nobody would deny that, in terms of the earning capacity of international airlines, things have been pretty tight in the last few years. We have seen some enormous losses in recent times. In one year alone in North America, the airlines lost more money than they had made in the whole period since World War II. So nobody would deny the fact that the airlines have to get their efficiencies into place, but you also have to be careful that you do not get rid of that competitive force.

I read a report by Paul Dempsey, the director of the transportation law program at the University of Denver, who is the author of a number of books as well as the president of the consumer advocacy group Americans for a Sound Aviation Policy. He aligned the whole business of code sharing with the expression `P.T. Barnum lives'. Of course, you will remember that Mr Barnum, well-known American business mogul, was once renowned for his assertion: `There is a sucker born every minute.'

Dempsey claims that this getting together of the airlines has resulted in consumer fraud, which is just pure and simple fraud and very anti-competitive. In the case of the United States, that could well be true. The fact that Professor Fels, and his particular organisation, has given only a five-year guarantee to this agreement between British Airways and Qantas is a good example. I sincerely hope that the Trade Practices Commission will also monitor some of the other activities on some of those other routes to and from Australia over these coming years to make sure that people who use our airlines do not miss out on some of that competitive pricing and that our international tourism effort is not jeopardised simply because we have been able to bump up the fares so quickly.

I mentioned earlier that there have been a number of areas in which the Australian travelling public has missed out because of the delays in the privatisation of Qantas. Another area of particular concern to me which has been raised in this House on a number of occasions is that agreement with the New Zealand government to open up the trans-Tasman services and to have an open skies operation between here and New Zealand and around the Pacific Rim.

There were many pluses for Australia in that arrangement. It was not, as the Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton) said, all Air New Zealand's way. It was not only an opportunity for Australians to benefit from the results of opening up that system but was also certainly a great opportunity to open up the South Pacific. We know that the real reason the government reneged on that proposition with New Zealand was simply to try to bolster the Qantas float. I hope that, once this float is out of the way, we can see an open slather arrangement across the Tasman and the opening up of this part of the world, because the benefits to tourism, foreign exchange earnings and job creation will be tremendous, not only for Australia and New Zealand but also for many of the small island states that are there. I think the excuses made by the minister were quite dreadful at the time and did no good for our international status as a major aviation player.

The other area in which I think we have suffered has been in the area of charter policy. In 1990, the government made a determination and changed the charter regime with another review that was due for 1994. The review was done 12 months ago. The results and recommendations of that review went to the minister. We have heard no more of it since. We are not likely to hear much of it, obviously because there might be a chance to undermine the value of Qantas.

I am afraid that the world is much bigger than this extra $250 million that the government may or may not get out of the Qantas float. I hope that one of the things the minister will do very soon is to make sure that he releases the result of that study into charter policy, and I hope he will pick up on some of its recommendations, which, I understand, are there to give us a more liberal regime.

Some of the great difficulties that we have in Australia are that we are at the end of the line and we are at the end of some long, thin routes. Charter policy is certainly one way in which we can build up international traffic into Australia, if we do it properly. Unfortunately, there has been almost an obsession by this government with the privatisation of Qantas, with consequent delays, which has probably been quite detrimental to Australian aviation and to the future growth of the Australian tourism industry.

The member for Watson made a statement that amused me. He was talking about the fit into the international air routes that Qantas and British Airways may be able to bring about. He said that he thought that was very good for Qantas and for the Australian travelling public. I believe that it probably will be. Let me say this: it is much better for British Airways and for the British travelling public. One thing that I think we have to be very aware of is the history of British Airways and its capacity to take over a market. It is quite interesting.

Once that privatisation is through, we are going to be dealing with a pretty tough customer. Take a look at British Airways and its history with airlines like British Caledonian Airways and Dan Air, and at the ongoing court cases with Virgin Atlantic at the moment. Bear in mind that Virgin Atlantic will soon be coming on the Australian route and that Mr Branson from Virgin Atlantic Airlines has won, I think, something like #860 million so far from British Airways in his challenges in the court. We will be dealing with one of the largest aviation groups in the world. We do not want ourselves to be totally swamped with a mentality in Qantas that big is absolutely beautiful and that everything it says must be taken as holy writ.

I hope that in this fit we will be able, through bodies like the Trade Practices Commission, to have a capacity to monitor what is going on so that the advantages that this particular privatisation process and the arrangement with British Airways can bring will not mean that Australian aviation will not have the capacity to be fully developed and will not have the capacity to maximise the effects on the fare paying passengers of Australia and those inbound tourists who want to come to Australia. We want to make sure that they can still do it efficiently, but we also want to make sure that they can do it at the right price.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slipper Mr P.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is important to remember that the Qantas Sale Amendment Bill 1995 is about an increase in revenue for the government of between $200 million and $300 million. The government hopes to raise this revenue through the changes that would be brought about if this bill became law. The main thrust of the bill is to increase the foreign ownership limit of Qantas from 35 to 49 per cent in the forthcoming public share issue. The bill also restricts individual foreign airlines owning more than 25 per cent of the issued share capital of Qantas. The existing 25 per cent limit on holdings by foreign individuals would be unchanged. Finally, the bill restricts foreign airlines in total to owning no more than 35 per cent of the issued share capital of Qantas.

PARA.TAB: The government has, in five successive budgets, trotted out the proposed sale of Qantas as a means of reducing the budget deficit. The Treasurer, the member for Gellibrand (Mr Willis), stood up in the House of Representatives a couple of weeks ago and told us bravely that the government was going to have a surplus of some $780 million. This is as a result of the budget fraud to be perpetrated on the Australian people.

When you look at the fudged figures, the paper shuffle and the downright fraud in this budget you find that the reality is quite different. The reality is that the figures brought down by the Treasurer in the budget a short while ago indicate that we have an $8.2 billion deficit not a surplus of $780 million. Part of the artificial surplus creatively produced by the Treasurer in the budget came from the sale of Qantas. The government has, budget after budget, sought to sell off Qantas in its endeavour to balance the books.

The government has been faced with a tortured path on the way to this Qantas float. One only has to look at various newspapers articles over the last couple of years to understand that. The Sydney Morning Herald on 5 November 1994 ran an article entitled `Qantas float will be delicate test for nervous investors'. It also ran an article on 19 July 1994 entitled `Govt faces tough task selling Qantas'. The Australian Financial Review on 16 February 1995 ran an article entitled `Qantas float: pressure grows for higher foreign ownership levels'. The effect of this bill would be to create that higher foreign ownership. The Age on 21 February 1995 ran a headline entitled `Hard sell on Qantas float'. The Canberra Times on 20 March 1995 ran an article entitled `Sale of Qantas may not prove to be windfall'.

This government has obviously been desperate to do anything it can to bring in some dollars from the projected sale of Qantas. It has told us five budgets in a row that we are going to raise money from the sale of Qantas, yet we find at this time that not one dollar has been raised. The government is asking for the support of this House to increase the foreign ownership limit of Qantas from 35 to 49 per cent. The government desperately hopes that will increase the take from the sale of Qantas by some $200 million to $300 million. The government has been totally, utterly and completely dishonest and hypocritical.
On 4 November 1992 in a second reading speech, the then Minister for Finance, the member for Gellibrand, said:

SPEECH.PARA: These safeguards—
which include the 35 per cent foreign ownership—

are important to maintain the basic Australian character of Qantas, as well as to ensure that Qantas's operating rights under Australia's various bilateral air service agreements and arrangements with other countries are not put under threat. Once in legislation, these safeguards will not be subject to the whim of the Government of the day.

As has been noted by my colleague the honourable member for Mackellar (Mrs Bishop) and others, the question must now be asked: why was it that in 1992 the 35 per cent rule was vital, essential and necessary to maintaining the character of Qantas as an Australian airline and yet in 1995 the figure has mysteriously blown out to 49 per cent?

PARA.TAB: The honourable member for Fadden (Mr Jull) in his erudite speech a few minutes ago pointed out to us the problems that other airlines such as British Airways had when they expanded their foreign ownership beyond the level of 35 per cent. The government must be accountable to the people of Australia for its proposal in this legislation to blow out foreign ownership from 35 per cent to 49 per cent. With the 3,000-odd international agreements relating to air travel, is Qantas now in jeopardy at 49 per cent foreign ownership of losing its essential Australian character? Will all of those agreements entered into by Australia with other nations be at risk? Will Qantas, instead of being a company which a lot of people want to buy, become a shell party to agreements which become absolutely worthless?

I think the government has not looked into this matter sufficiently. The government has been motivated by the need to cook the books. The government has been motivated by the need to produce a more acceptable budget night figure. The government has also been motivated largely by the desire to produce this artificial, fraudulent $780 million budget surplus claimed by the Treasurer on budget night. During question time on days succeeding the budget, even the Treasurer could not keep a straight face when talking about a budget surplus. He knows, as we know, the reality is that there is an $8.2 billion budget deficit. When the Treasurer was answering questions, he stumbled over words. He referred to a budget deficit rather than a budget surplus.

The government has been entirely inconsistent. Not only were comments made by the Treasurer in 1992, but as recently as February this year a spokeswoman for the Minister for Finance (Mr Beazley) was reported in the Australian Financial Review as saying:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the 35 per cent ceiling on overseas shareholdings in Qantas stood firm and no plans existed to change the parameters written into the sale legislation.

If this report in the Financial Review is accurate, then in the space of 11 or 12 weeks the government has obviously decided to turn the finance minister into a person who is deliberately economical with the truth.

PARA.TAB: What the finance minister or his spokesperson said 11 or 12 weeks ago—namely, that the 35 per cent ceiling remained as of May 1995—is not the truth. The government has again changed its mind on this issue. The government has again broken its word, in the way that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has junked the tax cuts proposed and announced prior to the last election. We all know, and the people of Australia who are listening to this debate today know, that the l-a-w tax cuts became the l-i-e deception. It has meant that the Prime Minister's word has become w-o-r-t-h-l-e-s-s, absolutely worthless.

The reason for the government's about-face in relation to the increase in the proportion of foreign ownership of Qantas to be permitted pursuant to this bill is obvious. It is a desperate attempt by a desperate government which knows that it is going to be decimated at the polls to pull a rabbit out of the hat to make the people of Australia believe that it has been more fiscally and financially responsible than it has. We in the opposition—and we will be the government after the next election—

TALK.START.PARA: —Ho, ho, ho! You've said that before.

—You may well laugh. Let me make a prediction: the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) will be the Prime Minister of this country, and I believe that history will show he will be one of the greatest Prime Ministers this nation will ever have. One ought to remember that the government in this bill is driven by a desperate need to again cook the books—a desperate need to maintain its budget surplus, which every responsible economic commentator in Australia admits is a fraud.

PARA.TAB: We, on this side of the House, very strongly support the principle of the privatisation of Qantas Airways. We do not believe that the government should be running airlines. We do not believe that the government should be running banks. We believe that it is appropriate that the Australian people should be given the opportunity to buy shares in important Australian enterprises. But, while I support what is actually happening in this legislation, I simply cannot, in any way shape or form, back the rationale behind the government, because I believe that the introduction of these changes in the Qantas Sale Amendment Bill 1995 seek to perpetrate a fraud on the Australian people, and we on this side of the parliament would certainly never support any fraud on the Australian people.

The government has claimed that despite the increase in foreign ownership from 35 per cent to 49 per cent Qantas will retain its essential character as an Australian enterprise because it will continue to be incorporated in Australia and it will maintain an operations base and headquarters located in this country. The government also claims that participation of additional foreign investors should help ensure the government attracts full value for Qantas.

It is all a question of words. The government is really admitting here that the increase in foreign ownership of Qantas, Australia's national flag carrier, from 35 per cent to 49 per cent is all about dollars. It is not about what is right and proper. It is not about consistency. It is not about honesty. It is not about decency. It is not about accountability; it is all about money. It is all about the extra $200 million to $300 million which the increase in foreign equity from 35 per cent to 49 per cent will hopefully raise, from the government's point of view, when the float finally takes place.

This government, I believe, stands condemned by the Australian people for yet again breaking its word. This government in five successive budgets has endeavoured to flog off Australia's national flag carrier. This government has failed to do so. The headlines in the newspaper and community sentiment indicate that this government is going to have a very difficult job in raising the kind of money that it wants to from Qantas.

This government, therefore, has come in in 1995, five budgets after first announcing the sale of Qantas, and wants to change the rules to increase what it expects to get. It has told us that it plans to get between $200 million and $300 million more than it would otherwise get. This change proposed in this bill indicates in another way that the Australian people are not able to accept the word of this government. This indicates that the government is driven by a desperate need to raise funds at all costs—at the cost of its integrity, at the cost of its policy. I believe that the government will be, in effect, shown up at the next election for what it is—a government which is not able to tell the truth, a government of dishonesty, a government which continues to perpetrate fraud at the expense of the Australian people.

Summing up, I endorse totally the excellent contribution made by my colleague the honourable member for Mackellar. She has pointed out the sordid and shabby motives which have propelled the government to bring this legislation into this place. She has also pointed out the very real dangers which exist to Qantas's future. For $200 million to $300 million, this government is putting at risk the international airline agreements which have given Qantas certain rights because it is considered to be an Australian airline.

This government has been motivated by the dollars. This government is not motivated by principle. This government, I believe, has absolutely no integrity left. If anyone had any doubt at all, one would only have to look at this legislation and at the government's budget strategy. The government in the budget announced a surplus of $780 million, which everyone agrees was an absolute fraud.

The reality is that the budget deficit was $8.2 billion. The money which the government proposes to raise from the sale of Qantas has been included in the receipt side of the budget, to create part of this artificial budget surplus of $780 million. It ought to be remembered that last year's asset sales were a flop and, after budgeting for proceeds of $2.4 billion, only $55 million was realised. If the government is no more successful this year than last year—and there is no indication that the government will be—its budgeted $5.3 billion in asset sales should read $121.4 million and there will be a shortfall of $5.18 billion.

These facts that I have outlined in the chamber will blow the government's budget strategy right out of the water. The government, in its budget, fudged the figures. It was dishonest. That is why I was very pleased to hear the Leader of the Opposition, in his budget response, indicate that in government we will have very many more principles than those opposite, as far as announcing the true situation when Australia's budget is released. I support totally what the honourable member for Mackellar has said; I support totally what my colleague the honourable member for Fadden has said; and I believe that history will record that this is a government of dishonesty, a government of fraud and a government which will stand condemned. It will be swept from office in a very major and very substantial way at the time of the next election.

To refresh the memory of honourable members, let me read from the Hansard of 12 September 1985. This is a speech by the member for Newcastle (Mr Allan Morris). He said:

SPEECH.PARA: How about the Budget Post Office? Those are the kinds of things that the average Australian can understand. Who could afford to buy the Commonwealth Bank? SPEECH.PARA: Big joke! Within a few years, all of that turned around. I thank the honourable member for his question. Those who talk about privatisation really are trotting out a very tired old piece of ideology which has been around for a long time. It is the usual ploy used by those tired old conservatives opposite.

The government has not even got the decency to pretend that it is going to sell it to Australians. I cannot believe the Australian Labor Party in what we are hearing today in the parliament with regard to the sale of Qantas. Further, in 1987 the member for Jagajaga (Mr Staples) made a statement in the House on a matter of public importance. It might enlighten the House to hear what he said:

What about the Opposition's privatisation policies? It wants to sell off the assets of the Australian public. What will it sell Telecom Australia for—$7? Do I hear $8? What about Australian Airlines, Qantas Airways Ltd, or perhaps the Commonwealth Bank of Australia?
He was being cynical here, was he not? What a cynical government the Australian Labor Party is. The member continued:
Now we are talking big bikkies. Let us look at last year's profits of the Commonwealth Bank—the people's bank; the big Australian bank. It had a 55 per cent profit increase.
The government is selling the Commonwealth Bank after all of that talk. The legislation before us proposes the sale of Qantas. It was a slow process getting to this point.

PARA.TAB: I refer the House to statements made by the former chairman of Qantas in 1992, Mr Bill Dix. He said that he would have to indicate that he believed that 48 per cent—which was the amount being spoken about at that time—foreign ownership of Qantas would raise in excess of $1 billion. In an interview on 11 March 1992, Mr Dix said that he believed the asset sales task force would resolve the situation by raising $1 billion for Qantas.

The Qantas Sale Bill, which was introduced in November 1992, sought to sell Qantas in three stages, to impose conditions on the articles of association of the private company and to allow certain financial transactions by the Commonwealth to facilitate the sale. The details of the sale were announced by the government in 1991. In February 1992 the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) delivered the One Nation statement which contained modifications to aviation policy and the proposed sale.

In a period of approximately four years, the government has played with the idea of selling Qantas, even though one of the great icons, one of the great traditions of the Labor Party of Australia, is that the government and the people should own these things. The irony of this situation is that the government has been hypocritical in every election. Remember when the Prime Minister bagged John Hewson in the countdown to the last election about whether Hewson's word could be trusted with respect to introducing legislation for the goods and services tax? This government has introduced legislation after legislation which restricts foreign ownership of Qantas airlines. Again, we are changing that today. The talk is that Qantas will basically become an out-station of British Airways and that we will have the flying kangaroo but it will not really be Australian any more. The Australian Labor Party has said to the Australian people at election after election, `We are truly patriotic. We really believe that Australians are good. I wish to disclose the way the government has sold Australian assets over the last few years. In 1991 the government said that it was going to sell $1 billion worth of Australian government assets. But, on each occasion, the budget looked good to the Australian people because the government estimated that it would sell assets of this worth. The government said, `Yes, on this side we're going to spend so much but on the other side we're going to sell so much so that things will look all right when you rule off the bottom line of the budget.' I do not know what would happen to the Australian people—and I do not believe that they are foolish—should they happen to vote the Labor Party back next year, because there will be nothing left to sell. It will have sold everything within the period it will have been in office. It will have sold everything, got rid of it. The cupboard will be bare. And in what way will Australians have benefited from it? You have had record sales of assets, record unemployment, record inflation, record bankruptcies—record everything that is bad—and you have sold the lot in order to make that continue to happen.

The Australian people will come to the year 1995-96 and see that the budget says the government is going to sell $5.3 billion worth of assets—that is what you say you are going to sell. Given your track record—which indicates that you have not sold nearly that amount, but you are doing it to make the outturn look good—it is no wonder that the Westpac Bank in its bulletin, in its post budget summary of what the government has done, stated:

SPEECH.PARA: 1995-96 Budget: too little, too late
It particularly talks about the budget surplus being `achieved with smoke and mirrors'. It states:
Financial markets were expecting a structural tightening in the order of $3.5 billion, but received only $2.6 billion.

In the period 1992-93 to 1993-94, the Government brought down a succession of fiscal packages designed to stimulate the economy, which injected in a full year just over $6bn into the economy. Genuine structural tightening should have been undertaken in last year's Budget. . .
Westpac goes on to state:
The Federal Government has projected a surplus—
in this budget—
of $0.7 billion. However, this seemingly attractive "headline" surplus relies on $5bn of extra asset sales which we define broadly to include equivalents such as early debt repayments by states.
Altogether there will be $7.5 billion of asset sales in 1995-96, hence the underlying deficit is more like $6.7bn.

There we have one of our great banks just saying, `Well, the deficit is really bad; it is really $6.7 billion because the government is insisting on including in the budget sales of organisations such as Qantas.'

PARA.TAB: I hope that we will see the day when Qantas really does flourish, because I do not believe that it will flourish while the shackles are on it. One of the highlights of this legislation—and one has to wonder at a government being so crass as to have this included in its legislation or needing to have this included in its legislation—for an Australian airline, owned by Australians but in fact funded by foreigners, is the inclusion of certain things so that we can be sure that Qantas really has a token, a shell, of Australian respectability. The government has to put that in the legislation.

We had the Prime Minister bagging John Hewson about whether or not he could legislate food out of a goods and services tax, and this government is legislating that an airline's headquarters are to be in Australia. We have seen the government do that time and again with the media. We have seen the way in which it has been prepared to deny citizenship rules for Rupert Murdoch. PARA.TAB: We have been over the government's record for the last 10 years. In 10 years it has proved that it does not believe in anything, that it does not stand for anything, that it will change any of its ideology or belief if it means it will stay in office. Despite all of the protestations about how good and how well managed it has been, one speaker for the Australian Labor Party has presented this as a good decision and a decision in Australia's interests.

Ultimately, it is a good decision. It is five or six years too late. The government is doing it the wrong way. It has had to pull in foreign interests because of the way it has so mucked up the sale of Qantas. At the end of the day, it has had to write into the legislation so the government is believable that the chairman has to remain an Australian, that the headquarters have to be in Australia and the directors have some power to control foreign interests.
