TALK.START.PARA: —I want to take this opportunity, in speaking in the budget debate for this year, to raise my profound concerns about the forestry industry in Australia. For some time I have felt increasing concern at what I see as the rape of our scarce natural forest resources for short-term economic benefits to forestry companies. My concern is that, by subsidising forestry activities, including woodchipping in native forests, we are all on the one hand destroying the heritage of future generations whilst on the other hand retarding the development of unsubsidised plantations. This, of course, creates a vicious circle where it is argued that there are not enough plantation sawlogs and pulpwood to allow us to stop logging and woodchipping in native forests. I want to deal with these arguments in more detail in a few moments.

PARA.TAB: I represent the seat of Makin in South Australia. In our state, the Dunstan Labor government ended logging of native forests in the 1970s. We are the only state to have done so. We are also the only state where a viable timber industry relies wholly on plantations for its survival. As with other states, we have timber towns, timber corporations, log trucking companies, about 3,500 timber and forestry workers, paper and pulp mills, sawmills, laminating factories and lumber companies. None of these industries or jobs relies on product from native forests.

South Australia in this instance provides what is obviously a model for what should have happened across Australia over the past 20 years or so. We should have moved to plantation timber chip and pulp production in all states. It is a shame on past and present state governments that the move to plantations did not take place nationally.

Of course, with no logging occurring in native forests in South Australia, my constituents, as Australian citizens, have little time for the continued forestry in native forests in other parts of Australia. During the recent public outcry over woodchip export licences, I did not hear from one constituent supporting the logging industry. On the contrary, the voices expressed that, if 100 per cent of plantation sources was okay in South Australia, they should be, likewise, used interstate.

It is my strongly held view that logging and woodchipping in native forests should be phased out forthwith and replaced with plantation feedstock. I realise that the Australian government cannot enforce such a policy except at the margin through export licences, for example, as we do not have constitutional power and we do not own the native forests. The constitutional power over land management and the ownership of the native forests is regrettably in the hands of the state governments. Because of this situation, I have sympathy for the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, Senator Faulkner, who on the one hand faces demands to stop the rape of the forests but on the other hand has no effective power to halt the destruction.

Fortunately, economic realities and environmental imperatives are starting to impact on the recalcitrant states. The Carr government in New South Wales, newly elected, has made clear its intention to stop logging of native forests. Pressure must now be put on Queensland, Victoria, Tasmania and Western Australia to move quickly to plantation stock and follow the example given by New South Wales.

Needless to say, forestry interests will fight to the death to preserve their access to native forests. They will do so for as long as the cost of logs and chips from these forests is subsidised by state governments which fail to charge market based economic rents. Full and fair market prices for logs would eliminate one of the major disincentives to private production forestry through plantations within Australia.

If there is one thing the Australian government could do to speed up this process to phase out native forestry it would be to reward those states that stop the destruction and to penalise those states which do not. But, of course, one hears bleating from the rapacious loggers and woodchippers. They say that there would not be enough hardwood.

I want to deal in some detail with the question of whether or not we could move quickly to a much greater reliance on softwoods. According to prominent spokespersons for the softwood industry, the answer is a resounding yes, we can rely on softwoods and we can reduce dramatically our reliance on hardwoods. The vast bulk, some 95 per cent, of all hardwood logged in Australian native forests is utilised in the housing and construction industry. Only a small percentage is used in appearance grade applications. Softwood radiata pine can and does effectively substitute for hardwood as a framing material in the housing industry.

Softwood resourced from government, semi-government and private plantations is on-stream. Between 1991 and the year 2000, the availability of softwood plantation sawlog in Australia will likely double from 3.6 million cubic metres to approximately seven million cubic metres. It should be noted that the volume increase in softwood is in the vicinity of the total hardwood log availability within the next five years and will exceed hardwood log availability as we move towards the 21st century. Therefore, the question logically arises as to whether we need to cut indigenous hardwood forests at all.

In pulp and paper production there is no easy substitution of softwood for hardwood as various grades and products require various proportions of softwood and hardwood chips. Currently, however, there is a worldwide surplus of hardwood chip. This could effectively be utilised to fill any shortfall of hardwood chip resource for pulp and paper production until Australia's own hardwood plantation resource comes more fully on-stream. This is recognised by at least one major pulp and paper producer, which is actively encouraging Victorian and South Australian farmers to provide suitable areas for hardwood plantation production.

The logical question, therefore, arises as to what degree the large-scale hardwood woodchip industry is an essential element of the industry. Over the next five years, hardwood log production should diminish substantially, thus also reducing the amount of woodchip available through milling, forest enhancement programs and thinnings. Even if logging were to continue in native forests, in due course hardwood plantations, which already total some 130,000 hectares, will replace any need to log our natural indigenous forests to obtain hardwood sawlogs.

The first areas of hardwood plantation resources are now coming on stream in Western Australia and need to be expanded dramatically to allow accelerated reduction of logging of our native forests. Naturally, fine hardwood furnishings can come only from such timbers. However, many other areas can easily find a substitute. For example, high quality finger jointed pine mouldings can be a substitute for hardwood architraves. Some hardwood woodchip would still be produced in the milling of hardwood timbers for fine furniture, but this could be utilised domestically.

There is a real need at all levels of Australian government and semi-government instrumentalities to facilitate a coordinated investment program for both softwood and hardwood plantations. Without such a culture, the $2.6 billion import of timber and timber products will worsen. Import replacement, however, can succeed only where the product is produced cost effectively and profitably within Australia. Increased resources of both hardwood and softwood are needed to effectively substitute for imports and to explore the potential export market for the product.

Having said that, I readily accept the fact that you cannot move forthwith to stop all logging in native forests without some pain. Whilst I regret that, work needs to be done to ensure that the pain is reduced by the maximum amount. We have seen situations in Queensland, for example, where a logging industry that existed in the wet tropics was phased out and people were moved to other jobs in the tourist industry and elsewhere.

Whilst it is regrettable that this move will have an impact on employment in some parts of the country, it is a fact that plantations also need labour to plant, thin and harvest the timber. In those circumstances, I think that the quicker we move to bite the bullet the better it will be not only for the persons who are working in the timber industry at present but also for the nation economically and, most importantly, for the environment.

As I said, I am well aware of the fact that the logging industry is not going to die without a great fight. In Australia's national interest, we have to do something to change dramatically the present practices. If governments do not move to require the industry to move to plantations, then the industry will continue to use cheaply available native forests and that is not, as I have been pointing out, in anybody's interests.

The arguments against logging and chipping in native forests are, in my view, unassailable. In the national interest, we should stop such logging forthwith. As a nation, we should require the states to charge economic rentals for their forests forthwith. We should encourage plantations, both private and public, as a matter of national priority. We should move to substitute softwood stock for hardwood stock wherever possible. We should stop the desecration of our national forests and we should do it now.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking today to Appropriation Bill (No. 1) I would like to raise a few matters regarding the Department of Veterans' Affairs. No-one could be more supportive of the Australia Remembers commemorative events than I am. The Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Sciacca) should be commended for his enthusiasm for the project. Recently, however, some situations in relation to the administration of care for veterans in the Riverina have been drawn to my attention and are a cause for concern.

PARA.TAB: I was first approached by a number of health carers in the Leeton area who were concerned about a veteran whom we shall call `Bill C'. He had been brought to their attention and required home nursing care. Mr C enlisted at Wagga Wagga in July 1940 when he was 17. Bill embarked from Sydney on the Queen Mary on 2 February 1941 and landed on Singapore Island on 18 February 1941. He spent time in Malaya, was captured in February 1942 and was interned in the notorious Changi prison. Bill spent most of his internment in Japan at Osaka and Kawasaka subcamp, where he was forced to work in coal mines and shipbuilding.

While a prisoner, Bill was repeatedly bashed with rifle butts about the head and shoulders, which later in his life created symptoms of epilepsy. He had all his fingers and toes broken and was lined up in front of a firing squad and threatened with execution. He also had to eat rats in order to avoid starvation.

Entries in his diary state `everyone received a letter today except Bill', `food—main thought—forever hungry', `3 small bowls of rice a day in the Double Diamond mine', `they hit us with anything and we don't know who will be next', and `God's help and the old Aussie spirit won through'. Bill would have been shot if the Japanese had discovered this diary.

Bill C was liberated in August 1945. In his diary he describes the day as `the best day of my life'. When he was liberated, Bill, a man who stood six feet two inches, weighed less than six stone. He was fed and cared for by the Americans before being sent home. Unfortunately, Bill's story is not unique, as many Australians suffered similar punishment at the hands of the Japanese and many did not return. On his return home, Bill was in very poor health. He suffered from depression, epilepsy, Singapore ear, tropical ulcers, dysentery, malaria, beri beri fever, migraines and tinea. Upon his return to Australia, Bill underwent shock treatment.

Eventually he went to live in Leeton with his mother and sister. Bill later married and had four children. His marriage failed due to ongoing problems that were a direct result of his war experiences. For many years, Bill and his sister Jean battled on with little help, and finally he was bedridden and could breathe only with the aid of oxygen. Bill paid for his oxygen for years, and only months before he died he purchased his own hospital bed which enabled him to remain in a sitting position to ease his laboured breathing. It was during only the last seven months of his life that Bill received any nursing help from the Department of Veterans' Affairs.

Bill's sister Jean looked after him 24 hours a day and spent many nights attending his needs with an oxygen nebuliser and trying to alleviate his anxiety. On 7 March I received a message in my office that Bill, then aged 72, was having respiratory problems along with a number of other debilitating complaints. The message was that Bill could not do anything for himself and that a private nursing agency was providing nurses twice a day. The report said that, because his sister who was caring for him was elderly, he should have been in a nursing home.

Unfortunately, prior to this Bill had been hospitalised on many occasions but when in hospital he became depressed and frightened—not because of a lack of care by the hospital staff but because of his traumatic wartime experiences. The report said the nursing hours being provided were certainly not excessive and that it would be well worth while having nurses make a check visit in the middle of the day as well as in the night. This would particularly be the case when Bill's carer was ill.

After a number of inquiries I found that many requests had been made to the Department of Veterans' Affairs for extra nursing assistance for Bill, but the department had refused that additional care and suggested Home Care be approached. Anyone who lives in rural New South Wales knows that Home Care is stretched to the limit and in Bill's case he required the type of assistance that Home Care does not have a mandate to provide.

Sadly, the refusal of the department came after suggestions over a long period by health workers, doctors and nurses that extra nursing care was required. A decision was made against that advice but assessors from the Department of Veterans' Affairs had not even seen the veteran—certainly not in recent times. Unfortunately, before I could do anything to try to assist Mr C, he passed away on 7 March 1995. Because I was upset with this treatment of a veteran and did not wish the same thing to happen to others, I wrote to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs on 15 March 1995 asking him to inquire into Mr C's case.

On 10 May I received a reply from the minister that, contrary to my information, the department had made arrangements for the provision of in-home respite services and that Mr C had passed away before the arrangements could be implemented. The minister said that he regretted the department was not made aware of the situation earlier. In fact, when assistance was sought from the Department of Veterans' Affairs in December 1994, the carers were dismayed to receive the response, in refusing the request, `Yes, but you told us he was dying in September.'

The sad thing about this matter is that the minister has been misinformed, as the Department of Veterans' Affairs was made aware of Bill's situation at least three months before he passed away. It appears that one of the reasons for this inhumane debacle is a confrontation between sections of the Department of Veterans' Affairs and private nursing services that provide most of the nursing care for veterans in their homes in rural New South Wales—and no doubt this occurs in other parts of Australia. If these services, which arguably provide a more economical service than can be provided by government agencies, are not supported and encouraged, then I fear for the future welfare of veterans who have no alternative than to remain at home. For some who wish to remain in their homes to die, this should be their prerogative.

I believe the feud between sections of the department and private nursing services is so intense that the department has had at least one nursing service under investigation for some time, with no fault yet having been found, except that it wants to get on with the job of caring for the sick and ailing veterans. In case people think I have a vested interest in the nursing services, if the government does not wish to have these services, it must quickly find another way of providing care for our ailing veterans.

On top of this, I believe there is a move by sections of the Department of Veterans' Affairs to transfer its home nursing responsibilities to the Home Care organisation that is not geared to provide the nursing care that veterans require, even if it had the resources to spend time with the veterans. As every member knows, the Home Care organisation, as I said before, is stretched to the limit.
Former Prime Minister Ben Chifley in 1946 told this House:

SPEECH.PARA: Upon this national parliament rests the responsibility that the right thing shall be done by those who serve their country at the time of war.

If there is any possibility that this is not occurring, whether it be bureaucratic bungling or trying to save money or whatever, it is just not on. We owe these people too much for any procrastination when it comes to their care. If ever there is any doubt as to the validity of the veteran's case for assistance, the judgment must come down in favour of the veteran—this means any Australian veteran.

PARA.TAB: But how much more should this apply to those unfortunate souls who were prisoners of the Japanese. To think that a bureaucrat or anyone else could hold up their aid is unthinkable. If there is a problem, it must be fixed and fixed quickly. If we feel we cannot afford this assistance to veterans, we may have to rethink the $8 million being spent on the Australia Remembers commemorations. I am a great supporter of those commemorations, but I think aid to the veterans must come first.

We will no doubt hear a lot from the opposition over the next few months, and most of it will probably be in the same vein as what we have heard from it so far. There really is no pleasing some people. In a period of strong economic growth the government has brought down a responsible surplus that has won over the markets, and still the opposition is not satisfied. I have said it before in this place and I will say it again: Australia is in one of the most prolonged periods of strong growth in our history, and we have low inflation too. These are very important elements in our society.

I would like to use the opportunity presented by this debate today to highlight some of the positives in the budget and to point out a few truths about the shallow tactics employed by the opposition lately. The opposition has continually obstructed the government at every turn and has criticised it for allegedly not governing properly. Now we have brought down a responsible budget and that is still not good enough for those opposite.

The primary purpose of this budget is to boost national savings and jobs—jobs for the long-term unemployed, for disadvantaged people and for youth. In short, it is to boost jobs for people who have been most severely affected. Through the twin strategies of the Working Nation document and the budget, the government will effect real reform in the areas of labour market assistance and job creation. At the same time, it will pursue responsible economic growth.

Over the last 10 years, the government has reformed the way the economy works by turning it into a more efficient and competitive economy enabling Australia to make its way in the world. That has been a very important aspect of this budget. It has also been a very important aspect over the last 12 years for the Labor government. Now we are faced with a period of stable growth and low inflation—the goal of Australian governments for the last 30 years. We face a bright future of prosperity in this nation. However, the task before the government now is to ensure that the recovery will benefit everyone, including the most disadvantaged job seekers in our society.

The 1995-96 budget seeks to consolidate and improve our economic performance whilst ensuring that all Australians share in the benefits of that progress. This budget is unique as it represents a new benchmark in budget reporting and government accountability. But, most of all, this budget is unique because it operates in conjunction with the Working Nation white paper on employment and growth. This scheme is without doubt one of the most ambitious, comprehensive and well thought out plans to reduce unemployment that this nation has ever seen. It is certainly having a very strong effect in my own electorate. I congratulate all those people who are actively supporting and taking advantage of the initiatives in the Working Nation statement. The strategies outlined in Working Nation will help the unemployed take their place in contemporary Australian society with dignity and independence.

My electorate of Oxley has areas of significantly high unemployment but it also has a number of competent and vigorous development groups and community organisations that enjoy good relations with local industry. I have devoted a great deal of my time to finding ways of promoting employment growth in my electorate as well as nationally, as is the case with my colleagues on this side of the House. That is the positive sort of thing that members of this place need to be doing to ensure that Australians who are not as well off as we are do benefit from initiatives like Working Nation.

In May last year, I established a local employment advisory group to assist in ways which could help the government's employment task force to reflect the priorities of my own electorate. That task force was jointly chaired by my colleagues the honourable member for Lilley (Mr Swan) and the honourable member for Port Adelaide (Mr Sawford), who were involved in a caucus committee in the parliament as well. The members of my local advisory group met with local employers, training providers, officers of the Department of Employment, Education and Training and members of the trade union movement, to gauge the effectiveness of current government employment policies in my local region.

This government's No. 1 priority remains assisting those unemployed back into the work force. That is working at the moment. Along with my colleagues on this side of the House, I have a very strong commitment to that initiative. My electorate, with its well established training network, including the Regional Development Corporation, three skillshare programs, group training schemes and private trainers, is well placed to pick up on the initiatives outlined in the budget and to pick up on the continuing initiatives outlined in the Working Nation statement. I will certainly be encouraging them to pick up on the initiatives in the budget.

I call on all Australians to look at the positive things in this budget rather than listen to the opposition's negative point of view. When we look at the budget we ought to look at the whole budget, the whole picture, and see what it really means for all Australians. The problem is that those opposite look at its bits and pieces and hone in on the negatives instead of looking at the big picture, which is absolutely important. We must look at the big picture to ensure that we benefit from all the initiatives that will come forward from this budget. Opposition members know that, but they will not admit it. It is not unusual for those opposite to be floundering around wondering what they are going to do next. As the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Mr Elliott) mentioned, the opposition is policy free and has no direction.

I am particularly pleased to say that the period of jobless growth that marked the first year and three-quarters of the recovery is now behind us. More than 230,000 extra jobs have been created since April last year and the unemployment rate has fallen from 11 per cent to 10.3 per cent, and it will go lower with the plans outlined in the budget and Working Nation. Real GDP is forecast to grow by 4.5 per cent and another quarter of a million jobs are expected to be created. That is good news for the unemployed. That will result in an unemployment rate by the middle of next year that is well below the double digit figures I mentioned before. Some of the unemployment figures that have come out recently show that downward trend, which is a very positive step for us.

It is true that the latest business investment figures did not show the immediate increase, but the government's forecast of 4.5 per cent growth is not overly optimistic, contrary to what was stated by the opposition last week. With the added incentive of the favourable tax regimes for business over coming years, the benefits of increased profit margins and productivity will show up in higher investment levels.

Among these added incentives, the budget includes the provision of the accelerated depreciation allowance, the development allowance for large projects, the general investment allowance, a 150 per cent write-off for research and development expenditure and the reduction of company tax to an internationally competitive rate of 33 per cent. All these incentives will reduce the government's tax revenue by nearly $3 billion for 1994-95, resulting in a substantial benefit for business. This further reduction in the tax rate will allow business to expand and take on more workers, as will the generous incentives offered under the employment and training initiatives in Working Nation.

While labour market programs play an important role in assisting the unemployed to get back to work, it will only be through private sector investment that sustained employment growth of the level required to substantially reduce the unemployment rate will actually occur. The increase in the company tax rate to 36 per cent has been the cause of some comment, but the important thing to note is that the government took this step at a time of high growth and profitability and it will provide further incentives for business to invest and will provide further job opportunities. With inflation at its lowest level for 30 years and interest rates at their lowest level for 20 years, these measures will be of great assistance to business. I encourage business to take full advantage of them and to give the people who desperately need jobs a chance of employment.

TALK.START.PARA: —We want to hear more from you.

—You will hear more from me. I could talk all day about this budget. I am just starting to warm up and the Speaker has arrived so I know he will be interested in some of things I am going to say because his electorate will benefit from a lot of the government's initiatives as will people in the electorate of the member for Ryan (Mr Moore). The member for Ryan does not seem to realise that his electorate will benefit like any of our electorates will from this budget. PARA.TAB: As I said before, the most important of the government's aims is to reduce unemployment, and that is an important thing for us all. Members need not be reminded of the urgency with which we must address this issue. It is something that has always received priority from members on this side of the House. I am pleased and proud to say that Working Nation has confirmed our faith and the determination of this government to devote all its efforts to getting Australians back to work. As a nation, we have to provide real hope to the unemployed, and Working Nation does that. In reforming the labour market assistance programs it will focus on an area where problems have been perceived in the past and will make the delivery of labour market assistance much more effective and more relevant. Indeed, the reforms of labour market assistance in Working Nation could justifiably be called a revolution in training methods.

The most important thing in this budget is that funding for Working Nation has not been reduced. This funding will continue to support an innovative project in my electorate called a transition centre. For the benefit of honourable members who may be unfamiliar with the concept of a transition centre, I will enlighten them a little. It was a successful pilot in my electorate. The aim of a transition centre is to provide long-term employment by creating new industries in its own area. The aims of the concept are to identify potentially commercially viable products for process developments as import replacements; identify firms willing to produce and market proven products; undertake product and process development work using teams of long-term unemployed; and, finally, to transfer proven, successful products to industry, providing full-time employment for the former long-term unemployed. So I certainly welcome the visit of the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Crean) and his announcement of those initiatives last year.

It is this emphasis on long-term planning and creating new opportunities that distinguishes the transition centre from former labour market programs which, despite the undoubted best intentions and efforts of those running them, often focused on short-term employment goals. Unlike these schemes, the transition centre aims to create sustainable employment for the long-term unemployed in the Ipswich region by establishing industries that will focus on import replacement. Following the successful completion of the pilot project, it is estimated that a fully operational centre will assist up to 200 long-term unemployed people every year. That is a great credit to the people who have been running that for some time now. I have seen cases myself where long-term unemployed people, not only from my own electorate but also from other electorates, have benefited through this program, and people who thought they were going to be unemployed forever have been able to come through with jobs.

The exciting aspect of this project is how it will integrate the entire local community. That is very important. With private sector support and patronage, local employment opportunities and markets can be identified and explored as potential income generating options for the region. The centre will provide a facility to develop and manufacture goods and provide training and work experience for the long-term unemployed. The goods and services produced at the centre will be aimed at replacing imports, rather than competing with Australian producers. In fact, there are export opportunities there that people have taken up.

The significance of this project cannot be overstated. It has huge potential and will hopefully represent a change in Ipswich's place in the national scheme of things. The region will be well placed to be at the leading edge of the employment and training initiatives outlined in the white paper. If this project proves to be successful, as I am sure it will, the concept will be transferred to other areas around Australia. You will be able to say that you heard it from Ipswich first because a lot of good things have come out of Ipswich, as you well know, Mr Speaker, when you see what happens on the football field.

Radically transforming the way employment measures are implemented will be a very important focus from this transition centre. Import replacement on a sustainable basis will create much needed new jobs because many products formerly manufactured in Australia have been replaced by imports with the strongest period of this trend being the 1970s and 1980s. We now have some good news in that area.

In addition to the transition centre funding, the Minister for Employment, Education and Training also announced that the project will receive an additional $164,000 under the jobskills program to provide training and work experience support to help the long-term unemployed make the transition into the work force. I would like to continue in this vain, concentrating on the employment and training initiatives in Working Nation, which will be funded by the 1994-95 budget.

Many of the initiatives in the budget and in the Working Nation statement that covers employment are very important aspects of this budget and the continuation of the Working Nation statement. I believe that many of these initiatives are things that we, as members of parliament, should pick up and focus on in our own electorates to ensure that the benefits from the government's initiatives on employment really reach the heart of the needs of Australians out there in the workplace, particularly addressing the needs of our long-term unemployed. I think we have a tremendous record in that respect. I realise that time is going to beat me, so I will pause there.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Attorney-General. I refer the Attorney-General to the recent Justice Statement, which was so well received in the Australian community. Can the Attorney-General inform the House how the reforms outlined in that statement will benefit Australian families?

—I thank the honourable member for Leichhardt for his very perceptive comments on the reception of the Justice Statement around Australia. The statement has three major themes running through it, as the honourable member may be aware. The first is that prevention is better than cure—we should direct our energies towards ensuring that problems do not become legal problems and that people do not need to have recourse to formal legal processes. The second is that there needs to be a range of structural changes in a number of the major components of the legal system—namely, the legal profession itself and some of the major components of that system, such as the way in which legal aid commissions operate in this country. The third deals with access to particular programs and the expansion of a range of programs.

PARA.TAB: All three of those themes have an immediate and important impact on the way in which Australian families have recourse to legal services in this country, particularly in terms of the focus on making sure support services are in place so that families do not need to have recourse to formal legal processes. To this end, given that the Commonwealth's major jurisdiction obviously is in the area of family law, the statement unashamedly addresses that area.

There are major additions to the $22 million a year which is provided to the 90-odd community based family support organisations in this country. These organisations currently assist something like 160,000 people annually and they will be able to expand those services considerably. Around $12.3 million will be spent over the four years on new services. This will mean a doubling of premarriage education services, and that something like 45,000 Australians will have the benefit of that education.

A range of new funding initiatives will help services attune their programs to the needs of Australians from non-English speaking backgrounds. There will be a massive increase in family skill training. There will also be a major increase in adolescent and mediation therapy centres, particularly in rural and regional Australia.

Unfortunately, obviously some relationships and marriages will fail. To that extent, the government has greatly supported the use of mediation in Family Court proceedings where that service is available. Particularly where there are no examples of domestic violence, services such as mediation have proven to be very effective. Something like $10 million over four years has been allocated to the expansion of both the court and the community sectors and to an increased counselling provision within the Family Court. That will see the Family Court being able to establish new counselling registries in Coffs Harbour, Mackay and Geelong. It will be able to upgrade—I know this is of interest to the member for Leichhardt—the existing registry in Cairns to a full counselling registry. In addition, there is now the development throughout Australia of pilot programs for handover and visiting centres to deal with those access matters where there is a difficulty between the parents.

All in all these services will greatly expand the range of programs available to Australian families. Importantly, they will help families stay together in the first instance. On those occasions where there are breakdowns of relationships, breakdowns of marriage, the services will be in place to make sure that that experience is as less traumatic as possible.

Is it not a fact that your recent budget, which was supposed to be an election manifesto but which was in fact just a four-day flop, has been condemned by industry groups as a further attack on jobs? I ask the Treasurer: why have you betrayed those battlers who have traditionally supported the Australian Labor Party?

—This budget is based on an estimated increase in employment of a further three per cent in 1995-96, an additional 240,000 jobs on top of the over 600,000 jobs that have already been created since the last election. In relation to employment, this is a government which has been phenomenally successful not only in terms of the target that we set ourselves of 500,000 jobs in the course of this government but also in terms of what is happening in Australia compared with other countries.

PARA.TAB: I have just been to a meeting of OECD countries in Paris, and the major concern was employment. European countries in general are desperate to create jobs. Australia, along with the United States, stands out like a beacon in terms of being able to increase employment. The difference between us and the United States is that we have increased employment without bringing about the devastating side effects which were referred to yesterday by the Prime Minister in reading from a speech given at the OECD by the US Secretary of Labour, Mr Reich. Mr Reich pointed out the tremendous downside of the American labour market in terms of falling real wages and the vast number of working poor.

The safety nets that we have built in in this country have ensured that we do not have that kind of outcome—those safety nets being that we have maintained awards; we have maintained safety net wage increases, so that those who are not able to get an enterprise bargain increase are able to get wage increases anyway so there is at least some sharing in the national increase in productivity and prosperity.

TALK.START.PARA: —You borrowed $26 million bucks!
—Order! I warn the member for O'Connor early today.

—Of course we have, through the enterprise bargaining process, put in safeguards to ensure that workers cannot be exploited and there is no net disadvantage to them. All of these sorts of factors indicate that Australia has been very concerned not only to create jobs at a record rate but also to ensure that it is done on a basis which is equitable; that the people get jobs which pay decent wages and that there is no exploitation.

PARA.TAB: All that stands in marked contrast, I might say, to what the opposition would have. The opposition's policy, as articulated by the previous spokesman on industrial relations, now Leader of the Opposition, was to hack away at those safety nets, to ensure that there would be a minimum array of safeguards. In that respect, the opposition wants to go down the American path, to go towards that kind of a labour market where there is exploitation, where you do have lots of working poor. Of course, in doing that the opposition would greatly exacerbate wage differentials and the inequality of the distribution of income.

This nation has everything to be proud about in terms of its employment performance over the last few years. It has created jobs at a very rapid rate—a rate that is as fast as that of any other country in the Western world—and it has done so on a basis of equity for the people in the work force. The government's Working Nation program, which we adopted last year, is out there as an example to the rest of the world of what you can do to assist the disadvantaged in the labour market. The fall of over 100,000 in the number of long-term unemployed bears testimony to the importance of that Working Nation package—which, of course, is enhanced in this year's budget with the amount to be spent under Working Nation greater in 1995-96 than in 1994-95.

At the OECD—and I will conclude on this point—one of the great concerns that was expressed not only by Mr Reich but also on the part of many people speaking for European countries, and by the Secretary-General of the OECD speaking on behalf of that organisation, was the great concern about `exclusion'—that is, the concern that larger and larger numbers of people in Western societies are not sharing in the increased prosperity, so that, as productivity improves and GDP increases per head, there is a growing number of persons who are excluded from benefiting from that, either through unemployment or through exploitation in the labour market.

We are not experiencing either of those. Certainly we have unemployment, and that unemployment is being brought down rapidly, thank goodness. That, of course, is something which we are doing faster than just about any other country in the Western world. As we continue to bring that rate down, we will do so on the basis of fairness and equity in the labour market—not on the basis of exploitation of the labour force in the way that the opposition would be happy to embrace.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Treasurer and also relates to the retail sales data released earlier today. Can the Treasurer inform the House what implications these figures have for Australia's economic outlook?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the case that there has been, on the face of it, a large increase in the retail trade figures for April; that is, an increase of 4.6 per cent—not 4.1 per cent, as mentioned by the Leader of the Opposition earlier. That 4.6 per cent increase, of course, is well above market expectations. But I think it is important to take note of what the statistician had to say in his release. He says:

ANSWER.PARA: Users should note that this could, in part, be due to greater retail activity across Australia surrounding Easter and Anzac Day. The ABS requires more information to determine if this increased activity represents a shift in regular trading patterns which would affect seasonal adjustment factors . . .

In other words, he is saying that this large increase may be explained by this problem with the seasonal adjustment factor.If I might just explain that a little further, there are two factors basically at work. Firstly, the timing of Easter changes from year to year, and the seasonal adjustment factors only react with a lag. In 1994 Easter was very early in April, and most of the effect on retail sales fell in March; whereas this year Easter was in the middle of April, and the effect on retail sales would be recorded in April. It is likely that the seasonal adjustment factors have not adequately compensated for this change in the timing of Easter.

PARA.TAB: Secondly, there is an increasing trend for extended retail trading hours, including public holidays. At present, the seasonal adjustment factors include an allowance for the number of trading days in the month. To the extent that retailers trade on public holidays and that may not adequately be reflected in the adjustment for the number of trading days, then the seasonally adjusted estimate for retail sales is likely to overstate the underlying situation. That appears to be the case in April.

As the statistician notes, further information on these developments needs to be obtained before any conclusive judgment can be made about the adequacy of the current seasonal adjustment factors. In the meantime, it would seem more sensible to have regard to the trend figures for retail sales. What they show is an increase of 0.5 per cent in April.

In the circumstances of doubt about the seasonal adjustment factors being adequately taken into account, it would seem more appropriate to have regard to the trend number. That would also be more consistent with the general understanding most people have about the economy, which is that the degree of activity is slowing but still continuing at a reasonable pace and certainly not zooming away, as the April seasonally adjusted figures would lead one to believe if one took them at face value.

The opposition wants to thrash around in a state of great agitation about the fact that we are devaluing against the yen. If is a case for such agitation, ministers for finance all around the world would be cutting their throats because they are all in the same position.

PARA.TAB: This country is doing better than just about any other country in terms of maintaining strong, low-inflation growth. That outcome is one which the Australian people should appreciate as being one which is serving them tremendously well. They are living in a country which has growth continuing at a rate which is at the top level of rates of growth amongst Western developed countries, with strong growth of employment, falling unemployment and inflation levels which, after four years of strong growth, are still around the three per cent mark.

That kind of outcome was just inconceivable when the now Leader of the Opposition was Treasurer of this country. When he was there, we had double digit unemployment and double digit inflation. It was an amazing achievement, actually, to be able to have double digit unemployment and double digit inflation both at once. It was under him also that we first had the current account deficit go over the 5 1/2 per cent of GDP mark.

The opposition clearly has nothing to point out to this government in terms of telling us how to manage the economy. The economy of this country is being run in a way which is the envy of most other countries around the western world. The current account issue is one which is being addressed as fulsomely as possible through the budget and through the proposal in relation to superannuation.The fact is that this budget directly takes on the current account issue and says that we are going to improve national savings by reducing public sector dissavings through an immediate move to budget surplus and higher budget surpluses in the years thereafter, meaning a significant boost to savings in this year 1995-96 and years to come. Also, there will be a move to increased private savings by way of superannuation initiatives, which are dramatic and extraordinary in terms of their scope. They will eventually boost private savings in this country by some four per cent of GDP.

That, along with the budget proposals, is about as comprehensive a way as one could possibly imagine for a government to tackle a current account problem. It is saying that what this country needs to do is boost its own savings performance, and to do that considerably and in a way which means we will be relying less on the savings of foreigners and therefore there will be less reliance on capital inflow and less current account problem in the future. That is an appropriate response. It is a very comprehensive, detailed response to the only issue of concern about the Australian economy at the moment. The issue is being very directly and comprehensively addressed in this year's budget.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Consumer Affairs, who will be aware that the Commonwealth is bound by the Trade Practices Act. Part V of the act prohibits misleading and deceptive conduct. Will the minister show concern for innocent consumers and investors by asking the Trade Practices Commission to investigate the conduct of the Treasurer, who, in September 1993, misled them in a prospectus saying `The government has no intentions whatever of further reducing its shareholding in the Commonwealth Bank', when he now proposes to sell every last share in the bank that the Commonwealth owns.
—I assume that is a frivolous question. The answer is that the act certainly does not apply in this case, as you well know.

—My question is addressed to the Treasurer. Is the Treasurer aware of calls to freeze the superannuation guarantee arrangements? Can the Treasurer advise the House of the impact of these arrangements on retirement incomes and national savings?

—I thank the member for Dunkley for his question. I am aware of calls by the opposition to freeze the superannuation guarantee at existing levels in the unlikely event that it wins the next election. That was said, of course, at the last election to be the opposition's policy. It was reaffirmed by the Leader of the Opposition in his budget reply—or should I say rant—to this House last sitting week. What he said then was that on a change of government `any existing retirement benefits will be preserved'; that is, they will be frozen at the next election.
—No, no; that's not what it means.

—If it does not mean that, perhaps you had better explain what it does mean. If one reads the words `any existing retirement benefits will be preserved', one would assume that it means—in the event of no further explanation from the opposition—that it is a rerun of the coalition's promise at the last election, to freeze the SGC at the level at which it found it.

PARA.TAB: That would mean that, at the next election, the requirement under the SG would be six per cent for larger employers and five per cent for smaller employers. To freeze superannuation contributions at this level would seriously detract from the improvements in retirement benefits that Australian workers stand to gain from the superannuation guarantee employer contributions and, of course, from the policy initiatives that I announced in Saving for our future; that is, a member contribution and a matching government contribution. A couple in their mid-30s will receive a retirement benefit 75 per cent higher than the age pension as a result of the initiatives announced on budget night.

If the coalition were to freeze the super guarantee contribution, employees on average weekly earnings, instead of having the super guarantee and the benefits that we announced on budget night, would lose about 62 per cent of their potential superannuation benefits if they work for large employers, and about 69 per cent of their final benefits if they work for small employers. To freeze the SGC at the 1996 levels would also permanently discriminate against the employees of small employers, who would receive superannuation benefits up to 17 per cent smaller than the employees of large employers. The estimated effect on total savings would be very significant. By the year 2000, about $17 billion of national savings measured in today's dollars would be lost. By the year 2003, that would be about $45 billion, and it would be running at an annual loss of about $11 billion.

The opposition's proposals would also have a significant impact on employees. If one looks at the impact on employees into the next century as set out in Savings for our future, under our policy people on average weekly earnings would receive a retirement benefit of $461,900. But with the benefit from the SGC frozen at its 1996 levels and with nothing else in addition through employee contributions and the matching government contribution, that amount would be only $143,000. In other words, they would be $318,500 worse off if they were employed by a small employer, or $288,000 worse off if they were employed by a large employer.

The impact of what the Leader of the Opposition said on budget night is enormous. His glib promise, `I will preserve benefits at that point'—that is, `I will freeze them'—means he is saying to the Australian people that he would dramatically reduce the retirement benefits that they could expect to get from the policies that this government has introduced and announced; that he would markedly reduce national savings to the tune of many billions of dollars per annum; and that he would markedly reduce the retirement incomes of the Australian people in the future.

An opposition member said, `Wait and see what we have to say.' We will wait and see with interest what else the opposition has to say apart from the freezing proposal. It has a spokesman for superannuation and retirement incomes, the member for Bradfield, who is working diligently away on trying to produce a policy. He has been doing it for the last two years. When the member for Bradfield made a speech recently to LIFA, he asked when he finished his speech if there were any questions. There were no questions because they did not regard him as having anything worthy to say.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Justice, and it concerns making Australia a safer place from crime. What role is the Commonwealth playing to encourage a national approach to crime reduction in Australia?

—Over the last decade the federal government has advanced crime and violence prevention and strengthened Commonwealth law enforcement. These initiatives include increased restrictions on the importation of guns and ammunition, and support through the Australian Police Ministers Council for greater adherence to uniform crime laws.

PARA.TAB: I would like particularly to address one issue that was on the agenda at the council's last meeting in Hobart. We moved to greater uniformity on the issue of gun laws. We have led the debate in this area, particularly with the support recently of the Victorian Deputy Premier, Pat McNamara. We have now moved substantially closer to a common approach on the issue of control, licensing and registration of guns in Australia. I think these are very important initiatives which should be welcomed by all members of this House.

We have also addressed key areas of criminal law and forensic procedures. As well as that, we have been restructuring Commonwealth law enforcement arrangements to increase effectiveness, established the Office of Strategic Crime Assessment to increase the capacity of the Commonwealth to assess future crime risks, and provided funds in the Justice Statement, which the Attorney has referred to, to the national missing persons bureau.

We have now taken our involvement in crime reduction a step further. Members would be familiar with the announcement by the Prime Minister in the Justice Statement of the establishment of a Safer Australia program. Safer Australia is significant because, traditionally, anti-crime initiatives have been matters solely for the states. I am therefore particularly pleased to inform the House of a meeting I had with state and territory police ministers in Hobart last week where I outlined that program. It was agreed that the Safer Australia Board, which is to be established, will assume the role of national advisory group to the nation's police ministers as part of a national crime prevention and community safety strategy.

The Commonwealth government has set aside $6 million over the next four years for the Safer Australia program. Safer Australia aims to prevent crime by assisting communities and governments to identify and develop responses to crime so that we can address not only the substance of crime in our communities but also the fear of crime at community level. Safer Australia will provide funds to assist community groups to develop the best crime prevention and community safety projects possible. It will assist in the evaluation of the effectiveness of those projects and the spread of knowledge about and experience of what crime prevention strategies will work to make Australia safer. Those strategies and activities will complement state and territory government policies, integrating them within a national framework.

We will be establishing a Safer Australia Board of a small, high profile group of persons drawn from a variety of professional, community and cultural backgrounds. Of course, that board will be advising the government on the allocation of funds and the promotion of anti-crime strategies. We will be launching Safer Australia at a forum later this year.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Human Services and Health. Is the minister aware of reports concerning a possible national men's health conference? Is it the intention of the government to have such a conference? What progress is being made in planning for this event?

This conference will do something that I think is very important: bring into the spotlight the growing disparity between men's and women's health, an issue I am pleased is receiving much wider and more serious attention not only from the community generally but by the health profession.

PARA.TAB: Not surprisingly, the evidence clearly shows—and I hope members in this House are aware, particularly the male members—that men not only die younger than women but also suffer significantly higher rates of injury and illnesses such as cardiovascular disease and cancers. I regard that as totally unacceptable, and I am sure members of the community do too. Young men, for example, are three times more likely to die from car accidents and four times more likely to commit suicide.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Assistant Treasurer. Does the policy require state governments to privatise water, rail and ports?

This is particularly so in Western Australia. Let me say that in every case they are wrong. There is nothing in the agreement which forces privatisation or contracting out. In fact the Western Australian government is acting on ideology alone and it appears to me that it hates the public sector.

PARA.TAB: The Western Australian government has made a decision to contract out the work currently being performed by water authority workers, but it has stopped this experienced work force from competing for the contracts. What the government has done effectively is taken the experts out of the market. The government is clearly restricting competition and this is not consistent with the competition policy agreement that Richard Court signed last month.

I have talked to employees in these industries and they are happy to face competition. They recognise the benefits of it, but they are bitterly disappointed that after a decade of efficiency improvements they are now being prevented from tendering for contracts in their own industry. Why? Because the Western Australian government claims it is necessary to take these people out of the industry because they do not pay the same taxes as the private sector and they cannot go broke.

I can only wonder whether the Western Australian government read the agreement before it signed it at COAG last month, because the competitive neutrality principles are designed to ensure that competition between the public and the private sectors is fair and takes into account tax treatments, different access to debt and all the other relevant factors. But the water authority workers are not allowed to tender. They are not even allowed to compete. The Western Australian government's ideology apparently has no place for the public sector.

The Western Australian government has also failed to outline any plan for prices oversight. This was the key element of the competition policy reforms, and I understand it takes time to set up one of these pricing bodies if that is the way the Western Australian government is going to go. In the meantime, I am going to offer Mr Court the facilities of the Prices Surveillance Authority. In fact, I will write to him tonight, and we will have the PSA run its ruler over the changes that are being made by the Western Australian government.

I also understand that the Western Australian government has similar plans for Westrail employees—privatising its work and preventing Westrail employees from tendering for the work, once again restricting competition. As the Prime Minister said yesterday, it was a decision based on ideology, designed with a political objective of challenging the union movement in that state. The only thing I can say in conclusion is that the Western Australian government and, clearly, the federal opposition have not been able to take a sensible and consistent approach on these issues because without policies they can only rely on ideology and the irrational hatred of the public sector. We have all heard about the pub with no beer. Here we have the political equivalent—the political party without any policies.

TALK.START.PARA: —We were just reminded a few moments ago by the Assistant Treasurer (Mr Gear), with his rather pathetic answer to a question, of the dispute going on at this very moment in Western Australia between the new stevedoring company Stateships—which is contracting with BAAC to provide stevedoring services to its shipping operations—and the Maritime Union of Australia.

PARA.TAB: The existence of that dispute reminds us—and it is a timely reminder—of one of the great untruths that this government has been getting away with for a long time. It is an untruth based on the fiction that it has successfully micro-economically reformed the Australian waterfront and delivered substantial benefits to the Australian economy and, hence, to the Australian people.

Of course, those of us who have been on this side of the House for some years now have had the opportunity to sit here and watch what this government is really good at; that is, getting away with some enormous untruths. They are things that most people in the rest of the community would call downright deceit, but here we have to call them untruths. The performance of this government in reforming the waterfront is one of those classic areas of deceit—a series of untruths have been used to describe the waterfront reform process.

Today we have again seen the government hard at trying to deliver more untruths about waterfront reform. Yesterday the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) typified in this House one of the great untruths about waterfront reform. This morning on the Elizabeth Jackson program on the local ABC radio station the Minister for Transport and the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Brereton) was hard at work at delivering more untruths about the Australian waterfront.

There are three great untruths that these people like to repeat over and over again. I would like to take members of this House through those three untruths that have been reported by ministers and prime ministers over time. They highlight the way in which this government has deceived the Australian public in relation to micro-economic reform of the Australian waterfront.

The first untruth was made by the Minister for Transport on ABC radio this morning. He said that turnaround times for ships in Australian ports had improved significantly as a result of the government's waterfront reform program. The second great untruth was also engaged in by the minister this morning. He said that productivity levels on the Australian waterfront had increased significantly. The third great untruth, which was practised by the Prime Minister during question time in answer to a question put to him by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) yesterday, is that Australian ports are now as efficient as major European ports.

Those are the three basic untruths that the government likes to repeat frequently when it talks about the Australian waterfront. Let me take those untruths one by one. Let us start with shipping turnaround times. A shipping turnaround time is how long it takes a ship to arrive in port, unload its cargo, load some more cargo and turn around and go out. Today the Minister for Transport said that our turnaround times have improved dramatically.

When waterfront reform commenced in 1989, the average turnaround time for ships visiting Australian ports was 44 hours. The average turnaround time today for a ship entering an Australian port is 53 hours. Pre the great micro-economic reform engaged in by this government, the turnaround time used to be 44 hours. But, post micro-economic reform of the waterfront, the turnaround time is 53 hours. That is an example of the success the government has had. We do not want any more of its success stories, please.

I wish to elaborate on that point. Let me refer to a document produced by Liner Shipping Services. It produced this document earlier this year. Liner Shipping Services is a cooperative, if you like, of a number of shipping companies that operate in and out of Australia. This document highlights the percentage increase in average turnaround times for ships in Australian ports. It compares the end of 1994 with the end of 1993. It goes through the major ports. In Brisbane, turnaround times have increased by 22 per cent; in Sydney, which is one of the major ports of Australia, they have increased by 46 per cent; in Melbourne, they have increased by 43 per cent; and, in Adelaide, they have increased by 55 per cent. The other great untruth that these people love to engage in is that our ports are now considerably more efficient. On ABC radio today, the Minister for Transport said that we have seen a huge increase in efficiency.

Let me use the figures provided by Conaust, which is the largest stevedoring firm in Australia today, to prove that to be a giant untruth. For example, the current container loading rate for Conaust is 14 containers per hour. What was the container loading rate for Conaust prior to waterfront reform in 1989? It was 14.1 containers per hour. Does that equate to a giant increase in efficiency on the Australian waterfront under this government's management? I would say most Australians would say that no, it does not. Yet again, the government has been engaging in giant untruths.

Again, going to the figures provided by Liner Shipping Services and comparing container loading rates from the end of 1993 to the end of 1994, and going through them by port, they show that container loading rates handled in Brisbane ports have decreased by 25 per cent; in Sydney they have decreased by 26 per cent; in Melbourne they have decreased by 18 per cent; and in Adelaide they have decreased by 15 per cent. We spent $430 million undertaking this waterfront reform program—that is, the taxpayers of Australia and importers and exporters have spent $430 million paying for waterfront reform. We obviously have not benefited from it because we have not got improved waterfront performance.

Who did benefit from it? No prizes for guessing: your mates in the trade union movement, the wharfies themselves. Those 4,000-odd who took a redundancy package picked up an extra $100,000 on average for their redundancy. Weren't they great people to sacrifice their jobs for all this money on top of their super, long service, sick leave, and so forth. In fact, many of them have not sacrificed their jobs. They are back at the wharf today working on the B register, which is casual employment. But do not just think that the fellows who retired prematurely got the best part of the deal. The best part of the deal goes to the wharfies who stayed there. Let me just give you an idea of how they have benefited. According to Conaust's own figures which were presented in a speech given at a conference I attended in March of this year in Sydney, a grade 4 wharfie—that is, the average wharfie working on the Australian waterfront—before the completion of the waterfront reform process in 1992, earned on average $34,000. Following the reform process, his wage increased to $45,000. By 1993, his wage was $65,000. By the end of last year, on average, the wage of the average wharfie was $75,000—more than a doubling of the wharfie's wage over the last few years.

What is the average wage for the average Aussie? It is around $30,000. But that is not good enough for us on the waterfront. That is where the benefits of waterfront reform have gone. That is why you see today in Western Australia the Maritime Union of Australia trying to stop somebody breaking up the party. That BAAC can even get off the ground and provide a stevedoring service is proof and evidence of the fact that waterfront reform in Australia has failed. If it had succeeded, BAAC would not have a hope in hell of being able to be in there, competitively tendering against a major, well established business with all the equipment, expertise and customer base to assist it in maintaining its business. BAAC is in there today because waterfront reform in this country has failed.

Yesterday the Prime Minister tried to say that what you see in Western Australia at the moment with BAAC and the state government of Western Australia is coalition policy hard at work, trying to crush the ordinary working man. What utter nonsense! What you see in Western Australia today, apart from living evidence that this government's waterfront reform program has failed, is a government interested in doing the best things by its own people in Western Australia by getting a state owned business the cheapest possible stevedoring services that are available to it.

What government would not, when offered a discount of 20 per cent on its stevedoring services, pick up those services and run with them? Yet there is a government that would not. It is called the federal Commonwealth government—the Labor Party. It is a case of Labor Party people protecting a Labor Party rort. That Labor Party rort, supported yesterday in question time by the Prime Minister and by the Minister for Transport over the last week or two, has cost this country $430 million to date. It is costing this country the loss of competitiveness on our Australian waterfront and, ultimately, it is costing Australian men and women lots and lots of jobs. That is why we need a change: these people protect the rorts of people who have been selfish and greedy and have cost Australians a hell of a lot of jobs over a lot of time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Based on estimates for 1995-96, individual income taxes will have increased by 172.5 per cent at 30 June 1996; company tax by 370 per cent; and indirect taxes by 149.8 per cent. These figures are part of an overall increase in the total revenue to be collected by Labor over its 13 budgets of 178 per cent, excluding the proceeds of assets sales.

PARA.TAB: This government tells us that we live in a low tax country. Yet, with good reason, very few believe it. Tax increases during Labor's 13 long years on the treasury bench will have, after the 1995-96 financial year, outstripped the rate of inflation by an average of 9.3 per cent per annum.

On top of the higher rates of taxation Australians now pay are the ever escalating compliance costs. The compliance costs in this country are the highest in the Western world, with only the possible exception of the United States of America. These compliance costs are only going to be higher still after the increase in the company tax rate to 36c in the dollar. Before the 1993 election, our Prime Minister stated:

As part of a dynamic East-Asian growth region, and with increasing strength in education and training and research and development, Australia is well poised to take advantage of these trends. Our integration into the Asian regional economy, however, means that we need to compare ourselves not just with OECD members but with regional competitors for new manufacturing and large-scale processing facilities.

SPEECH.PARA: The Prime Minister claimed that to aid this integration the government would cut the company tax rate from 39 to 33 per cent. He said that this would encourage firms to invest out of increased retained earnings and improve the competitiveness of Australia's business tax regime compared with our regional neighbours. If the words of the Prime Minister were so true then, why do they not apply now? With the cut in the rate of company tax, the government introduced a new quarterly instalment system. That was part of the trade-off; that was the stick to go with the carrot.

PARA.TAB: Now companies will be hit with a double whammy because they will still have to meet the accelerated payment schedules as well as pay the high rate of tax. The compliance costs will also be higher because companies will have to maintain three franking accounts, reflecting the tax payable at the three different rates. As Mr Geoffrey Lehmann stated in the Australian Financial Review on 21 April 1995, this will make a complete joke of tax simplification. Labor promised tax cuts, lower compliance costs and simpler law. What it delivers is the opposite.

This budget has made significant changes to the superannuation system by making employees contribute towards their own superannuation. The main objective of this change is to bolster national savings. The previous speaker, the honourable member for Oxley (Mr Les Scott), touched on this. I want to add a word of caution. In the FitzGerald report it is made very clear who the main culprit in this decline is when it stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The main contributor to our long term decline in national saving is a decline in public sector saving.

That is governments. This major structural decline FitzGerald traced back to the excesses of the Whitlam years, but it is clear that the government has made a substantial contribution of its own to lower national saving levels in recent times. While the government has been claiming that the deterioration in public sector saving has been cyclical in nature, Dr FitzGerald has made it clear that this slide has been anything but cyclical. He noted:

The main cause of the fall in our saving performance is not cyclical factors (as saving is still low even after recovering) but underlying structural factors—particularly the structural decline in public sector saving.

Dr FitzGerald noted that reversing this structural decline in our national savings will require a major effort on the part of the public sector to restore public sector finances. It is one thing to rabbit on about the contribution near universal superannuation will make to a sadly depleted national saving effort. However, it is quite another matter to be certain that mandatory superannuation will not merely become a substitute for other forms of private saving.

PARA.TAB: We can look to contemporary experience with Medicare for an inkling of what might eventuate if the extravagant claims being made for compulsory superannuation are not toned down and tempered by reality. With Medicare there always was, and is increasingly, a mentality amongst taxpayers either that because the levy is compulsory it is all that individuals need to pay to provide for the cost of their health care or that, because the amount of money conscripted by way of the levy is perceived to be so high, there need be no further contribution to the cost of personal health care. The increase in the levy in the budget period will do nothing to modify such attitudes. Whether increasing numbers will continue to opt out of private health insurance is yet to be seen, although it seems likely under the present regime.

A similar reaction would not be a surprise amongst workers forced to contribute to superannuation funds. There will almost certainly be an element which decides that, because of being in superannuation funds and being credited with three or five per cent or increasing amounts of income, there is no need to set aside further amounts by way of savings to provide for retirement income. As the balances in those accounts is increased to thousands and tens of thousands of dollars over coming years, the unrealisable expectations of individuals will arguably grow commensurately. Any assumption that compulsory superannuation will add to total savings and not be merely a substitute for other existing forms of savings should be heavily discounted. Equally, the expectations of present-day workers that their retirement needs are being adequately catered for should be constantly played down—not the opposite, as is now the case.

The prime objective of compulsory superannuation is clear and will be enhanced by the changes foreshadowed in the budget speech of the Treasurer (Mr Willis). They will further tighten the grip of the union movement on superannuation. These employee contributions are not to be legislated as most would expect. Instead, they will be negotiated on an award basis, thereby enhancing the power of the union movement. Introducing employee contributions in this fashion will restrict coverage to only 74 per cent of the working population, not the 87 per cent currently covered by the superannuation guarantee charge.

Most importantly, this proposal will further restrict the fundamental right of all workers to exercise the freedom to choose their own superannuation funds. This is a basic issue which Australian working people are increasingly demanding action on. Labor cannot deliver, but the coalition is committed to providing choice to all in the provision of superannuation.

Whether it be in the style of retirement savings accounts, traditional forms of superannuation or other products yet to be developed, all Australians should have a choice. Australia needed this budget, and the previous one, to deliver real hope of sustainable economic recovery. Labor has demonstrated once again that it simply cannot grasp the nettle. Tighter fiscal policy and a structural surplus, not this asset sale induced mirage, are required to push down, and keep down, real interest rates and lessen the pressure on the disgraceful balance of payments figures.

Continuous debt accumulation, which our children will have to pay off, is an issue of such importance that it needs to be tackled in a realistic fashion. This budget's fraudulent surplus is achieved by the sale of national assets. The way in which the proceeds from the sale of these assets are to be used, to fund recurrent expenditure and not to repay our debt, is disturbing. This is a flagrant waste of our national assets, which have taken many years to develop and accumulate. The Western Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry put it well this month when it stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The Commonwealth is not irresponsible in planning to sell its assets, but in how it plans to use the money. The states now generally recognise that revenue from asset sales should be used to either retire debt or to purchase replacement assets—either of which maintains their net assets. The Commonwealth's revenue from asset sales is being used entirely to finance current expenditure. This leads to the erosion of the government's—or rather, Australia's—net assets. The budget is not only fiscally irresponsible, it is irresponsible in a wider and more important sense. It does nothing to sustain Australia's economic growth now the cyclical rebound from recession is over.

The Australian people have now done 12 years of hard Labor. The government totally lacks any understanding of what the mainstream of Australian society wants. Whether it be sound economic policy, choice in superannuation or simple old-fashioned honesty, the current government simply can no longer be expected to deliver even if it ever could. It has destroyed all its political capital. It remains in government not out of a sense of duty for what it can do for the Australian people, but only for the naked pursuit of the privileges of office. The electorate will get a chance to condemn it for that in the very near future.
