Members of the opposition come in here and they cannot help themselves—in one way or another they bring in a touch of the old union bash. No opposition speech is quite complete unless somewhere in it the old rhetoric and all the lines are used. Somewhere along the way they will come in with a bit of the old union bash, give the unions a bit of a touch up.

Let me tell you something about unions, having been involved in the trade union movement all my life. I have no argument with people who do want to join a trade union. That is fine. If they do not want to join a trade union, that is fine. What really amuses me is that time and time again, usually about once a month, people will come into my office when they have been ripped off. See how a doctor would get on if he is not a member of the AMA or how a solicitor would get on if he is not a member of the legal profession's body. The trade union movement has always and will continue to play a very important and legitimate role within Australian society, and long may it continue to do that. Having said that, let me congratulate the honourable members who have made their maiden speeches during this debate. I must say that many of their speeches were better than some that have been coming from that side.

The budget speech delivered by the Treasurer (Mr Willis) was, I believe, a responsible document setting the parameters for secure economic growth in the coming years. I was amazed by the opposition's reply or non-reply delivered by the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard). He said absolutely nothing. I actually listened to it very intently, thinking that an election may not be all that far off. The Treasurer came in here and put his budget down.
Mr McArthur interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sure the honourable member for Corangamite would have made a wonderful reply and would have given us details of a policy. But I was surprised, and I must say a little disappointed, when the honourable member for Bennelong came in here and said nothing. PARA.TAB: In an age when more and more enterprises are within the private sector, and in an age when there is much discussion, most of it ill-informed and misrepresented, regarding the trade union movement, there is a very important role for government to ensure the protection of workers' rights and entitlements. At a time when many commentators are talking about the economic impact of superannuation funds and how these funds will be managed and invested, there are some very disturbing incidents of workers losing those superannuation fund entitlements.

In my office I am dealing with several cases now where unscrupulous bosses, although deducting superannuation payments, have masked these contributions in such a way that when their businesses are placed in receivership the workers lose out on their award entitlement or superannuation. If it is good enough for the government to ensure that there are inspectors or other avenues to enforce compliance in the workplace with equal opportunity or sexual harassment legislation then, in my view, surely it is not too much to expect that workers' superannuation entitlements will be safeguarded; in other words, that they will be paid by the employer when they are working and paid out by the employer if a business goes into receivership, as sometimes happens.

Over recent months, three high profile businesses in the Illawarra have been placed into receivership with the workers being denied their award entitlement, such as wages, accrued annual leave, long service leave and superannuation. UFI Pools was a local swimming pool manufacturing company located at Yallah in my electorate. UFI was placed into receivership a couple of months ago. There was some hope among the local unions that a rescue package involving investment from a Chinese source could be gained to keep the company operating as a going concern. Unfortunately, this hope was not sustained. The Chinese investment source pulled out and UFI closed its operation. There has been an occupation of the UFI site by former employees, and an official picket line was established to ensure that no equipment was removed from the site and that former employees would be paid their full award entitlements.

I received a letter from one of my constituents whose husband was employed at UFI Pools. He was concerned about award entitlements. I have taken the concerns of my constituent up with the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Mr Elliott) and the Australian Taxation Office. The constituent claimed—and there is some debate about this—that since October last year the super contributions were in arrears for a substantial time. In her letter my constituent said:

SPEECH.PARA: I rang National Mutual again when my husband's employment with UFI was terminated on 9 February 1995, and again when the company went into liquidation on 22 February 1995. National Mutual would produce a letter of claim to the liquidator and when the assets were sold, funds would be equally distributed among the employees—regardless whether they were outstanding employee's contributions which were taken out of wages or unpaid employer contributions.
My constituent finished her letter to me by saying:

I would urge the Federal Minister responsible for Superannuation to put tighter government controls on superannuation to avoid complications of this kind in the future, and to protect Australia's workers peaceful retirement.

This last sentiment is one with which nobody could disagree. We are dealing with the workers' nest eggs—the money which they will have to retire on. It is the money which they will depend on when they leave the paid work force.

PARA.TAB: Two weeks ago the Clutha coal mine in the Burragorang Valley—which is in the electorate of Macarthur, but many of the workers live in my electorate—closed down, leaving workers high and dry, with close to $18 million in award entitlements suddenly disappearing from the company books. I understand from a report in Monday's Australian Financial Review that the Australian Securities Commission is investigating capital raisings conducted by Clutha Ltd in the month before the company shares were suspended and an administrator appointed. Clutha Ltd was placed into the hands of Coopers and Lybrand's administrator Tony Sherlock in February, after operational difficulties at the mine and after two years of losses.

The great issue here, as I said earlier, is that there is a great deal of uninformed comment on the role of the trade union movement. That is very bad, deficient corporate management. The Clutha mine management mismanaged a coalmine on which a town depends. It has mismanaged the working and social lives of an entire community, adversely affecting the lives of nearly 1,000 families by creating this uncertain future.

The uncertainty of the position of the Clutha miners is made worse by the fact that at the moment they do not have a job. Even worse, somebody has ensured that $18 million of legal award entitlements—such as wages, superannuation, annual leave and long service leave among other things—have been lost or gone missing. Not only do these workers and their families have no livelihood; they have nothing to show for the work they have conducted at the coalmine in the Burragorang Valley over the years they have hauled and mined coal from these pits.

CFMEU officials in the southern district—such as Barney Fittler and Bruce Watson—have shown tremendous leadership by setting up what are termed checkpoints. They are staffed 24 hours a day by the miners who used to work on the other side of the gate until Clutha closed down. The checkpoints ensure that no equipment is removed from the mine. The mining equipment will be slowly recovered from the mine and will hopefully recover a sound price so that these miners and their families can see all of that $18 million they are legally and morally owed. SPEECH.SPEAKER: McArthur Mr F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —This government's 13th budget is a Keating and Labor budget to the core. It is an unmistakably Keating budget with its distinctive cocktail of electoral misrepresentation and dubious bottom line accounting. The budget is unmistakably Labor because it promotes big government solutions to problems already caused by excessive government intervention which can only be solved through individual initiative and personal responsibility.

PARA.TAB: In the last 20 years Australia has slipped from 10th place to 18th place in the world in per capita income. One hundred years ago we were the richest country in the world. Our real interest rates are among the highest in the developed world. High mortgage rates have played a significant role in the Canberra by-election, as members opposite would fully realise.

Interest rate rises are a very potent political factor in this parliament and in the electorate at large. The fundamental approach of the government in this budget is to bring about a perception that interest rates will remain as they are and will not go up. We await the outcome of all those market related activities in relation to interest rate rises and where they might be on election day.

The cause of the slide is not a failure of the market, as sometimes the government would have us believe; it is a failure of government. The symptoms of Australia's current position are high unemployment, high real interest rates, a dismal level of national savings, a record current account deficit—it was $2.1 billion yesterday—and a burgeoning foreign debt. These are all matters which members on this side of the House have referred to in their budget discussions. For every one of these conspicuous symptoms of government failure, the ALP constructs big government plans to rectify the situation. These illusory bureaucratic solutions typically win votes in the short term but see Australia's long-term prospects sinking further into the economic mire.

This time last year we were debating the 1994-95 budget and the Working Nation white paper on employment and growth. At that time there was concern about the unemployment levels of 11 1/2 per cent throughout the rest of Australia. Working Nation was considered to be the answer. Again, it was a major proposition by the government to alleviate a fundamental problem.

The backdrop was an unemployment problem caused by gross government policy failure: an overregulated labour market, an inefficient tax system, costly business regulation and a disastrous high interest rate policy in the late 1980s. But the solution put forward was more government, not less. Personal responsibility and initiative were overlooked in favour of an assortment of new training schemes, wage subsidies, individual case management under the Working Nation program and a new regulatory authority, the ESRA.

Labor's answer was a $6.3 billion spending program on Working Nation, and we have yet to see the results. This year the priority is national savings and superannuation. The inadequacy of national savings is again a failure of government policy: large social spending programs and taxes which penalise thrift and continual public sector overspending. But, once again, Labor's answer is more government, not less. This time the panacea is a massive compulsory system of superannuation which will see government directing workers' earnings to be returned at retirement age. Private savings and personal responsibility take the back seat to government intrusion and compulsion from central authority.

By the year 2000 employees will be contributing a compulsory three per cent of their income to superannuation. By the year 2002 their employers will be contributing nine per cent. But the real cause of our poor saving record is that every facet of government policy acts to discourage saving, and the Commonwealth seems intent on setting the worst possible example.

The federal government shows no fiscal responsibility. High underlying budget deficits are inexcusable in these four years of supposed economic recovery. This year the underlying Commonwealth government deficit is $8.23 billion, as revealed towards the back of the budget papers—not the $716 million surplus that the Treasurer (Mr Willis) would claim that the government had brought down in this parliament.

In a budget which was supposed to address national savings, the government has increased real spending by 1.7 per cent. This is partially offset by a nine per cent revenue increase—the second highest since the Whitlam government—with bracket creep on income tax payers and the next round of former Treasurer Dawkins's wholesale sales tax rises which will take effect on 1 July. The wholesale sales tax was at 10, 20 and 30 per cent. One per cent was added on last year. Now there is the insidious effect of the further one per cent being added on 1 July. So sales tax is being imposed by this government which was so adamantly against the GST of 12 per cent, 22 per cent and 32 per cent after 1 July.

Let us look at the so-called surplus which comes from the pie in the sky $5.3 billion worth of asset sales. This is an increase of 9,000 per cent, and a raft of one-off dividends to help in the balancing of the books. There was an increase of 42 per cent in dividends from Australia Post and Telecom. All of this helped to try to bring about this illusion that the government had balanced the books.

Let us consider the lease-back of Dasfleet. The government is claiming the $400 million sale price as revenue, without including the cost of the lease-back arrangements on the outlays side. Again the government was fixing the books. It sold a capital asset but it did not allow for the cost to government of renting the fleet back again.

This is just like the Labor government in Victoria that leased its railway rolling stock for $400 million but then had to pay the lease payments. Victorians were appalled and amazed that their own railway system had been leased to the Japanese and they were paying a yearly interest rate rental on that particular rolling stock which they thought was their own. That was all to get a cash flow for the cash-strapped Cain-Kirner governments.

As we all know, the asset sales by the Commonwealth do not add to national savings. They simply realise the proceeds of many past years savings that have built up these assets. The special dividends from the government enterprises simply transfer money from those enterprises which are trying to be efficient just to help the Commonwealth government to make ends meet.

As Mr James Cox of the New South Wales Pricing Tribunal estimates, there is an 87 per cent correlation between national savings and government savings. Fiscal responsibility is the single most important factor in boosting overall savings, but an underlying $8.23 billion deficit does not achieve this aim or encourage average Australians to save more.

If we look again at the compulsory superannuation program and compulsory saving, we see that, having failed to cut its own spending or possibly save for the future, the government's answer is to compel individuals to do it on its behalf. Compulsory superannuation is little more than a draconian measure involving the forced removal of income today to be returned at retirement age. It takes away individual responsibility for long-term financial planning and replaces it with government decree.

Compulsory superannuation contributions commence with a phased-in nine per cent employer contribution by the year 2002, the addition of up to three per cent employee contributions and dollar for dollar contributions from the government to match the employee input. That last dollar for dollar is a mechanism by the government just to encourage employees to join the scheme and join this superannuation arrangement which the government is proposing in this budget.

As Terry McCrann pointed out in the Sunday Herald-Sun on 14 May, whereas the One Nation l-a-w tax cuts were to provide $1.8 billion in 1996-97 and over $4 billion each year thereafter, the government's super contributions only cut in in 1998, meaning that by the year 2002 taxpayers will be swindled out of $17 billion. Mr Terry McCrann is regarded as a very reliable economic commentator by both sides of this House.

The tax cuts, which we were supposed to get now, will be received in as many as 45 years time. Those tax cuts—which were to be put into law, as the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) said on many occasions—have now gone and will never be recovered under this government. A real savings strategy would rely on encouraging voluntary savings, rather than the government dictating what people's consumption patterns should be. In the current context, is it any wonder that Australians are not saving enough.

Savings are not attractive to Australians because when governments run large public programs there is no incentive for individuals to save for their old age, illness, injury, looking after their children's education or future unemployment. The government has taken over all these responsibilities, which of course costs a considerable amount of taxpayers' dollars. Section 2, page 46 of the budget papers concede this point. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: Increases in social security arrangements over the past two decades may also have lowered the perceived need of individuals to save for periods of reduced income such as retirement, or the need to provide for education or health services.

Young people aged between 24 and 34 make up 22 per cent of the population, pay 25 per cent of total taxation but receive only 14 per cent of benefits gained from government spending. They need not save for retirement, as long as they observe people over 65 paying five per cent of tax but receiving 28 per cent of government benefits. They observe the example of the older members of our community receiving large government handouts and hope they will be in the same position—so why should they save for their own individual programs? They know that throughout their whole adult life they need not save very much because the government will pick up the cost of their health, the cost of their children's education and, of course, the risk of illness, injury or unemployment.

PARA.TAB: As I have mentioned, the government will pay for education. For tertiary students, the government pays an average of 77 per cent of the cost of a university course. Twenty-three per cent is paid through the HECS program, which means that the student has some responsibility to make some contribution to the cost. In 1995-96 this represents a subsidy of about $8,060 per student each year that the government provides for tertiary education. Meanwhile Austudy and Abstudy provide $1.8 billion, which is purely a tertiary education subsidy.

There is the same trend again for health. Big government has brought about a situation whereby it will help individual Australians get through any of their health problems. The government, through Medicare, picks up 85 per cent of the schedule fee for out-of-hospital services and 75 per cent for in-hospital services. The Medicare funding agreements between the Commonwealth and the states require state governments to offer free public hospital access to all Australian residents. Even high income earners who could be saving to pay a modest fee for public hospital treatment are told not to bother—`It's all right, the state will pay, the government will pay; it will be taken off other taxpayers.' Sixty-nine per cent of Medicare services are bulkbilled—literally, free to consumers from their point of view because they never see the transfer of any money from their pocket. Nobody could pretend that 69 per cent of Australians are incapable of paying even a modest sum for their health care.

Costly drugs are made available on the cheap. Even the wealthiest in our society this year will pay a maximum of $16.20 per prescription for pharmaceuticals up to a limit of $407, and will pay $2.60 thereafter. Let me draw a comparison. If I purchase some fresh fruit or a pair of running shoes to enhance my health, those items are regarded as a private consumption choice. But if I visit the doctor or get a pharmaceutical prescription the government will see fit to pay 80 or 90 per cent of the cost for me. The government's overwhelming generosity in relieving Australians of their need to save would be commendable if it were not all done with other people's money.

Let us see what happens with the tax situation. To arrange for its extravagant social programs, the government discourages saving by heavily taxing middle income Australians. That is self-evident. As the tax scales move up, middle income Australia cops more and more of the tax burden. A recent EPAC study report found that Australia's tax on savings was 27 per cent higher than the OECD average and 50 times higher than the Asian average. So a reputable report is saying that in Australia there is every disincentive for people to save. That occurs because of our high dependence on individual income tax collections, which have risen by 13 per cent in this budget. This again is a massive increase in the middle income tax area.

We also have a strong dependence on company taxation which again has risen by 15 per cent in this budget—it has risen from a mere 33c to 36c in the dollar. Those companies do not have the capacity to vote with their feet as much as do individual voters. Our top marginal rate is 47 per cent for all incomes above $38,000. By contrast, the top marginal rate in New Zealand is 33 per cent, which allows people in that country to have some incentive to work harder and to create some savings. New Zealand income earners have a better after tax position when they can make these choices.

In the closing minutes, let us look at Australia's savings record. In the mid-1970s household savings as a percentage of GDP were over 15 per cent. Under this Labor government, they have moved down to 8 1/2 per cent. The key barometer—the very thing that the Prime Minister and the Treasurer talk about—is developing these savings. Under a Labor government they have been halved. In the 1970s, our savings ratio to GDP was equal to the OECD average. In the 1990s, under the Labor government, we are four percentage points below the OECD average.

The government's inability to cut spending and its policy of discouraging private savings have led to the proposal for a system of forced savings through compulsory superannuation. We now have the situation of overseas borrowings to make up for that and, of course, we have a credit card society—we borrow now and pay back later. That is this government's attitude and that is the way it is approaching this particular problem.

Compulsory superannuation diverts private savings from bank accounts to superannuation funds, shifting money from those savings vehicles, but adding nothing to overall savings. Compulsory superannuation only raises savings levels for low income earners who currently are not saving at all. As the well-known and respected commentator Mr Vince FitzGerald said:

SPEECH.PARA: The key element producing increased saving, over the longer term . . . is that it is compulsory, raising the saving of many that without it would not be saving much in any form.

The low income earners who currently do not save are mostly young people who need to spend all their income on current living expenses. These same people save more as they get older, but they will not save any more than the compulsory amounts in middle age if they feel they have been forced to save too much when younger.

PARA.TAB: There are serious prudential problems emerging, which other members have alluded to. Employee contributions will come through the award system, entrenching the position of unions and industry funds. The proposal which has been floated that maritime workers' funds be used to buy shares in the struggling ANL is a classic example. We also have the Prime Minister telling super funds to look at small and medium businesses for investment. They are usually high risk concerns and should not be related to superannuation investments. Super funds are not there for furthering social aims like stimulating employment, picking winners, or buying up state assets to satisfy ideological fantasies. But the outcome will be one result of the heavy-handed, big government approach to savings that are proposed in the current budget.

Looking at investment, parallel to the savings dilemma is Australia's ageing infrastructure, which can effectively only be replaced through imported capital from overseas—as evidenced by our $27 billion current account deficit occurring last financial year and being proposed for next financial year. In fact, we find that Australia as a nation is importing its capital to make up for the lack of saving in our own home base.

The exemption of capital gains tax on the first home has created a bias in favour of housing investment and luxury housing. The slow pace of micro-economic reform in transport and industrial relations has made property and speculative assets more attractive to investment capital than productive assets made marginally viable by high regulation and costs of inputs.

Professor Helen Hughes in her study Achieving full employment says that many small business people eventually decide to fold up and invest their capital in property, become employees or accept social security. For instance, she estimates that the opening of a coffee shop today would require as many as 20 separate licences and permits, posing a disincentive to invest in such concerns. Is it any wonder that, with such investment disincentives, growth in the overall capital stock has fallen from around six per cent of GDP in the 1960s to 2.5 per cent in 1995?

What I am concerned about, as a member of the opposition and as an Australian citizen, is that this government is providing big solutions of government activity to overcome the major problem of saving in the future, which I concede, and the problem of achieving full employment. The real way to go is to encourage individual Australians to work harder and save their own money for superannuation. (Time expired)

The government also recognises the tourism industry. The budget was very good for the tourism industry. I will go through some of the programs. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vaile Mr M.A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is good to have the opportunity to make a few comments on the 1995 budget in this debate on Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1995-96. I note the previous speaker, the member for Leichhardt (Mr Dodd), touched on it in a few places throughout his speech but not very often. However, that is a prerogative in debates on appropriation bills, I suppose. It is important to note the disquiet throughout Australia with some of the policies that the government has implemented in the budget this year. Quite a few of my constituents in the electorate of Lyne on the mid-north coast of New South Wales are not very happy with the outcomes of the budget that was announced by the Treasurer (Mr Willis) a few weeks ago.

PARA.TAB: The headline surplus of $718 million that has been achieved in this budget is seen by people as a real fudge of figures by the government. On page 7.3 of Budget Paper No. 1 we see that the underlying deficit is $8.2 billion. That is an ABS figure with the asset sales taken out. Although the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has claimed it as a great result that we have turned back into surplus after a number of years of producing deficit budgets, it is not really the case, because asset sales do nothing to boost national savings. When any other business sells a capital asset, a non-current asset, it does not bring it into the balance sheet the way the government has done in this budget.

The real impact of this budget on individuals right across Australia will be in the increase of 8.9 per cent in taxes. The increase in company tax from 33 per cent to 36 per cent is a broken Keating promise announced during the campaign for the 1993 election. The increase in wholesale sales tax on cars from 16 to 21 per cent is another broken promise from the 1993 election. The 12 per cent wholesale sales tax on building materials will, depending on the construction of a home and what goes into it, increase the cost of a $100,000 home by $2,500. If you work that through, say, a 30-year mortgage on a home, it could impact on home buyers by about $6,000. That is not to be sneezed at.

I suppose that, in a cynical way, that manoeuvre by the government could put pressure on the money market and interest rates in that it will certainly lessen the demand for finance in the housing sector. It will drive the housing sector even lower than at the moment. The number of housing approvals has really dropped off. I have got a number of letters from constituents in my electorate that attest to that. The number dropped off prior to the budget; it will certainly drop off more after the budget.

The increase in the Medicare levy from 1.4 to 1.5 per cent was never going to happen, said the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence). An increased tax on bank licences and fees will raise another $822 million over four years. That money will ultimately end up coming out of the pockets of average taxpayers across Australia by way of bank charges and bank fees.

There has been a reduction in outlays—which a lot of people do not read about in the newspaper reports on the budget—such as reform of indexation for Commonwealth own purpose outlays. The Treasurer today in question time was just dropping the Royal Flying Doctor Service into that category. A reduction in the government's own purpose outlays is just a reduction in funding to activities of government. That is where the flying doctor service got its budgetary cuts. An amount of $2 billion dollars is being picked up here.

Interestingly enough, a lot of specific purpose payments to the states are being cut and they are included in that $2 billion which is being saved. I have just been participating in an inquiry being conducted by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts into Commonwealth-state agreements for specific purpose payments. These are a means by which the government can cut outlays in the budget and let a lot of the state governments wear the blame for their programs being cut. It is a good sleight of hand trick that is evident right throughout this 1995-96 budget.

The government is reducing its own running costs by $662 million. There are also cuts to the Working Nation program of $1,216.5 million; that is, $1.2 billion in cuts to the Working Nation program. The previous speaker, the member for Leichhardt, was talking about the Working Nation programs when I came into the chamber. There was not a great deal of fuss made about that $1.2 billion cut. The minister was able to deal with it quite well because so far this year I think the program has been pretty well underspent. That provided a bit of saving in itself. I would imagine that is factored into the $1.2 billion that is being saved in those Working Nation programs.

As I say, the greatest fudge in this budget is the asset sales. Over the last five years or so, this government has factored asset sales worth $8.075 billion into its budgets. It has put in budgets that it is going to sell $8 billion worth of assets, but to date it has achieved only $3.7 billion worth of asset sales. It will be interesting to see what the result of this year's asset sales will be at the end of this next 12 months. Will we ever see the finalisation of the sale of the FAC, of Qantas and of ANL? There seem to be ever decreasing chances of ANL actually getting sold, with the intervention of the unions at this stage. In every year from 1990 onwards, the government has budgeted on $8 billion worth of asset sales, but to date it has achieved only $3.7 billion worth to prop up its spending programs.

This year again factored into the budget is the sale of the holy cow, the Commonwealth Bank of Australia. Will that be achieved? Will some of the queries that have been raised by the opposition about the legitimacy of that decision allow the government to proceed through that program?

A lot of company directors right across Australia are complaining about the integrity of the Treasurer of the government of Australia making a statement on a prospectus and then doubling back on it a few years later. If any company directors did that the Australian Securities Commission—or whatever Commonwealth body oversees those people and their activities—would be down on them like a ton of bricks. It will be interesting to watch the progress of that particular element of asset sales in the budget this year.

It raises that great issue of what is good for the goose should be good for the gander. If we are going to be enforcing some fairly stringent rules about the duties of company directors, why should the Treasurer of Australia not be put in the same category? Why should he not be accountable in exactly the same way? It will be interesting to see the outcome of that asset sale. I found this interesting quote when doing a bit of research for this speech tonight. I realise that this is going back a fair way, but in 1985 the current Prime Minister, then Treasurer, said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Labor Party will fight tooth and nail to keep these public authorities—
that is, Telecom, Australia Post and the Commonwealth Bank—
in the hands of the Commonwealth . . . We are not about wrecking them and selling them.

That was the Prime Minister of Australia. The sale of the Commonwealth Bank was factored into the equation at the eleventh hour, as the documents were being rushed off to the printers, to facilitate bringing that budget down with a surplus of $718 million to try to appease the markets, to try to fudge it and to try to paint a glossy picture in the hope that we see another drop in interest rates. That certainly remains to be seen.

PARA.TAB: Some of the other budget fiddles on top of asset sales include the one-off repayment of Commonwealth advances by Queensland of $994 million; the reconfiguration of Telstra equity injections worth $250 million; capital repayment by Australia Post, the Commonwealth being the only shareholder, of $75 million; increased dividends from government business enterprises, again the Commonwealth is the single shareholder, of $107 million. It will be interesting to see how this is going to be achieved. In a previous inquiry we had an interesting debate on whether the minister responsible for the portfolio that controls policy settings of government business enterprises should also be the shareholder where there is a conflict of interest between those policy settings and the economic imperatives of squeezing more dividend, more profit, out of those government business enterprises.

That brings me to the sale of the entire Dasfleet. It has come to light this week in the budget papers that that particular decision was also rushed in, along with the sale of the Commonwealth Bank. The budget papers say that the government is going to sell Dasfleet for an estimated $400 million and in this next financial year is still going to get the profit from the operation of the fleet. It is going to be interesting to see how it is going to achieve that. It will be one to watch to see what the downstream effects of that will be in the next 12 months. That is another fudged factor in this budget.

I have been in this parliament since the 1993 election. The Prime Minister's favourite saying when attacking the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) and the opposition generally, after spewing out a whole heap of statistics which nobody understands, is: `Mr Speaker, this makes a lie of what the opposition leader has been saying. These statistics today make a lie of what the opposition policies are.' This budget confirms as lies all the Prime Minister's promises at the last election and prior to the last election. In November 1992 the great promise of the Prime Minister was: `What I am promising is not to put up tax.' All we have seen since the 1993 election is massive increases in the taxation burden on the taxpayers of Australia.

During the February 1993 campaign, he said, `They'—the tax cuts—`are not a promise; they are l-a-w.' They have gone by the by, haven't they? They have gone ta-ta and they are not to be seen. They will not be seen by some people—another sleight of hand trick in this you-beaut, fantastic national savings program that does not start until 1997. That shows the importance that has been placed by this government on improving our national savings. That scheme does not start until 1997, after the next election. How cynical is this government? In 1985, as I said, the Prime Minister said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Labor Party will fight tooth and nail to keep these public authorities—
Telecom, Australia Post and the Commonwealth Bank—
in the hands of the Commonwealth . . . We are not about wrecking them and selling them.

The most heartless, most unrealistic, out of touch and arrogant comment of all came from the Prime Minister at the end of budget week when he was taking incoming phone calls on talkback radio in Brisbane. He said about small business:

. . . if they are feeling the pinch, they ought to say "small business is not for me", because it is never going to get any better. This is as good as it ever gets . . . they have got to say "I had better go back to PAYE employment".

That was the Prime Minister of Australia talking about 870,000 Australian small business operators who are the engine room of this country and who provide the majority of the employment in this country. If he had any nous at all, he would realise that they are the 870,000 people who will provide long-term employment in the future in this country if given a chance.

PARA.TAB: The budget forecasts are very interesting. The 1995-96 current account deficit forecast is $27 billion. What is it today? It is $27 billion dollars. So the government is admitting that it is not going to do anything about the current account deficit during the next 12 months. It says four per cent inflation and 8.25 per cent unemployment, which is what it is today. The government is saying that it is not going to do anything about unemployment for the next 12 months. Public debt interest is $9.38 billion.

Yesterday the trade deficit was $2.25 billion. For the eight or ninth month in a row it was in excess of $2 billion. Australians are becoming desensitised to these outrageous figures. We are slipping further and further into the mire and our chance is just thrown away. The government trots out the day or so before the release of such figures—aNiMaLS gets a press release out—and says, `If it is below $2.3 billion, it will be a good figure. It is $2.25 billion. Zippo! What a fantastic figure.' It is disgusting and it is outrageous that the people who are managing this company—Australia—can say that $2.25 billion in trade deficit is a good figure.

Before I close my remarks I will quote a few of the ordinary Australian small business people I was talking about earlier that the Prime Minister continually denigrates in this place. These people are kitchen manufacturers. They have highlighted to me that the government has put this 12 per cent tax on prefab kitchens so it is on not just materials but on about a 39 per cent labour content. David Olsen in Port Macquarie has a substantial business manufacturing kitchens. He wrote to me:

SPEECH.PARA: Mark, some of the points which could be used in your speech tomorrow—
he rang me and said to highlight these—
D Olsen Joinery enquiries for Residential Kitchens for 1995 has fallen by 52.3% as against the same period in 1994.
By taxing the full cost of the Kitchen it will mean that the Purchasers will be paying 12% on the cost of the Labour . . .
Is this going to encourage more employment? Of course, it is not. I continue:
. . . as well as the cost of Material which in our organisation on an average Kitchen the cost of Labour is approximately 39%.

Because of the general slow down of building Australia wide I believe this Tax will further effect the industry and will help to bring on a major recession as it is a recognised fact if building slows down so does the rest of the economy.
The only growth industry seems to be the Commonwealth Public Service, Taxes and people depending on Government Handouts whatever they like to be called.
The Building Approval for the last meeting of the Hastings Municipal Council—
which covers 52,000-odd people—
was seven dwellings. For a so called growth area this is pathetic and a sign that the Labor Government is really stuffing Australia. We've really got the banana republic.

I got an interesting letter from another company which is based a bit south of my electorate. Earp Brothers sells bathroom fittings, tiles and the like. It is in the Newcastle area and is represented by Labor members. I am going to read only the first paragraph of this letter which is addressed to me as the member for Lyne in Taree. It says:
Dear Sir
I am writing to remind you of the implications of your recently introduced G.S.T. of 12% on an additional range of building products.
So I wrote back to him:
Dear Mr Earp
Re: 12% Wholesale Sales Tax on Building Materials
In the opening paragraph of your letter dated 22nd May, 1995, you refer to "your recently introduced GST of 12%".
I would like to point out that I am a member of the Opposition and not the Government and therefore am not responsible for this regressive tax.
You should note that we have made it quite clear in the past that we are going to vote against this measure and all the other tax increases in the 1995 Budget.
Thank you for your letter of concern and I sincerely hope you sent exactly the same letter to your local federal member, who is a member of the government responsible for this tax.
That was from a manufacturer in Newcastle. Lachlan McClure from Nobby Kitchens in Wauchope, another kitchen manufacturer in my electorate, wrote:
Re: The proposed 12% of Sales Tax on joinery in the Federal Budget.

PARA.TAB: We must express our deepest concern for our business's future and that of the kitchen and joinery industry in general, if Labor's proposed 12% sales tax comes into force on 1st July 1995.

We, along with the Housing Industry Association, estimate that this tax would add around $1000 to the cost of a new home or major renovation. We are sure this extra cost will result in reduced sales levels, which will obviously be to our industries' detriment.

SPEECH.PARA: The people in Australia who are desperately trying to get this country going again have once again suffered at the hands of the Labor Party. They have been kicked in the teeth again. All the Prime Minister can say to those 870,000 small business people in Australia—who are the engine room of this country, who are trying to get it going and who are trying to generate employment—is, `Bad luck, boys. This is as good as it gets. Don't whinge. If you want to whinge about it, go and get yourselves a job.' This is exactly the same thing he told university students. I can guarantee the government that these people will remember those comments of the Prime Minister when it comes election time at the end of this year or the beginning of next year and they will vote accordingly.
