SPEECH.SPEAKER: Henzell Ms M.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted to speak in the debate on Appropriation Bill (No. 1). I hope the member for Lyne (Mr Vaile) recovers from obviously a very sore throat. This has been a bold, bright and beautiful budget, no matter what the opposition says. We are going to have the typically feral response from the opposition because it cannot bear a good news story when it hears one. I am going to address a number of my remarks to the superannuation issue. But before I do I remind the House that the Treasurer (Mr Willis), in his speech to the House on budget night, stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The Budget that I deliver tonight has one principal objective: to provide for the continued expansion of the Australian economy.
It will enable the continuation of substantial employment growth, falling unemployment and rising living standards, while reducing pressure on interest rates, inflation and the current account.

At the end of the day what will help families, business and the future of this country is managing those issues. I heard the member for Corangamite (Mr McArthur) say earlier that this budget had the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) stamped all over it, or words to that effect. We should not be surprised by that. This government is about leading from the front with vision. We expect the Prime Minister, together with the Treasurer and all the senior ministers involved in the lengthy deliberations on the budget—it was a very tough process, and the Minister for Social Security (Mr Baldwin), who is at the table, was involved in that process—to lead on this issue, as he does on all others. I will come back to the issue of leadership somewhat later in my speech.

PARA.TAB: I want to specify some of the issues that were certainly of importance in my electorate of Capricornia, which is in Central Queensland and a regional and rural type of electorate. Certainly one of the key issues for me was Queensland's huge win in university places from the budget—4,200 growth places over the next three years. This will mean that Queensland's need to reach the national average will be met by the year 2001, with $2.2 billion for student places in 1996 to 1998, including $129.6 million for new student places. I am delighted to say that the Central Queensland University, which is based in Rockhampton but covers the Central Queensland region, is a beneficiary.

As always, we tend to get people saying, `But it wasn't good enough. We need more. We still should have more.' Certainly that response was present. Some of the local press comments from key spokespersons for various industries interested me. There was the typical expected sort of whingeing, but organisations across the board and people who have given some thought to the matter after having had a chance to assess how the budget will impact on them are now saying it is indeed a very constructive budget.

When we talk about development in the university sector, we are really talking about infrastructure. Apart from providing education, which is vital for our young people at the tertiary level, we are also investing in state-of-the-art technology to provide those resources. We did not introduce up-front fees. Irrespective of what the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Crean) said or what the Prime Minister said, students complained about this.

As should be said many times, when we first came to power in 1983 three out of 10 students finished high school in this country. Now the figure is closer to nine out of 10. In fact, young people between the ages of 15 and 18, and even beyond, will now be in training. We have expanded our TAFE sector enormously. These are real benefits to the families and young people concerned and to the future of this country. We cannot have a clever country if we do not have a trained work force.

The social security measures, which the minister at the table was responsible for, have been warmly welcomed. They include increases in rent assistance for families. A particularly positive aspect is the streamlining of means testing for pensioner shares and managed investments. This has been a matter of considerable controversy during the life of this government. What we did in this matter was consult with people and listen to those consultations, as we have done with many other matters, and bring in a much more streamlined process so that there will be a much more transparent and easy way for aged pensioners to handle investments in shares and they will know exactly what they can expect from the pension.

Our new initiatives for families include a maternity allowance of at least $816, which I believe is a very positive move in dealing with providing benefits to families at a time of great expense—when new babies arrive. This allowance has been available to only a small portion of the work force up to now. I look forward to that measure being expanded when budgets will allow it. This measure will cost us $643 million over the next four years—a not inconsiderable amount of money.

In the area of child care, the government has continued to forge ahead in the provision of work related child care. In this budget we will improve access for 31,000 families. As well, there will be more family day care places and more flexible services piloted in rural and remote areas.

I had to represent the Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley) at a child-care centre seminar at the Gold Coast just after the budget week. Of course, there was a hue and cry once again. It came from a vested interest group that was frightening families and mothers about the supposed loss of child-care rebates for non-working parents. What we have effectively done is stop the rorts that were going on. We extended fee relief on a means tested basis to private child-care centres. Indeed, we have promoted the private child-care sector as the most effective way of making sure that we have work related child care to respond to a need. As I have said before, women are voting with their feet and they are in the work force because they want to be.

What was happening in this area was that non-working parents who were accessing some hours of child care were being told by some centres, `You should register for 50 hours a week because that is as much fee relief as you can get.' In most cases those parents were using far from that amount and then some child-care centres were selling those places again and getting another lot of fee relief.

We are not about to subsidise small business to that extent. What we have done is provide for non-work related child care to be available by fee relief for 12 hours a week. My suggestion to those who are waxing strong on this issue is that they as an industry should talk to us and negotiate. This measure is not coming in for another 12 months, but we are not prepared in a tight fiscal position to subsidise small business in that way.

We are always being asked by the opposition to cut government spending. The opposition spokesperson was there on the day. He put in a pretty expected political performance by saying, `Isn't it shocking the way you people are being treated?' But he forgot to say that that was not one of the issues that the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) said in his response to the budget that he was going to block in the Senate. More of that later.

I move on to other initiatives, particularly in the health area. They include: $18 million over three years to discourage young people from smoking—this is particularly important for young women—$25 million over two years on the national child immunisation program; $42 million over four years for cervical cancer screening programs; $13 million over four years to develop and trial strategies to reduce youth suicide; and $204 million over four years to improve Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander health. We will get all this from a 0.1 per cent rise in the Medicare levy—about 64c a week, I believe.

There is $217 million being given over the next four years for environmental issues, including the coastal management package and the acceleration of the national forest policy arrangements, biodiversity and wetlands programs. We would always like to do more, but once again we have interest groups saying, `You should have done more.' In relation to the drought relief measures, which the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Bob Collins) has just extended today to take in drought areas in New South Wales and Victoria, the public response in my electorate was, `There is nothing in the budget for us; nothing in the budget for rural producers.'

I found that absolutely stunning when, in fact, our drought relief package, delivered in September and December 1994, gave over $500 million to drought assistance through the drought relief payment which has now been picked up by over 10,000 families. With the current extension, which is worth another $40 million or so, there will be a sizeable increase in the number of families—another 4,000 families—who qualify for the exceptional circumstances payments. Apart from the drought relief payment, we have also removed the assets tests for Austudy, and there are additional family payments and health care benefits.

This has been a remarkable response to a very serious problem. In my own electorate, we still have major problems with the drought. In the long-term planning measures, which came through the parliament in December, we have dealt with the farm management bond scheme and investment allowance issues—a whole raft of measures worth millions of dollars for our hard hit rural producers. So it is a bit stunning when rural spokespeople say, `There is nothing in it for us.' The new body in Queensland handling the rural adjustment scheme is encouraging people to reassess their eligibility for rural adjustment because there is money available to help farm families. We want to keep efficient primary producers on the land.

The other important issue in my electorate is the benefits to the coal industry—$9.2 million to promote coal exports and $2.8 million to encourage best practice and productivity initiatives in the industry. All of these have come out of very important consultations with the ACTU. Mr Deputy Speaker, you and I are on the caucus committee dealing with that. I am delighted to say that representatives of the Queensland coal industry came to see me for the first time today to discuss the issue. As I have more coalmines in my electorate than any other member in the federal parliament, I was delighted that two years down the track the coal owners thought it was time they actually spoke to me.

One of the key issues of this budget is the big win for everyone—superannuation. What have we heard from the opposition? We have heard that there is terrible fraud on tax cuts not being delivered. But let me tell the House what the Advertiser said in its response in an article titled `Big gain in 3pc pain':
Under the plan announced in this week's Budget, a worker on average weekly earnings will be more than $100 a week better off in superannuation at retirement.
This is in return for losing out on a $9.20 a week tax cut promised in the Government's 1992 One Nation statement.
But Canberra will match the compulsory super contributions made by low and middle-income earners.
The dollar-for-dollar deal will be means tested and will not apply to high income earners.

SPEECH.PARA: But it will apply to income earners earning up to $46,000 a year. That is a pretty generous and non-regressive tax cut. In fact, while there are undoubtedly people in this country who would like to get their $9 a week now—and I understand that—what we have had to do, and what only a Labor government would do, is take the hard decision on superannuation.

PARA.TAB: The Chifley government wanted to bring in a retirement benefit. But that was all too hard for the Menzies government. It could not plan a retirement incomes policy. We never saw a retirement incomes policy from the present Leader of the Opposition when he was Treasurer or from the Fraser government. Despite what the Whitlam government tried to do, it took this government, fighting tooth and nail every step of the way, to get a compulsory superannuation scheme going so that high income earners and long-time public servants would not be the only people to benefit from a superannuation scheme, which because of tax incentives always gave further tax benefits to high income earners.

We as a government realised that, given that we have an ageing population and that working people will probably spend 20 to 30 years in retirement with better health and will want to do more and have a better standard of living, we had to help them now and, at the same time, increase our deplorable record in national savings—all the things I would have thought the opposition would have applauded. But no, it does not want to do that; that is all too difficult.

Let us just get the figures right. Single persons on average wages who have been in the work force since their thirties could have expected pre-budget to have received $264,427 in superannuation. In future, they can expect to receive nearly $462,000. Pre-budget, a couple on average wages could have expected to have received around $455,000. In future, they can expect to receive a vastly increased amount—$797,000. The measure will also assist women who are working part time. In delivering the budget, the Treasurer said:

SPEECH.PARA: For a couple on average earnings, now in their mid-30s, the Government's initiatives deliver retirement incomes 75 per cent higher than the age pension.

We have a very positive commitment to provide those tax cuts. We brought the first part forward in the 1993 budget. Now we are delivering in a way that will materially assist families when they most need it—at retirement—while at the same time providing a vastly increased pool of savings. It will benefit workers right up to the higher income earners. I believe what we have done on superannuation is very important.

PARA.TAB: The other thing we have done is to provide information to people. One of the concerns in the community has been the many changes to the superannuation scheme. They have occurred because we have been trying to make it better and more effective all the time. This is particularly true of the collection mechanisms for small fund and part-time workers. But it is very important to know that, if people have concerns, the Taxation Office has actually put in place an information hotline that people can access. If people ring 13 10 20, they will get their information. There are a number of other hotlines that people can ring to get the information they require. I believe that once people are aware of the benefits they will indeed be very positive and the positive poll results on this issue will be further entrenched.

In comparison, what is the opposition delivering? I thought I would be underwhelmed by the response from the Leader of the Opposition—I said that in the House on the day he delivered his response—but I was appalled by his response. The Leader of the Opposition said that the opposition would oppose various tax cuts, the rise in company tax and so on. But several days later the shadow Treasurer, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Costello)—that slick salesperson with no substance, little style but a bit of slickness, as Michael Gordon suggested in his article—said, `No. We will oppose them, but if they get through we will not change that.' What sort of hypocrisy is that? I notice that Tom Burton in the Australian Financial Review on 26 May wrote an article headed `Will the real John Howard stand up'. The opposition does not have any policies and does not have any leadership.

At the end of the day, this budget is a piece which contains all our policies. It is integrated, forward looking and will deliver real assistance for families. It will enable an increase in the number of jobs. This five minutes of economic sunshine that the Leader of the Opposition talks about, as the Minister for Employment, Education and Training said, is nonsense when this government has been producing employment growth that those opposite said could never happen and projected could never be achieved. The government has delivered 640,000 new jobs. It will continue to do that because it has a fiscally responsible budget and socially just policies.

The credibility and integrity of our policies will win the day. The emperor on the other side of the House has no clothes. The opposition has no policies. At the end of the day, it will be seen to have no policies. All the opposition can do is whinge and provide illogical and inconsistent arguments with no substance. I have not heard one thing from the opposition since the budget was delivered that puts it up as an alternative government. Increasingly, the electorate will see this to be the case. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Somlyay Mr A.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is fundamentally wrong with this budget is that people just do not believe the government any more. Do you know why? It used to be the `true believers'; it is rapidly becoming the `few believers'. This was demonstrated for everybody on this side of the House on the Four Corners program when a former Secretary to the Treasury, Tony Cole, revealed to this nation that your One Nation tax cuts, your One Nation package, before the 1993 election was built on a lie. The fundamental premise, the economic forecasts, were falsified.

PARA.TAB: The only conclusion that one can draw from that fact is that the tax cuts that were promised in One Nation were never intended to be delivered. The whole package of One Nation, as I said, was built on a lie and delivered as a lie during the election campaign. This was borne out after the election in the second Dawkins budget.

Yesterday we heard two maiden speeches, one from the member for Canberra (Mr Smyth) and one from the member for Wentworth (Mr Thomson). The interesting thing is that when people make maiden speeches, and every person in this House of course does, they speak from the heart. They speak with sincerity. It is usually a reflection of what they really believe, not what the party apparatchiks want them to say. I was interested to hear yesterday the member for Wentworth observing what this country was like at his birth 34 years ago, what it is like now and the transition that has taken place in the last 13 years.

I was prompted to go back and read my maiden speech, which I made in this House some five years ago. I covered the impact of the 1990 budget on my electorate. I told the House that my electorate of Fairfax was a retirement area with well above the state average number of retirees in the population, both pensioners and non-pensioners. The engine room of my electorate is small business based on tourism, the hospitality industry and, of course, the building industry. I told the House of the importance of the sugar industry and tropical agriculture.

What has changed for my electorate after five years and six ALP budgets? Not much. The problems I spoke about which I could not understand, and which my electors could not understand, was why the government would increase interest rates for small business, why people with mortgages had to pay $300 or $400 more per month, and why wives had to return unwillingly to work to pay that mortgage on the pretext that this would solve our current account deficit.

We had too many imports flowing into this country. The only way the government sought to reduce imports was through a monetary policy—increasing interest rates, taking money out of people's pockets so they could not save and, obviously, could not spend. Six years later, what do we have? Yesterday's current account deficit figure was $2.2 billion. We have an accumulative current account deficit which has not been addressed.

Forcing up interest rates to cut imports has achieved nothing but recession. The problems of 1990 are still here today. In my five years in parliament six budgets have been handed down by five different treasurers. I will go through a few of the budgets that have been brought down during my time in this House, which is just a few short years. In 1990 Treasurer Keating said:
Australia has negotiated a difficult transition over the last 12 months from an economy where spending and growth were overblown to an economy with lower activity and fewer imports.

SPEECH.PARA: That could well be said today. He continued:

PARA.TAB: National Accounts data released tonight with the Budget show that the economy has slowed.
The current account deficit is falling and inflation is abating.
Economic policy has worked and is working.
The faith the Australian people exhibited in the Government at the election is now being repaid as the economy adjusts to a sustainable rate of growth without a catastrophic collapse.
In short, the kind of outcome the Government was seeking, delivered without the misery and despair of high unemployment and a savage recession.

SPEECH.PARA: That was the first budget I sat through under this government. But it did not make sense to me because I knew that was not the case in my electorate. As we know, we ended up with the worst recession in 60 years and the highest unemployment since the Great Depression.

PARA.TAB: In his 1990 speech, the Treasurer also said the Australian community had faced difficulties of high unemployment and recession `with a great degree of understanding and forbearance' and `an understanding that the reformation of the economy is a continuing and at times difficult task'. That was Treasurer Keating's Holy Grail.

The following year, one Treasurer later, Treasurer Keating passed on his Holy Grail to John Kerin and it became Kerin's poison chalice. Treasurer Kerin opened his first and only budget speech by saying it had been a disappointing year for all Australians, `a year of lost jobs, squeezed profits and dashed hopes'. That was in stark contrast to what Treasurer Keating had said the year before when he said that the Australian community had faced the difficulties of high unemployment and recession `with a great degree of understanding and forbearance'. Treasurer Kerin went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . we could not continue to spend more than we produce without imports being far too high and bringing on an acute current account crisis.

PARA.TAB: We were living beyond our means. We could not continue to do that without facing dire consequences.

SPEECH.PARA: Does this sound familiar? They are the sorts of things we hear budget after budget. In 1992 Treasurer Dawkins handed down his first budget. The 1992-93 budget was an election budget. It was a year during which unemployment reached one million, 11.3 per cent of the population, and the nation was devastated. That budget talked about training and retraining, and $1.2 billion was allocated over two years.

PARA.TAB: This was the introduction of the Labor government's scheme to hide unemployment. The object was not to help Australians find jobs but to keep a certain percentage of unemployed people out of the unemployment figures because an election was looming. The next year, 1993, the Labor Party was re-elected by using the slogan `jobs not GST'. We all heard it. It was plastered up across this nation. It was a deceitful, negative campaign which sought to discredit solid policies which, at the time, were badly needed by this country.

When Treasurer Dawkins announced his second budget, which became known as the tax lie budget, he said that it would stimulate growth in exports and training. After using the theme of jobs not GST, and having no mandate to increase taxes, Treasurer Dawkins introduced the high tax budget. What did Treasurer Dawkins say about indirect taxes? He said that indirect taxes had to be increased otherwise income tax would have to be increased. That of course affected middle income Australia. Did we hear that from him before the election?

The l-a-w, law, tax cuts which had been legislated before the election were scrapped. As I said at the beginning of my remarks, it was revealed by Tony Cole that the forecasts in the One Nation statement were falsified and the tax cuts were never meant to be delivered. The 1993 budget clearly shows that that is in fact what occurred.

The higher taxes introduced by the Labor government included a 7c a litre excise on leaded petrol and a 5c a litre excise on unleaded petrol. It also introduced a three per cent excise on tobacco and increased sales tax which was to be applied in stages. The last stage will be effective from 1 July this year. This should have been a budget item in this budget, not the budget two years ago.

People have had enough of the deception, the shonky figures, the trickery, the craftiness, the illusions, the swindles, the sneaky tricks, the fraud and the dupes. As I have said, the true believers are rapidly becoming the few believers. I have sat in this House and listened to budget after budget and they are all the same. People honestly tell me that they are fed up and have had enough.

Last year, the Treasurer (Mr Willis) told the House with a straight face that the 1994-95 budget would maximise economic growth, reduce unemployment, promote social justice and reduce the budget deficit without increasing taxes. This was after the government had introduced taxes to take effect this year. The l-a-w, law, tax increases were already legislated. Why is it that tax increases legislated in advance are delivered and tax cuts legislated in advance are deferred, changed, dropped or abandoned?

The Treasurer this year again read his budget speech with a straight face. I admire him for that. Somebody said to me the other day that he must feel like Ali Baba watching the 40 thieves hop into the cave. This year we have seen Labor doing what it knows best—upping taxes.

Small business is the engine of growth that drives the economy and the wealth of this nation. Small business in my electorate is tourism and building industry based. A downturn in the economy caused by Labor's short-sighted economic vandalism is reflected in the fact that small business is going to the wall.

Every year the building industry and small business are being hit by the cumulative effect of higher income tax, increased sales tax, higher regulation and more complicated paperwork associated with compliance. We know about the increasing cost of compliance in relation to the fringe benefits tax. The cost of compliance amounts to half the tax collected.

The business community is appalled at how out of touch this government and the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) are with reality when they say to small business that it does not get any better. They say this at a time when small businesses are going broke. When a business goes broke people are put out of work and bills are not paid. In my area, the building industry is suffering and the subcontractors are bearing the brunt of the problem. They cannot absorb the costs into their overheads so they have to pass them on to consumers. We all pay a higher price. The case is not that small business has never had it so good, the case is that small business is made up of desperate Australians living on a knife edge.

The opinion in my electorate is that the economy went off the boil quite some time ago—as early as March last year in some sectors. The real estate industry showed a downturn before the government raised interest rates. The situation was exacerbated in my tourism based economy by the most severe drought we have seen for many years. Spending on tourism and associated small business was down so we have gone off the boil.

Every section of the business community in my electorate that I have spoken to has told me that the current climate is a disaster. They certainly do not believe in the five per cent growth rate predicted in this year's budget. Where is it? In what industries is it in? In what states and in what regions is it in? If the economy has gone off the boil then there is no way the government is going to achieve the profits predicted from the sale of assets.

The budget surplus of $718 million is manufactured. Everyone in business knows that you sell assets for one of two reasons. You sell assets either to pay off debts or to cash up to use for investment to expand and create more employment. You do not sell assets for current consumption, which is what this government wants to do.

We all know that the budget surplus was manufactured at the last moment. Two days before the budget was delivered the Prime Minister decided in his office that he would have a manufactured surplus. The decision was taken at the last moment to sell the Commonwealth Bank and other major assets. Other members have raised the issue of the sale of Dasfleet. That was a fraudulent exercise. At the last minute the government decided to sell Dasfleet. It included the proceeds of sale on the revenue side of the budget, but it did not include the running costs on the other side of the ledger.

In my electorate, small business people have lost confidence in the government. They have also lost confidence in the rules they are forced to operate under. They are continually hit with higher taxes, more rules and unpaid debts. I know that the situation is similar all over Australia. Small business suppliers, especially building subcontractors and suppliers, are left in crisis when others go bankrupt. For businesses operating already on tight profit margins, writing off big losses is almost impossible.

Members of the government's front bench do not understand this because they have no experience in business. I look at the front bench every day and I see that they are either from trade unions or they are academics. There is nothing wrong with that, but there is nobody on that side of the House with any experience in business. I call upon the government to set up a parliamentary inquiry into Australia's bankruptcy laws and the cost of bankruptcy to this nation, businesses, individuals and families so that it understands what it has done to this country and how it has destroyed businesses and the accumulated wealth of generations.

I want people like the subcontractors, builders and suppliers in my electorate to be able to give evidence to this parliament. I want the Prime Minister and his front bench to hear the real stories of real people who are struggling to keep their heads above water, the small business battlers. They make up the majority of unsecured creditors, but they are the backbone of this nation.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the few joys you get in this parliament is sitting in here and listening to debate in respect of appropriations. In a sense, it is a form of comic relief as people postulate—
—Do you think it is funny?

—No. What I think is funny is the speeches I hear from people who condemn everything out of hand but have not got a clue what they would do themselves. The other big thing about this budget is that speakers on the appropriation bills do not have to be relevant, which is just as well because it is very hard to be relevant about a budget that has already been brought down. But I must say that the tedious drivel that one hears comes from both sides. We worship the chivalrous, we talk about small business without actually understanding or knowing what small business is or what the real problems are. I suggest to this House that the great problem today is that we have far too much bipartisanship in this place. There is really not a great deal of difference between the rabble on that side and what the government proposes and what the government is doing. Sadly, neither, in my view, has the answer.

PARA.TAB: We are told how important tourism is, that tourism is the solution. I can remember that not so many years ago tourism was going to be the answer to our problems. The truth about tourism is this: no-one can tell you what the net figure for tourism is, but it is one hell of a lot less than the gross figure. That is also true for elaborately transformed manufactured goods. We on this side say, `We have increased it, as a percentage of revenue, to 30 per cent from a very low base.' That sounds significant and it is. But, once again, it is a gross figure, not a net figure. No-one really knows what the net figure is. Once again, like tourism, it is considerably less than the gross figure.

The current account deficit is a great problem confronting Australia. I hear some people on this side say, `It doesn't matter because the current account deficit is not government debt; it is private sector debt.' The effect on the economy is exactly the same; it does not matter. The current account deficit is a problem and it must be brought under control. The problem is that once we get above four per cent growth in the economy we suck up imports because we do not manufacture anything any more. If you have more than four per cent growth, the current account is going to blow out. That has to be addressed by a coherent industry policy. I see no signs of industry policy on either side of this House. In fact, the position of the opposition, as it goes to a supposed level playing field with zero tariffs, will compound the errors that we are making.

There are a few other things in the budget that need to be mentioned in passing. The government is expressing its concern about Aboriginal health, and it will demonstrate this by spending $102 million on Aboriginal health over two years. We are also putting $46 million into housing over two years to improve Aboriginal housing. The reality is this: if you really want to improve Aboriginal health—and I am not sure that is the end desire—what you would do is put the $102 million into housing.

By improving the level of housing you would automatically improve the level of health. That is not what we will do. We will go on funding Aboriginal medical services, which is basically an expensive way of providing an inferior service. The evidence to demonstrate that is overwhelming, but we will keep on doing it because it is politically correct to do so. The reality is that the opposition will do just the same because it is afflicted with the same sort of political correctness.

The sale of assets has been mentioned. It is true that many people believe that the sale of assets is an easy option and if it does not work then you sell them again. Unfortunately, you cannot do that. You lose the income stream of those assets when they are sold. I have no great view about government ownership of many things, but there are some things I believe should be under government control, and I would go to the barricades for some of those things. I would argue, for instance, that the big advances in telecommunications have been brought about not by competition, as we are told by both sides of parliament, but by technological advancement. I believe that Telecom was one of the great unifying factors in society, providing services equally across the community. It is going to be forced to abandon that scheme or dilute it due to economic pressures imposed upon it. This should be remembered.

The sale and lease-back of Commonwealth cars, I must say, is stupid. It will undoubtedly cost more in the long run than the present system. There is absolutely no doubt about that. If we do that for cosmetic reasons, it is basically silly. I might just say while I am on the subject that Commonwealth cars are, in my view, exceptional value. It is not readily recognised by either sides of this House that they provide a very good service—a service that the government will have to provide at some level. You simply cannot put visiting heads of state into taxis. It is a service that, I believe, is worth the money it costs. When people talk about losses, they are talking about book entries, shuffling from one department to the other. I think the time is overdue for us to take a serious look at a real cost benefit analysis of the Commonwealth car service.

In relation to superannuation, it is quite clear that we need to increase saving in this country, but I am not sure myself that I trust the superannuation companies. They are mainly incompetent, and the returns they have had in recent years have been negative in many cases. I know of cases where people are actually losing their capital because of the very high charges imposed by incompetent funds. I also have grave concern that sooner or later we are going to see one of these superannuation companies fall over, go broke. I believe that the government will then be in a dilemma of having an absolute moral obligation, if not a legal obligation, to bale that fund out. The government has forced people to put their money into these companies and, therefore, I believe the government's moral obligation would be absolute. That is something that has to be recognised.

My own view is that the British have done it somewhat better with their funded pension scheme. The funded pension scheme in Britain—and remember that Margaret Thatcher never touched the British funded pension scheme; she never attempted to dismantle it or privatise it in any way—collects money from people through the taxation system, puts it into the funded pension scheme and provides a safety net. People wanting more than that can arrange their own superannuation. I think that is a better option. It is interesting, too, that the British pension scheme is the largest investor in new British technology.

That cannot be said for superannuation companies in this country. They spend very little, infinitesimal amounts, in research or in the development of new technology. They simply will not take those risks. It is a risky area, but it has to be realised that success in those areas is very profitable. You do not have to pick that winner every time. I believe that we will have to look at a situation where, if the superannuation companies do not lift their game in respect of investing in new Australian technology, we will have to force them to do that. I say that with great regret because I do not believe, generally, in that line of action, but I think their performance to date has been so abysmal that we are going to have to do that.

I said that industry policy is the key. I think we have to decide what an industry policy is. An industry policy, in my view, is the arrangement of circumstances to provide the best opportunity for chosen industries to develop, thrive and to continue. It is not just directions from manufacturing in isolation. It has to be integrated with influences as diverse as industrial relations, immigration policy, social welfare policy, taxation, environmental policy, research and development policy, foreign aid, government purchasing policy, and, above all, the government's attitude to its own people.

TALK.START.PARA: —The number of reports over the years on the problems of Sydney's urban sprawl would no doubt fill the Opera House. It would, therefore, be naive to think that any great breakthrough will emerge from New South Wales Premier Carr's latest call for an examination of the problem. Nevertheless, there are some grounds for optimism.

PARA.TAB: Carr is certainly the first major figure in state or federal governments to dare to raise the fundamental cause of urban sprawl—population growth and, therefore, immigration. It is true that there are many other causes of sprawl and that even with no immigration the population would still grow slightly for a few years; nevertheless, immigration is the dominant cause, all things being equal.

If we continue with current policies, we can expect a Sydney population of over 4.5 million in 25 years. That means at least 500,000 new dwellings and space for many thousands of workplaces, shops, community facilities, roads and all the services required by the increased population. It means a further deterioration in the quality of life.

Given the present state of the Sydney basin—with such problems as the ocean beaches contaminated with raw sewage, contamination of the Hawkesbury-Nepean waterway, the problems of air quality, waste disposal, endless traffic congestion and the failure of successive state government urban consolidation policies—Premier Carr is certainly correct in raising this issue. We are now paying the penalty for the last 50 years of running the developed world's highest rate of immigration while simultaneously reducing urban infrastructure spending in real terms.

Immigration policy, since it lost public support in the 1960s, has been driven by special interest. Migration numbers have never been determined by considering the effect on infrastructure, health, education, urban sprawl or, in fact, almost anything except political advantage. It has been a cat and mouse game balancing ethnic demands and public opinion and maintaining a bipartisan position depriving the public of any say. Total immigration figures have, therefore, wildly fluctuated from year to year, rather than having established a long-term, considered, sustainable target.

The hysterical reaction to Carr's initiative from `the usual suspects' underlines the difficulty of sensibly addressing immigration numbers. Ethnic leaders will continue to generate community distrust and undermine their own credibility while ever they continue to react to any suggestion of questioning immigration levels as a `racist attack on migrants', ignoring all other effects of population growth.

State Liberal MP Helen Sham-Ho went right over the top in accusing Carr of racial vilification and promoting hatred on the basis of ethnic origins. Coming from a leading spokesperson for ethnic communities, this shows what can happen under racial vilification legislation.

For a rational statement on immigration and urban sprawl, whatever its merits, one could be impoverished after having been dragged through a futile court action. No reasonable person faced with the prospect of being financially broken will be prepared to even enter into public discussion.

It is irrelevant that the racial vilification accusations made by Sham-Ho are ridiculous and only show her obsessive and myopic view of the world. The fact that Sham-Ho's views are shared by a large number of racial McCarthyists heading many publicly funded organisations determined to find racists under every bed now makes discussion of population growth extremely dangerous. It confirms that freedom of speech is massively limited by racial vilification legislation and the threat of expensive legal action.

Premier Carr has had no choice but to raise the question of sustainable population growth, given the federal government's abysmal record of ignoring the problems. The reaction of the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Bolkus) of pandering to ethnic fears in an attempt to curry political favour, and the irrelevant mantra from the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Howe), who equated urban sprawl with residential density claiming in effect that population growth is not a factor, leaves any dispassionate observer in despair.

Urban sprawl in Sydney and most of Australia's urban areas is a result of four major factors: firstly, the conscious and unconscious policy decisions of state and federal governments over the last 50 years to encourage and subsidise road based transport; secondly, the lack of any land use transport plan and even any mechanism to implement such a plan if it existed; thirdly, ignoring the effect of the expansion of non-residential land uses, which makes up about 70 per cent of urban areas in Australia; and, fourthly, the rate of population growth. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight on the adjournment debate I want to comment about the Cape York Peninsula in my electorate. The first comment I make is that I was very pleased last week to go with the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner) on a visit to the

SPEECH.PARA: western Cape York Peninsula. We visited Kowanyama, Pormpuraaw, Aurukun, Weipa, Napranum, Mapoon and, on Friday, Mossman Gorge. It was a very successful visit.

PARA.TAB: Quite often when people refer to the Cape York Peninsula in my electorate, they highlight the negative aspects of Aboriginal communities. But the minister and I saw very positive things coming out of those Aboriginal communities. In particular, it was a great honour for me to go to Mapoon, which is north of Weipa in my electorate. The Mapoon community is probably one of the most recent examples of dispossession in Australia. The National Party government colluded in burning down the houses of those people and transferring them to the northern peninsula area.

TALK.START.PARA: —Disgraceful.

—It was disgraceful, as the honourable member for Oxley said. The people of Mapoon have shown great courage and determination—and I commend that—in going back to their land and building a community there. It is great to see the strength of that community growing.

PARA.TAB: We visited Kowanyama, and it is good to see the things that are happening in the justice system in that community. Under an initiative of the Queensland government, they already have local JPs who have been trained. They are able to hand out punishments which are in tune with Queensland law, while also utilising their own knowledge of local laws and penalties when considering individual cases. That is a very good scheme.

In Kowanyama, we also heard about the proposal to have a community accounting conferencing scheme. This is a system where every person in the community who has been affected by a crime has an opportunity to participate in community dialogue, resulting in an offender being able to see the full impact of how his or her crime affected each person. That is very important because there are problems—especially with youth crime—in communities like Kowanyama. This proposal has been welcomed by the Kowanyama community council in response to a joint proposal put forward by policeman Bill Hiscocks and the school principal, Barbara Loban. I certainly commend the Kowanyama community for this initiative.

It was also positive to see the women of Pormpuraaw at the women's centre who were taking the lead in their community. It was good to see the development of labour market programs, such as LEAP, at Aurukun. It was good to see the initiatives taken by the Napranum council, both in doing work for the Weipa community and in the completion of the fencing contract for the Scherger air base. It was great—and I know the minister will agree with me on this—to go to Mossman Gorge to see that community's plans for development in the tourism industry in a very beautiful part of my electorate.

Of course, things like roads and health were raised. These matters are perennial problems in the peninsula and cannot be ignored. In Kowanyama, the problem of roads and the resulting isolation of the community in the wet season was also mentioned.

Tonight I would also like to talk about an important mining town which has been in the news lately for more than its mining. I visited Weipa with Minister Tickner. The media has fixed on Weipa as an example of bank greed. Bank bashing has become a national sport in Australia. Some of the people's criticisms of banks are excessive, but not in this case. Nowhere has there been a greater example of a bank failing in its service obligations.

The Commonwealth Bank decided to close its Weipa branch in November last year. There was no consultation or notification and residents of Weipa were suddenly faced with the prospect of going from having full banking services to having few options. No-one had any idea that the bank would be closing its branch. When the Commonwealth Bank made the decision, people found out with only two weeks notice.

Understandably, Weipa residents were not happy about the closure and protested strongly. People such as Anna Clark put in a great deal of work to impress upon the bank the stupidity of its decision. I have contacted the bank on several occasions. The bank was so arrogant that it did not even reply to my letters. The Commonwealth Bank's short-term financial decision must result in long-term losses as the goodwill and customer loyalty of people in Weipa disintegrates.

Luckily, there is a happy ending. The Queensland Credit Union has decided to set up a branch in Weipa. That will happen in late July. Certainly, the Queensland Credit Union's reward for its decision is a monopoly banking market in Weipa and the fierce loyalty of a small and dynamic community.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer to the drought assistance package for New South Wales and Victoria which has just been released by the government. The package consisted of $40.3 million as further drought relief support for both of those areas. But the areas in Victoria to receive assistance are the old local government areas of Wimmera and the northern part of Ararat. There was absolutely nothing for north central Victoria. North central Victoria is one of the hardest hit drought areas in Australia. It is probably experiencing the worst drought in its history, yet this government has offered no financial assistance to the farmers or their families in that area.

PARA.TAB: Bendigo and district farming families in these areas will miss out on assistance in the form of interest rate subsidies on up to 100 per cent of their outstanding debt; a drought relief repayment to meet day-to-day living expenses; basic and additional family payment; partner allowance as applicable; and health care card and Austudy eligibility concessions. I cannot understand it, and neither can the farming families in my area. Why is the government pouring billions of dollars into job creation programs when some well placed assistance in the farm sector would do more to put people back into employment than would any number of short-term programs? Here was an opportunity for the government to provide these farming communities with financial assistance and income support to get them through the next nine months. This financial assistance is critical for grain producers in that area. It would ensure that they are viable so that they can support their families until such time as they receive some income from the grain that they are planting at the moment.

I ask the government: why has it ignored north central Victoria in its latest allocation of drought funds when north central Victoria has been hit by the worst drought in its history and when farmers in that area have a limited or a nil income for the next nine months? Is it because the 1995 budget is in deep financial strife with particular doubts over increased interest rates and likely problems with asset sales or has the government simply abandoned farmers in this area?

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australia Remembers 1945-1995 commemorative campaign has been an outstanding success. It has received a tremendous response right throughout Australia, and my electorate has been no exception to that. I would like to take a few minutes to speak briefly about the commemorative services that were held to mark VE Day on 7 May.

PARA.TAB: I would like to thank a few people for their assistance in making the ceremony in Ipswich such a success. I refer in particular to Group Captain Phil Presgrave and Warrant Officer David Basham of the RAAF base at Amberley. The air force base has naturally been very supportive of this program, and I would like to put on record my deep appreciation of that.

Our memorial service and wreath laying ceremony, which was held on Sunday, 7 May to remember VE Day, was a very successful day as a result of the support that we had from the RAAF base at Amberley. Our guest speaker, retired Air Commodore Deryck Kingwell, was a former commanding officer of the RAAF base at Amberley. I would like to say a few things about retired Air Commodore Kingwell tonight. Everyone who attended the ceremony was moved by his speech and his reminiscence of the war in which he served with distinction.

Deryck Kingwell was born in Brisbane on 15 June 1916. His association with flying began early with his great interest and involvement in the Annerley Gliding Club, which flew at the open fields at the Yeronga-Fairfield bend of the Brisbane River. In 1935 he applied to join the RAAF and was inducted into Point Cook in July 1936 as an air cadet. At that time, the Royal Australian Air Force consisted of 138 officers, 61 cadets and 1,166 airmen.

Deryck Kingwell's induction into the RAAF was the start of an auspicious service career, spanning some 35 years. It began in the right vein, with him winning both the Sword of Honour upon graduation as the top cadet and the Mannock Cup for best pilot on the course. After a short posting to No. 3 Squadron at Richmond and some time in Britain on training, he returned to Point Cook for training as an instructor in mid-1938.

When war was declared, the expansion of the RAAF became the major priority in his life. At the age of just 23, he became the chief instructor at the General Reconnaissance School at Point Cook. He established and ran the first wartime specialist navigation course in the RAAF. Some 18 months later, at what by today's standards was the remarkably young age of just 24, he became Squadron Leader Kingwell and took command of the school at Point Cook.

Later he took command of No. 23 Squadron at Archerfield. In 1942 the Squadron's Hudsons were posted to Port Moresby and linked up with Hudsons from No. 6 Squadron and No. 24 Squadron to form the new No. 32 Squadron under the command of Deryck Kingwell. His job was to stem what at the time seemed to be the inevitable Japanese tide of conquest in the Pacific. He had to do this with a total of just 10 Hudsons and a handful of Catalina flying boats at his command.

Time will not allow me to cover everything, but there were some tremendous stories told about Air Commodore Kingwell in his war history, particularly in Papua New Guinea. At one stage he was attacked by some Japanese Zeros. Of course, the Hudsons were a reasonably slow aircraft against Japanese Zero fighters. So they used to often hide in the cloud as part of their manoeuvres. During this particular conflict, it just happened to be a fine day. They went through all the manoeuvres and the Zeros were actually defeated on this occasion, which was a good thing. The Hudson was damaged and crew were wounded, but they got back to base safely—no doubt as a result of Air Commodore Kingwell's experience.

After the war, the now retired Air Commodore Kingwell filled many posts in the RAAF, both in Australia and overseas. He was instrumental in recommending the purchase of the Macchi aircraft in which so many RAAF pilots have done their jet training. He held the position of officer commanding Amberley air force base twice—first from 1954 to 1956 and again from 1967 to 1971—as Air Commodore Kingwell. Before his retirement in 1971 he was responsible for, amongst other things, replacing 82 Wing's Lincoln bombers with Canberras, which were in turn replaced with Phantoms. Unfortunately, Air Commodore Kingwell retired before the F111 was introduced to Amberley. Of course, he would have loved to have been part of that as well.

I would like to put on record my appreciation to all the RAAF people at Amberley of their assistance and, in particular, to retired Air Commodore Kingwell for his participation in the VE Day commemorative service in Ipswich.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I would like to pay tribute to the Troiani family of Bundaberg in my electorate of Hinkler on a truly remarkable achievement in building products technology. This family owns and operates Australia's largest privately owned brick manufacturer—Wide Bay Bricks—on the Bundaberg industrial estate. Last Wednesday saw a major milestone in this highly successful regionally based family company which now sells bricks not only to an extensive domestic market but to the world.

PARA.TAB: Last week Wide Bay Bricks unveiled the latest and biggest upgrade—the largest and most advanced roller kiln not in Australia but in the world. It is a tribute to provincial companies to think that, with all the demand for building products in an expanding nation like Australia, what was once a relatively small brickworks in a provincial town could now have the largest roller kiln technology not only in Australia but in the world.

The roller kiln, costing $14 million, incorporates the latest in clay brick manufacturing technology and will boost the company's total production capacity to around 90 million bricks a year. The high-tech mori roller kiln will further enhance the company's strong reputation for quality brick products and customer service.

Much of Wide Bay's success can be attributed to the company's founder, Mr Sante Troiani; the Troiani family partners, his brothers and sisters; and the Luff family of the Sunshine Coast. Success did not come easily for Sante Troiani. He was a young man when he came out to Australia in the postwar period. He worked as a cane cutter, and got a little farm. He brought out his brother, his sister came and worked for the two boys, and they built up a very successful cane farm. They became highly expert orchardists in the fields of mangoes and avocados and, later as floriculturalists, their carnations became famous throughout Australia.

It was a chance investment and a love of ceramics from his native part of Italy on the east coast that saw Sante Troiani purchase the run-down Bundaberg brickworks in 1974—purely as an investment; he never saw himself as a brickmaker. But, as I said, his love of ceramics and the fact he had this brickworks that only turned out 4 1/2 million bricks enticed him to do something with it. In 1976—and I remember this day well as I was there—the then Premier, Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen, opened Sante Troiani's plant on Bundaberg's industrial estate. By 1986, just 10 years later, he had introduced one of the first tunnel kilns to Australia at a cost of $5 million, lifting the brickwork's capacity from about four million bricks to 48 million bricks.

That was a struggle, too. It did not come easily. I remember he had terrific problems in adapting European technology to the Australian conditions, Australian clays and Australian gases. During this time he developed a whole range of products—patented reinforced products—and he was probably the first to develop the clay block, as distinct from the brick, which became the rival for the concrete block and has become very important in designing buildings against earthquakes, cyclones, and that sort of thing.

In 1990 the company started exporting bricks to New Zealand—and that is quite an achievement; you would hardly think it would be profitable to ship bricks across the Tasman. But not to be outdone in that enterprise, in December 1990 he then started to export to Japan. He now exports 15 per cent of his production to the Asia-Pacific region. This roller kiln of course, with its capacity of 90 million bricks, will put him into yet another league.

Tonight I would like to pay tribute to this family. I was present on Wednesday when the state Minister for Industry, Business and Regional Development, Warren Pitt, opened the brickworks. I was able to join with 200 of Mr Sante Troiani's business associates, builders and friends in paying him tribute and recording his success and the contribution he has made to the community. It has not just been one of creating jobs and creating clay products. He has put a lot back into the community; he has been a great agriculturalist. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —At the 1993 election the government made a commitment to the Australian people that it would engineer strong economic growth and job growth in Australia—and it has done that. At that time the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) made a commitment to the Australian people and to the unemployed of this country not to leave them behind in the economic recovery.

PARA.TAB: The government responded to the unemployment situation in 1994 with the Working Nation program, the most ambitious and comprehensive economic and social program announced by any government in our postwar history. The government committed billions of dollars worth of Commonwealth resources and called on communities to enter into a partnership with the Commonwealth to confront the unemployment problems in their own areas.

The Geelong community responded admirably to this challenge and formed a local task force to initiate a jobs action campaign, which it entitled `We're all in it'. That program was initiated by the city of Greater Geelong in cooperation with a radio station, Bay FM, the CES, the community of Geelong, employers, the trade union movement, community groups—and, of course, I give a special mention to the Rotary clubs of Geelong who swung in strongly behind that campaign.

The campaign was announced by the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Crean) on 21 July 1994. It had a fairly ambitious target of creating 1,000 vacancies in a 12-month period. In addition to those activities, the committee organised an industrial relations seminar, which was very successful, and also promoted vigorously the national training wage.

I pay tribute to the committee and the task force and, in particular, Trevor Cole, Chairman of the Rotary Service Clubs, who did much to rally the Rotary clubs of Geelong in this endeavour; he had a passion for this particular campaign, and its success is owed very much to his efforts. I also pay tribute to Glyn Jenkins, Deputy Chairman of City of Greater Geelong Commissioners; he came to me in the early stages and asked whether the Commonwealth would commit its resources to this campaign which he worked tirelessly to support. Tony Stante of the CES, Geelong region, also did a power of work in a secretarial and administrative support role to that committee and put in a lot of leg work; the success of the campaign is directly attributable to his efforts as well.

I also pay tribute to Reg Fisher of the Greater City of Geelong; Jenny Stow, Regional Manager of CES, Geelong; Victor Hunt of the Geelong Trades Hall Council; David Peart of the City of Greater Geelong Development Unit; Cath Fraser of Sales-Marketing, Geelong Advertiser Group; Laurie Wanders from CES Employer Services; Steve Gartland from my office; and of course Graeme Bound, Regional Director, Brotherhood of St Laurence—all of whom formed the core committee.

Former members who also contributed and supported that campaign were Gordon Bratby, formerly of Bay FM; Graeme Hawkins, Development Board, Greater City of Geelong; John Kranz, Secretary, Geelong Trades Hall; and Lisa Meyers, Regional Manager, CES, Geelong. Additional support came from Cathy Roth, Geelong Chamber of Commerce; Mike O'Brien, Australian Chamber of Manufactures; Graeme Esler, VECCI; Jim Harvey, Metal Trades Industry Association; David Rolfe, Geelong Region Group Training; and Graeme Goldsworthy, Geelong Otway Tourism Authority. It was a magnificent effort from that particular committee. I bring the efforts of the committee to the attention of the House and, through this adjournment debate, from the citizens of the Greater City of Geelong, thank the members for their magnificent effort.

TALK.START.PARA: —Most members of this House would accept that I have a very strong record in the area of the environment. Tonight I wish to draw to the attention of the House a matter of very great concern—and that is our appalling record nationally in relation to the preservation of our very many species of flora and fauna. In particular, the state of Queensland has a very bad record.

PARA.TAB: I was disturbed to read in the Courier-Mail today that we have, in Queensland, the worst record of mass extinction of animal species in the world. This report came from a Queensland museum expert. The expert is Glen Ingram, Senior Curator of Vertebrate Zoology. He said that as many as six frog species might have become extinct in the last 15 years in what he considered to be—and I agree with him—an international environmental tragedy.

The Queensland people have endeavoured to get a seventh species of frog, the sharp-snouted day frog, breeding again. Unfortunately, this plan has turned to disaster with the only known female carrying eggs dying in Melbourne. I think as a nation we really have to realise that we hold our world in trust for future generations, and we have to do whatever is necessary to preserve our flora and fauna.
