TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, upon notice, on 31 January 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) On which issues and proposals has the Commonwealth sought the agreement of the States in working parties of the Australian Education Council since 1991.
(2) How long did each State take to respond in each case.
(3) Was agreement eventually reached in each case; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Crean The Hon S.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1)-(3) The Australian Education Council (AEC) was a Council of Commonwealth and State Ministers with portfolio responsibility for education. The function of the Council was to promote the development of Australian education by enabling Ministers to consult on matters of common interest and generally to facilitate exchange of information and co-ordination of common programs. The Chair of the meeting rotated annually among members.

The AEC was merged with the Ministers of Vocational Education, Employment and Training (MOVEET) and the Youth Ministers' Council in December 1993 to form the Ministerial Council on Education, Employment, Training and Youth Affairs (MCEETYA).

The AEC was supported by a Standing Committee of representatives of the Ministers, usually with head of department status. The AEC also established working parties according to need. Most had representation from all States and the Commonwealth but occasionally the AEC resolved that particular tasks be undertaken by smaller groups. Some working parties were ongoing; others were set up to work on a specific short-term task.

The AEC operated on a consensus basis and proposals, initiated by the Commonwealth or the States, would often change over time in light of the AEC consultative processes. Issues and proposals cannot always be clearly identified as wholly Commonwealth initiatives. Therefore, all parts of the question are answered together by referring to major proposals which the Commonwealth sponsored through the collaborative processes of the AEC.

As part of its policy to improve the quality of schooling the AEC agreed to promote a comprehensive national collaborative strategy. In 1989 the AEC ratified a set of common and agreed national goals for schooling in Australia. Following this agreement the Directors-General and Directors of Curriculum agreed in January 1991 that national curriculum statements should be prepared in the eight identified key learning areas. After a mapping of existing curricula was undertaken, the AEC commissioned the development of national statements and profiles in the learning areas of English, mathematics, arts, studies of society and environment, science, technology, health and physical education and languages other than English.

Draft statements and profiles for the eight learning areas were considered by the AEC in July 1993. They were neither endorsed nor rejected and the AEC resolved that they be referred back to the States for further review in consultation with the educational communities so that each State could determine if the initiatives should be pursued.
All States are now using the Curriculum statements and profiles for Australian schools as the basis for State based curriculum and syllabus development.

A Commonwealth discussion paper on a national policy on language and literacy was presented to, and endorsed by, the April 1991 meeting of the AEC. In September 1991 the Government launched the Australian Language and Literacy Policy (ALLP). The Policy set out Australia's language and literacy situation and made recommendations for initiatives and programs to improve language and literacy skills in Australia.

At its October 1991 meeting the AEC established an AEC/MOVEET Working Party to oversee national implementation of the ALLP. The Working Party, now known as the MCEETYA Taskforce on the ALLP, has three subgroups: the Languages Other Than English (LOTE) in Schools Subgroup, the Adult LOTE and Asian Studies Subgroup and the Adult English Language and Literacy Subgroup. Each subgroup has developed a collaborative strategy addressing activities in its area. All three strategies have been endorsed by MCEETYA.

ANSWER.PARA: National Policy for the Education of Girls

PARA.TAB: The National Policy for the Education of Girls was developed in recognition of the important role education has in enabling women and men to participate as equals in all aspects of life.

The AEC endorsed the National Policy in September 1987. In June 1990 the AEC agreed to `explicitly include, as one of the terms of reference for the writing of curriculum statements issued by the AEC, the principles and objectives of the National Policy for the Education of Girls'. The National Policy was reviewed in 1991. A major outcome from the review was the National Action Plan for the Education of Girls 1993-1997 (NAP) which was endorsed by the AEC in November 1992. Its eight priority areas form a framework for action and annual reporting. From 1994, the annual reporting on the NAP will be included as part of the Annual National Report on Schooling.

ANSWER.PARA: National Strategy for Equity in Schooling

PARA.TAB: In September 1992 the AEC endorsed Commonwealth proposals for collaborative development of a National Strategy for Equity in Schooling which would set the framework for the national effort in schools equity covering the Commonwealth's National Equity Program for Schools (NEPS), State programs and those run by the non-government sectors. The Schools Working Party coordinated the development of the Strategy, co-opting representatives of the Catholic and independent sectors.

In July 1993 the AEC endorsed a draft Strategy for community consultation, the results of which were reported to the December 1993 meeting. At that meeting the AEC referred finalisation of the Strategy to its successor MCEETYA. After further work by the Schools Taskforce MCEETYA adopted the Strategy in November 1994.
In December 1990 the AEC established a review of Young People's Participation in Post-Compulsory Education and Training (the `Finn Review').
In August 1991 the AEC approved the review report for release and consultation.
In October 1991 the AEC, combined with a meeting of MOVEET, endorsed the main elements of the review's recommendations including:
national goals for participation/attainment in post-compulsory education and training by young people;
in principle, the development of employment-related Key Competencies in post-compulsory education and training, subject to further work by the `Mayer Committee';
the importance of access to post-compulsory education and training by disadvantaged groups; and

the high priority for reform of entry-level training (which was being taken up concurrently by the Employment and Skills Formation Council (ESFC) of the National Board of Employment, Education and Training).

In March 1992 the ESFC released its report `The Australian Vocational Certificate Training System' which recommended introduction of a new entry level training system led by industry, based on competency-standards and establishing a set of articulated pathways including vocational education and training providers, schools and workplaces.

At joint AEC/MOVEET meetings in June 1992 the strategy in the ESFC report was endorsed in general terms, noting the importance of piloting and evaluation before final decisions were taken. Tasmania reserved its position.
Piloting began with Commonwealth funding support and a draft evaluation of the pilots was considered by MCEETYA in November 1994.

MCEETYA agreed to amend the name of the system to `Australian Vocational Training System' (AVTS) and to phased implementation from January 1995, with priority being given to apprenticeships and traineeships in existing and new areas, and gradual and sustained increases in AVTS activities in schools. Milestones for implementation are to be reviewed at the next MCEETYA meeting in the light of available resources.

In September 1992 the AEC, meeting with MOVEET, received the Mayer Committee's report, endorsed the definition of key competencies and agreed on a set of seven key competencies that are essential for all young Australians.
The Commonwealth is providing funds to support the development, trial and evaluation of the key competencies. No final decisions have been taken by MCEETYA on Key Competencies implementation.

ANSWER.PARA: Higher Education: Commonwealth—State roles and responsibilities

PARA.TAB: In April 1991 the AEC asked the Joint Working Group on Higher Education to draft an agreement to set out a process for consultation between the Commonwealth and the States on higher education policy and planning, to identify their shared and separate responsibilities and to establish a simpler system of payment to higher education institutions.

In August 1991 the AEC endorsed the draft Agreement Between the Commonwealth and States in Relation to Higher Education. The Agreement makes it clear that policy and planning are joint responsibilities of the State/Territories and the Commonwealth. At this meeting, Queensland, the Northern Territory and South Australia reserved their positions with regard to direct Commonwealth payments to institutions.

The draft agreement was considered subsequently at the Premiers' and Chief Ministers' meeting in November 1991. The Communique from that meeting noted that the accountability and transparency to the community of Commonwealth funding for higher education should be improved and that this could be achieved by clarifying that public funding of universities is the responsibility of the Commonwealth.

The Premiers and Chief Ministers agreed that direct funding from the Commonwealth to institutions would be appropriate. Legislation to implement the new funding arrangements was subsequently developed on the basis of the consultation processes specified in the Agreement Between the Commonwealth and States in Relation to Higher Education. The agreement is now in place and is being applied.

ANSWER.PARA: National Communications Framework for Education Delivery

PARA.TAB: In April 1991 the AEC received a report from the Working Party on the Use of Satellite Facilities for Distance Education. The AEC subsequently agreed to establish a cross sectoral Working Party on a National Education Communications Framework (NECF) to develop a national, open access curriculum framework for national telecommunications delivery, in conjunction with collaborative curriculum development.
The AEC received the Working Party's progress report in October 1991 and, as a first stage, agreed:
to the collaborative development of nationally agreed guidelines on the use of communications technology in education and training;
to the preparation of a feasibility study for a proposed small national collaborative education communications body;

that the Working Party establish a sub-group to conduct negotiations with regulatory bodies and service providers regarding the principles underlying the policies for the education sector which these bodies currently hold;
to the development of common/agreed equipment specifications for use in establishing contracts accessible by the education and training sectors;

that brokerage assistance in linking national educational technology projects with relevant design expertise be provided initially from a sub-group of the Working Party NECF and subsequently from the proposed national collaborative education communications body; and
to the provision of a full-time secretariat to assist the Working Party in the tasks identified above.

In June 1992 Ministers agreed to the establishment of the Open Learning Technology Corporation (OLTC) to be owned by Commonwealth and State/Territory Ministers. It was further agreed that the OLTC should consist of three major service areas related to the delivery of open learning and distance education: education management, technological management and project management.

The Commonwealth gave a commitment to provide elements of catalytic funding to the OLTC to develop specifications for a national open learning information service. At the end of 1994, the Department of Employment, Education and Training provided establishment funding to the OLTC to provide an Open Learning Information Service and report to MCEETYA on services and associated cost regimes.

In September 1992 the AEC noted the Senate Standing Committee Report on Adult and Community Education Come in Cinderella and the Commonwealth Government's response to it. AEC agreed to establish a Working Party to consider the implications of the Report and to draft some national policies or principles on adult and community education.

In December 1993 the Working Party reported and AEC endorsed the National Policy on Adult and Community Education. All Ministers also agreed to advise the Council (now MCEETYA) at the end of 1995 on implementation activities and outcomes arising from the Policy.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Human Services and Health, upon notice, on 6 February 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Did the Government introduce measures in March 1993 which allowed Australian Hearing Services (AHS) to monopolise the market in hearing aids.
(2) Has her attention been drawn to difficulties being experienced by private sector hearing aid providers since March 1993.
(3) Is the situation in the provision of hearing aids consistent with the Government's national competition policy.
(4) Is the cost of hearing aids provided by AHS lower than that which was provided by the private sector; if so, on what basis.
(5) Is it a fact that AHS does not allow private practitioners to test pensioners' hearing in the same manner that optometrists are permitted to test eyesight; if so, why.
(6) Does AHS claim that it needs to control the market because eligible pensioners are incapable of making informed choices when dealing with the private sector; if so, does she support the claim.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) No. In March 1993 the Government extended fringe benefit entitlements to all pensioners. These benefits include hearing services from AHS and are provided through a combination of AHS hearing centres and over 100 private sector contractors.

(2) I met with representatives of the hearing services industry in August 1994. At that meeting matters relating to the arrangements for providing Commonwealth hearing concessions to pensioners were discussed openly.

(3) Yes. For any government the principles of competition and the associated efficiency objectives must be reconciled with broader social objectives. A balance between these is nowhere more crucial than in the provision of special benefits for the purpose of social equity; in this case government funded hearing services to pensioners.

(4) Yes. The cost of purchasing and fitting hearing aids by AHS is approximately $300 below the schedule fee paid to private sector providers for monaural fitting under service contract arrangements. AHS costs for binaural fittings are some $500 below the contract schedule fee for the same service. The incidence of binaural fittings by AHS contractors is 53%. Thus the average (weighted) difference between AHS costs and the schedule of fees for AHS contractors is approximately $400 per client. AHS costs have been calculated on the basis of full-cost and accrual accounting principles by external consultants.

(5) AHS contracts out to accredited audiologists and audiometrists adult clients (pensioners and Commonwealth Seniors) who are excess to the operational capacity of AHS. These clients are free to attend the accredited provider of their choice and are provided with a directory of contractors for this purpose.

The range of services associated with hearing rehabilitation is broader than testing and are provided by a service industry in which there is varying levels of expertise and no registration standards. Differences in the levels of audiological and optometrical benefits provided by the Commonwealth and in the status of providers makes direct comparisons between AHS services and the testing of eyesight inappropriate.

(6) AHS, as the statutory provider of Commonwealth hearing services to children and pensioners, does not, nor does it seek to, control the private market (i.e. all those over 21 years who are not pensioners, eligible veterans, Health Benefit or Commonwealth Seniors card holders). As detailed above, Commonwealth beneficiaries referred to AHS contractors are free to choose their own service provider. AHS contract arrangements with accredited private sector agents involve standards that ensure pensioners receive appropriate levels and quality of service. The use by AHS of private sector contractors is monitored continually against levels of demand for services and AHS's obligations to its 300,000 existing child and adult clients and for responsible fiscal management.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 27 March 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) What is Australia's annual defence budget.
(2) Do RAAF pilots sign a contract of service which binds them to the Australian Defence Force (ADF) for a period of years.
(3) Are the weapons which the Steyr F88 rifle is replacing being sold overseas; if so, to which countries.
(4) Have several equipment purchases for the ADF been found inadequate for the ADF's needs; if so, are selection methods being reviewed.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The 1994-95 Defence Budget is $9,637 million.

(2) RAAF officers do not sign any specific employment contract with the RAAF. All RAAF officers are initially appointed to be an officer in the RAAF for a specified period under Air Force Regulation 46(1). An officer appointed for a specified period of service may, on or before the expiration of that period, volunteer for a further period of service or for permanent appointment and the Chief of the Air Staff may extend the appointment for a further specified period or convert the appointment to a permanent appointment accordingly.

When officers undertake special training, or special duty, or a period of service outside Australia, they may incur a Return of Service Obligation. The principal intent of the Return of Service Obligation policy is to assure the continuing service of the member for such a period as will provide the Service with a productive return for the investment in the skills and knowledge acquired by the member as a result, for example, the Return of Service Obligation for basic pilot training is ten years. Pilots with an obligation are not normally permitted to leave the RAAF until the obligation has been served.
(3) Currently, none of the replaced weapons are being sold either overseas or internally (except for a few to State Authorities for feral pest control). Weapons disposed of so far have been smelted.

(4) Equipment which does not meet the stated Defence requirements would not usually be accepted into service. The Defence processes are intended to achieve an acceptable outcome, which balances user expectations with practicable, cost-effective solutions. Broadly, this is achieved by capability considerations determining the project scope; value-for-money considerations in the source selection process, which may trade-off non-essential characteristics in a range of criteria; progressive testing and evaluation by the contractor and Defence during the contract period and final acceptance into service testing.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of Employment, Education and Training: Staff located in Canberra

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 29 March 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is the RAAF seeking 10,000 square metres of storage space at the former No. 7 Stores Depot (7SD) site in Toowoomba.
(2) Has the RAAF approached the private owner of the site.
(3) Does the requirement for storage space relate to proposed additional aircraft deployment to RAAF Base Amberley; if not, what is the reason for the requirement.
(4) Has the RAAF offered to pay twice the current commercial rental rate for the type of storage space required; if so, why.
(5) How critical is the need for additional storage space.
(6) Was the need for storage space considered during the Defence Logistic Redevelopment program which led to the decision to close 7SD.
(7) What options are available to the Department of Defence if the former 7SD site is not available.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The RAAF is not specifically seeking storage space at the former No. 7 Stores Depot (7SD) site. The 10,000 square metres storage area is at this stage an arbitrary figure for planning purposes only.

(2) A representative from RAAF Amberley did approach the owner of the former 7SD site for advice on available storage space and cost. A quote was provided by the owner but no further action was taken by the RAAF.

(3) The requirement for additional storage space does not relate to any additional aircraft deployments to RAAF Amberley. Rather, it relates to the USAF decision in 1994 to withdraw the F-111s from service over the next few years. As the RAAF plans to operate the F-111 for a longer period, it is intended to take advantage of the opportunity to acquire stocks of spares at low cost.
(4) The RAAF has not made any offer to any individual or organisation for storage space required for the aircraft spares.
(5) The amount of additional storage space, if any, has yet to be determined.

(6) The USAF decision to withdraw its F-111 fleet was only made in late December 1994. Previous USAF planning was for EF-111A operations to continue until 2015. The possible need for this additional storage space could not have been identified during the Defence Logistics Redevelopment Program.
(7) If it is determined that extra storage space is required because of this new development, the Department of Defence will evaluate all available options on a value for money basis.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 30 March 1995:

PARA.TAB: Has the Minister's Department entered negotiations for the purchase by the Commonwealth of land adjacent to HMAS Waterhen, Balls Head Road, Waverton, NSW; if so,
(a) when did the Minister first become aware of the negotiations or proposed purchase,
(b) has a contract for the purchase of the land been signed; if so, (i) on what date and (ii) what date is named in the contract for its completion,
(c) what price will be paid for the land,
(d) what are the (i) dimensions and (ii) Land Titles Office lot-and-plan descriptions of the land,

(e) is it a fact that the land use planning and zoning of part of the land has been under review by the Waverton Peninsula Task Force, comprising the NSW Property Services Group, the NSW Department of Planning, the North Sydney Council, the Waverton Precinct Committee, local residents and Commonwealth and State members of parliament from the area; if so, when did the Minister and his Department become aware of the task force and its review,

(f) is it also a fact that the task force invited the Minister's Department to participate in discussions and resolution of the use of the land; if so, (i) when did the Minister and the Department become aware of the invitation and (ii) what was the Minister's and the Department's response to the invitation,
(g) did the Department or a representative participate in the task force; if so, (i) when and (ii) in what form,
(h) what are the details of the proposed use of the land,
(i) will use of the land include accommodation for (i) married (ii) or unmarried personnel,
(j) if the land is used for accommodation, how many personnel will be accommodated,
(k) has the Department budgeted for the (i) purchase of the land or (ii) construction of buildings; if so, (A) what provisions have been made and (B) for which years have they been made,

(l) are the Commonwealth and the Minister's Department required to (i) comply with (A) NSW planning laws and (B) the North Sydney Council's planning, development and building codes and (ii) notify State and local agencies of land use, development or building proposals for the land,
(m) will the proposed use of the land comply with the North Sydney Council's planning, development and building codes, and
(n) will the Department notify local residents and the North Sydney Council of its proposals in accordance with the same requirements which apply to private landholders.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: (a) I was first made aware of the proposed acquisition of land adjacent to HMAS Waterhen, Balls Head Road, Waverton, when I approved the 1994/95 Defence Acquisitions Program on 15 July 1994.

(b) A contract for the purchase of the land has been signed and completed for the acquisition by the Commonwealth of land adjacent to HMAS Waterhen. A parcel of 3,863 square metres fronting Balls Head Road was acquired by compulsory process, by agreement with the then NSW Property Services Group, on the date of the gazettal of the compulsory acquisition, being 8 March 1995. A further 7,948 square metres of land was acquired by agreement and settled on 20 January 1995.

(c) An amount of $2,095,777.00 was paid to the State of NSW as compensation for the compulsory acquisition of the 3,863 square metre parcel. The 7,948 square metre parcel was acquired by agreement for $4,404,229.00.
(d) The land(s) are described as 3,863 square metres being Lot 1 in Deposited Plan 837879 and Lot 94 in Deposited Plan 840347, and 7,948 square metres being Lot 2 in Deposited Plan 837879.

(e) It is a fact that a review was conducted and reported on by a Waverton Peninsula Task Force. I was not aware of the task force but the Department of Defence became aware of the task force through a letter from the North Sydney Council dated 6 June 1994.

(f) I was not aware of any invitation but it is a fact that in Council's letter of 6 June 1994, the General Manager of the North Sydney Council invited the HMAS Waterhen Project Director to nominate a representative to the task force. The invitation to participate on the task force was declined by the Department of Defence as the then landowner, the NSW State Government, was in a more appropriate position to consider the matters before the task force.
(g) Neither the Department of Defence nor a representative participated in the task force.
(h) The land has been acquired for the proposed development of residential accommodation for Australian Defence Force personnel.
(i) Use of the land will provide accommodation for personnel of mixed gender and rank, predominantly unmarried personnel.
(j) Present planning by the Defence Department provides for accommodation for up to 200 personnel.

(k) $6.5 million was provided for the purchase of the land from within the 1994/95 Defence budget. Budget provision for construction of facilities will be made once requirement details are finalised and Government approval given to a specific construction project.
(l) (i) (A) and (B)—no. (ii) The Department of Defence will, in accordance with Commonwealth requirements, consult with relevant State and local planning authorities on any such development proposal.
(m) The Department of Defence intends to use the land in a way which accords with the North Sydney Council's present planning, development and building codes.

(n) As part of the consultation process, the Department of Defence will ensure that local residents and the North Sydney Council are notified of Defence's proposed use and development of this land; the form of such notification will depend to some extent on the initial consultations with State and local planning authorities.
